## Page 44

Regional Cultural Chronology One of the most significant identified potentials for site 41COL172 relates to the refinement of the regional cultural chronology. Single-component and temporally restricted sites with in situ diagnostic materials in the upper reaches of the East Fork of the Trinity River are rare. The majority of the regional understanding of prehistory is based on multicomponent sites with mixed assemblages on, or near, the main branches of the Trinity River (e.g., Ferring and Yates 1997, 1998; Yates and Ferring 1986). Given the position of site 41COL172, a testable hypothesis was established concerning the artifact types and styles present at the site. Given that types and styles are often time transgressive, the site has the unique ability to test the pre-established regional date ranges for these diagnostic artifacts. For example, a Pennington Punctated-Incised ceramic sherd was identified at the site during the 2006 test excavations. This sherd type indicates an extension of Caddo influence into the area. Although Caddoan traits are not altogether uncommon on the East Fork Trinity River (cf. Lynott 1975; Stephenson 1952), similar sherds have not come from well-dated sites or contexts. Thus, the specific nature and timing of the introduction of Caddo influence, Caddo ideology, or Caddo people themselves into the area is undocumented. The initial investigations at site 41COL172 suggested that the site represented a limited span of occupation during the Late Prehistoric period, and the materials appeared to be well preserved and in relatively good context, given the vertisolic nature of the deposits characteristic of the area. Particular emphasis was thus placed on identifying and recovering datable materials from the specific portions of the site that yielded Caddoan-influenced materials. Paleoenvironmental Reconstruction Paleoenvironmental reconstructions of the Late Quaternary period focusing on Northcentral Texas are rare in number; but environmental change has been often cited as a mechanism for social change during the Late Prehistoric period (Dillehay 1974; Lynott 1981). There are four commonly employed analyses for such reconstructions: pollen, phytoliths, land snails, and isotopes. In Northcentral Texas, pollen is generally not well preserved in the clay-rich alluvial soils common to the region. Phytolith morphology is still poorly understood as it relates to specific plant parts and thus remains unreliable to the Prairie/Cross Timbers ecotone. Snail diversity is relatively untested in the region because the smallest species of snails may be susceptible to pedoturbation processes. This leaves isotopic studies as the only reliably tested paleoclimatic proxy for the region. To date, there have been only three isotopic studies from localities within Northcentral Texas (Brown 1998; Frederick 2009; Humphrey and Ferring 1994). The most comprehensive paleoenvironmental reconstruction within the upper Trinity River valley is Humphrey and Ferring’s (1994) isotopic study of bulk organic and pedogenic carbonates at the Aubrey site (see also Ferring 1989, 2001). The Aubrey record extends from the terminal Pleistocene through most of the Late Holocene period. Although the record is extremely useful for much of the Holocene, the record contains only three data points for the period post-2000 14C years before present (yr B.P.)—and none extend into the Late Prehistoric period (post-1250 14C yr B.P.). Brown’s (1998) study at site 41DL270 focused on characterizing isotopic variability in mussel shell features. Brown’s record spanned much of the Late Holocene from 3570 to 760 14C yr B.P. The study identified a relatively small shift in δ18O and δ13C ratios within the period, but three general trends were identified. One peak in O and C ratios between 1500 and 2500 14C yr B.P. 24


---

## Page 45

was noted and attributed to an increase in moisture and/or a decrease in temperature. Similar to the final data points at Aubrey, the record at 41DL270 appears to concur that a relatively modern isotopic regime established around 2000 14C yr B.P. A subsequent study of bulk organic δ13C by Geo-Marine was conducted at site 41DL203, located only 7 km south of 41COL172 and in a similar setting. Site 41DL203 is important for establishing a local isotopic signature that extends firmly within the Late Prehistoric period. The record at 41DL203 shows a progressive trend of increasing abundance of C grasses throughout the period before a dramatic shift to an abundance 3 of more arid-adopted plants around 500 years ago. This shift occurs much later in time than it does at both Aubrey and other well-documented sites in Texas from outside the region (i.e., Nordt et al. 1994, 2002; Quigg et al. 2008). Whether the record at 41DL203 reflects a highly localized or regional signature needs to be further addressed, and the study at 41COL172 was conducted to complement this data. Subsistence Practices The high level of preservation of faunal materials present at site 41COL172 provides a unique opportunity to address research questions relating to subsistence practices of hunter-gatherer groups in Northcentral Texas. The specific themes for the faunal analysis at the site were to address the environmental availability of prey and the analysis of carcass exploitation (butchering procedures). One of the most seemingly significant discoveries at the site was the presence of bison in the collection. Bison populations are known to have varied in abundance during the Late Holocene in Northcentral Texas and this would have certainly affected the lives of hunter- gatherer groups in the area (Dillehay 1974; Lynott 1981). There are only a few regional archaeological sites dating to the Late Prehistoric with associated bison remains. Site 41COL172 thus has the opportunity to shed light on the relationship between bison and Late Prehistoric peoples. The presence of such well-preserved faunal materials, recognized during the identification and testing seasons at the site, was also of interest because preservation of floral evidence was thought to likely have a high probability also. Consequently, a subset of flotation samples was processed with the goal of determining if such floral preservation existed. Technological Patterns Technology and the processes prehistoric people used to convert raw materials into consumable goods is the basis for understanding behaviors of Late Prehistoric populations in the upper East Fork of the Trinity River. In light of the kinds of materials associated with the site, analysis focused on issues relating to lithic and ceramic technologies. As previously stated, some of the ceramic sherds recovered from site 41COL172 during the first testing season possessed decorative motifs similar to those found farther east. Initial inspection of the vessel indicated that the vessel type, paste, and method of construction were all indicative of an East Texas influence. One of question that would help to better understand the nature of the relationship between local Late Prehistoric populations and Caddo peoples rests in the identification of the clay source(s) used to create this vessel. Recently, researchers have begun making strides toward identifying regional clay sources using instrumental neutron activation analysis (INAA). The facilities at the University of Missouri Research Reactor (MURR) have 25


---

## Page 46

helped analyze the ceramic assemblage of the George C. Davis site (Descantes et al. 2004). From the analysis, it was concluded that clays from multiple sources exhibiting potentially different ceramic recipes were used to make various Caddo pottery types. Thus, it is possible that Caddo potters reserved specific types of clays or combinations of clays for specific types of vessels. This research has subsequently been expanded to include nearly 1,000 samples from Caddo sites in East Texas, Northwest Louisiana, Southwest Arkansas, and Eastern Oklahoma (Ferguson et al. 2008). Although similarities in regional geology often obscure clear recognition of isolated sources, a total of 11 distinct regions have presently been identified in East Texas. Given the fact that the ceramic type identified at site 41COL172 was defined at the George C. Davis site, it was postulated that the vessel may have been constructed in a similar fashion. If so, the clay recipes indicated by INAA should reflect those at the Davis site. Clay sources dramatically different from those found at the George C. Davis site would either suggest interaction with other Caddo groups or, potentially, local manufacture. Regional Exchange and Interaction No specific items in the assemblage from site 41COL172 would immediately be labeled as exotic materials. The absence of exotic materials limits insight into long-distance exchange. However, items are present in the assemblage that represent at least a regional interaction with other groups. The type of exchange represented by the ceramic assemblage was unknown prior to this study. Shafer (2006) has suggested that the many numerous sites in Central Texas exhibit characteristics that do not match with either the Austin or Toyah complexes. Some of these traits include early Caddo ceramic types and decorative motifs, similar to those identified at the George C. Davis site; early bone-tempered pottery; large bifacial knives such as the Gahagan or Friday types; early stemmed arrow points such as Bonham-Alba points; and deer metapodial beamers. Shafer (2006) notes that these traits have been used as indicators of trade with Caddo groups; however, they may also be indicative of a group of Caddo who did not consider the Piney Woods villages of East Texas as a permanent home. Instead, he proposes that some hunter-gatherer groups in Central Texas may have ideologically, and perhaps linguistically, considered themselves to be Caddo. However, their home range is centered on the Southern Plains instead of the Piney Woods. The geographic distribution of artifacts that Shafer identifies for defining the Southern Prairie Caddo model has no easily perceived corollary with the northern prairie of the upper Trinity River. One reason for this is, in part, due to a time-transgressive distribution. For instance, the Prairie Caddo that Shafer (2006) proposes is pinned on the date range between A.D. 1000 and 1300. It has been suggested that the relative abundance of bison populations on the Southern Prairie has had a dramatic affect on altering the lifeways of prehistoric hunter-gatherer groups (Dillehay 1974; Lynott 1981; Prikryl 1990). When bison populations were relatively scant, Prairie Caddo groups would have been more reliant on agricultural lands to the east. During the date range proposed by Shafer, bison populations may have been sparse in Northcentral Texas, and the region may have been all but abandoned. When bison populations reappeared in the area, after A.D. 1300, the technological traditions that were noted by Shafer would have transgressed into later Caddo types. Many of these later ceramic types have been noted on Northcentral Texas sites such as Cobb-Pool (Peter and McGregor 1988), Pecan Springs (Sorrow et al. 1966), and at sites attributed to the Wylie Focus, such as Hogge Bridge (Stephenson 1952). 26

## Page 47

The Cobb-Pool site in Dallas County has raised the greatest questions concerning an outlier hamlet of the Caddo in Northcentral Texas. The ceramic collection at Cobb-Pool contained many sherds with Caddoan traits, and the architectural styles seen at the site were certainly indicative of those found to the east. However, Peter and McGregor (1988) argued that the traits represented trade or an adoption of ideals and not the actual movement of East Texas Caddo populations onto the prairie. Investigations in light of Shafer’s model position site 41COL172 at place where the site can offer additional data to apply to this important area of inquiry. As with the earlier investigations at the Cobb-Pool site (Peter and McGregor 1988), raw materials used for lithic and ceramic tools are critical to this research issue. FIELD METHODS Testing Phase The testing phase of archaeological research at 41COL172 consisted of two seasons of investigations. During the first season (2006), six backhoe trenches were excavated to an average depth of 2.20 m below surface (mbs). A 50-x-50-cm test unit accompanied each trench and was excavated to an average depth of 70 cm within cultural-bearing units on the site. During the second season (2007), 10 additional backhoe trenches were excavated across the site. Controlled excavation during the second testing season included four 2-x-2-m blocks and one irregular 2.5-x- 2.5 m block placed within and adjacent to cultural-bearing backhoe trenches. Additionally, 13 auger cores were taken across the site to determine the vertical limits of the paleosol, which has shown to contain the archaeologically relevant materials at the site. Mechanical Trenching Sixteen trenches (which include the two 4-x-4-m Trenches 9 and 10) were excavated in the project area (Figure 3) by a backhoe with a bucket approximately 1 m in width. One trench was placed south of a channel swale visible on aerial maps of the area. Since no cultural materials were located in the trench, it was determined that the paleochannel delimited the southern boundary of the site. The remaining 15 trenches were all located north of the paleochannel and were excavated to determine the extent of the cultural deposits to the east and west. The 14 long trenches measured approximately 4.6 m in length with gradually sloping or stepped floors to allow for entry and egress. Each trench was approximately 1.5–2 m wide and was excavated to approximately 2.5 m below the surface. Prior to hand excavation, an area covering approximately 3-x-2.5 m was stripped to provide a safe excavation area. All mechanical trenching was carried out under the supervision of Geo-Marine personnel, who monitored the excavated matrix for the presence of cultural materials. Manual Excavation To recover finer data, manual excavation units of varying dimensions—0.5-x-0.5 m, 1-x-1 m, and 2-x-2 m—were placed on the sides of, and within, selected backhoe trenches (see Figure 3). All hand units were excavated in 10-cm-thick levels using shovels and trowels to an average depth of 2 m below the original ground surface. All excavated matrix was screened onsite through 6.4- 27

Animal bone, baked clay masses, ceramic sherds, lithic tools and debitage, fire-cracked rock, mussel shell fragments, and particularly large pieces of wood charcoal were collected and delivered to the Geo-Marine laboratory in Plano, Texas. Field observations were documented on standard Geo-Marine forms for each level within each unit, with separate forms for each feature encountered. Data Recovery Phase As with the testing phase, the mitigation or data recovery phase at 41COL172 consisted of three major stages. First, the surface soil and sediments were mechanically removed from a 20-x-20-m surface to expose the stripped top of the paleosol encountered during the previous NRHP testing phase. The second stage consisted of a geophysical survey within the stripped surface to identify areas that were likely hearths or other activity areas. Finally, manual excavation proceeded by (1) testing the anomalies encountered during the geophysical survey and (2) establishing two excavation blocks around identified features (see Figure 3). Mechanical Stripping A trackhoe with a bucket approximately 1 m in width was used to mechanically strip upper deposits from the area selected for mitigation. The 20-m stripped surface was positioned over the area of greatest concentration of cultural materials identified during the testing seasons. The trackhoe operator performed horizontal scrapes to remove approximately 20 cm at a time under the supervision of Geo-Marine archaeologists, who observed that the paleosol and its associated concentrations of cultural materials were not encountered at consistent depths across the stripped surface. To avoid disturbing culturally relevant layers, the stripping extended only to a depth of 1.0–1.4 m instead of the uniform 1.5-m depth discussed in the scope of work. At the southern end of the 20-m stripped surface, the paleosol was much deeper than in the northern portion due to the location of the paleochannel at the southern end of the site. Approximately 50 cm of overburden were left intact over this area in order to avoid stripping away culturally relevant stratigraphic units with the trackhoe. Geophysical Survey The goal for the data recovery phase was to investigate activity areas surrounding hearths, earth ovens, or other isolable components at the site. In order to identify likely areas and target the excavations, the 20-m stripped surface was surveyed with a Bartington Grad601 dual fluxgate gradiometer (see Bartington and Chapman 2004). This instrument contains two sets of fluxgate magnetometers oriented in vertical alignment with a 1-m separation between sensors. The fluxgate sensors are sensitive to changes in the magnetic field at an absolute resolution of 0.03 nanotesla (nT). Within each set, one sensor is located approximately 0.25 m from the ground surface and the second sensor is located 1 m above the first. Archaeological features such as hearths or earth ovens that have been fired beyond the Curie point often contain thermoremnant magnetism and will cause disturbances in the background magnetic field between 0.1 and several hundred nT. 29


---

## Page 50

Data were collected within the survey grid at a sufficiently high resolution such that archaeological features as small as a post mold would be detected given sufficient magnetic contrasts. Each sensor was calibrated and aligned to magnetic north prior to data collection. All transects were oriented in a N–S direction and collected at 0.25-m spacing. Eight readings were collected within each meter along each transect. These methods yield 28 readings per square meter within the survey. The data set was then downloaded to a laptop computer and processed in Surfer 8. A zero-mean-traverse function was applied to the data to remove small-scale drifts in the background magnetic field encountered during the survey. The data set was then interpolated and clipped to ± 10 nT to display archaeologically relevant anomalies within the data. Manual Excavation Five anomalies were selected from the magnetometry data for excavations. The specific results of the excavations are discussed fully in Chapter 6. Based on the proximity of two anomalies, two data recovery excavation blocks were set up within the 20-m stripped surface. The larger main excavation block—Block 1—was originally laid out at 4-x-3 m, in the northeast quadrant of the stripped surface. Block 1 was placed diagonally to the cardinal directions to allow the block to be positioned directly adjacent to former test units excavated during the testing phase (see Figure 3). The second excavation block—the smaller Block 2—was placed directly adjacent to and in alignment with the Trench 9 excavations, which encountered the greatest concentration of artifacts during the testing seasons. Given that the results of the testing phase indicated that the cultural occupation zones were most likely contained within sloping strata, all 1-x-1-m units were excavated in 5-cm-thick natural levels. The overburden above the cultural-bearing paleosol was removed within the first level of each unit. Small erosional features were noted at the top of the paleosol and were excavated separately from the remainder of the fill. A total station was used to establish vertical datums and record large fragments of animal bone, fire-cracked rock, ceramic sherds, and mussel shell fragments encountered in situ during excavation. The total station was set up over the same ground surface datum each day and two back sight measurements were collected to account for small errors in data collection. All excavated matrix was screened onsite through 6.4-mm mesh hardware cloth. Animal bone, baked clay masses, ceramic sherds, lithic tools and debitage, fire-cracked rock, and mussel shell fragments were collected from the screens. Due to its fragility, charcoal was not systematically collected from the screens. Particularly large fragments (over approximately 1 cm in diameter or length) were noted and collected in situ before removal of the matrix, but smaller flecks and chunks were noted only. Field observations were documented on standard Geo-Marine forms for each 5-cm level within each 1-x-1-m test unit, with separate forms for each feature encountered. All recovered materials were bagged, labeled, and delivered to the Geo-Marine laboratory (see Laboratory Procedures below). In the laboratory, a field sample number was assigned to each excavated context (for instance, one 5-cm level within a 1-x-1-m subunit, or half of a bisected feature), and all materials associated with that context were inventoried. Flotation samples were collected from all features encountered and also from a continuous 15-x-15-cm column in 5-cm- thick levels corresponding to levels throughout the rest of the block. 30

## Page 51

Geoarchaeology Fieldwork for both the testing and data recovery phase included geoarchaeological study of the exposed deposits. The various field and laboratory methods employed are discussed briefly here; more details of the geoarchaeological analyses are presented in Chapter 7. The most fundamental geoarchaeological method used at 41COL172 was the creation of measured profile drawings. During the testing phase, the project geoarchaeologist described and photographed a subset of the mechanically excavated trenches. In most cases, the end wall of the trench was cleaned (usually with a pick mattock, knife, and trowel), and the deposits described. A similar strategy was followed in the data recovery phase subsequent to hand excavation of the data recovery Blocks 1 and 2. The deposits were described in general accordance with Schoeneberger et al. (2002) with the exception that the fundamental unit of field observation was a ―zone,‖ which was used to represent any physically different deposit. All zones were subsequently assigned soil horizon designations. The approximate age of the deposits examined in the field was inferred on the basis of the degree of soil development in accordance with general principles outlined by Birkeland (1999). Geoarchaeological study of the fully excavated data recovery blocks also included several analyses of a continuous 15-x-15-cm column of sediment from within the west wall of Block 1. The columns were collected in 5-cm levels to correspond to the rest of the data recovery block. The 15-x-15-cm column samples were processed in the laboratory to determine grain sizes represented, calcium carbonate content, magnetic susceptibility, and microartifact inclusions, with the overall goal of illuminating depositional and taphonomic processes. A similar column of magnetic susceptibility samples was also collected from within Block 2 to address magnetic variations across the site due to intensity of human activity. Subsequent to collection of all geoarchaeological samples and archaeological materials, the 20-m- stripped surface and the excavation units were mechanically backfilled under the supervision of Geo-Marine personnel. LABORATORY PROCEDURES All cultural material recovered during both testing and data recovery was returned to the Geo- Marine laboratory facilities in Plano, Texas, to be washed, weighed, counted, catalogued, and labeled in compliance with Texas Archeological Research Laboratory (TARL) standards prior to analyses. Context and attribute data for all materials were recorded in a Microsoft ACCESS database on an IBM network system. The main categories of material recovered were animal bone, mussel shell, baked clay masses, lithics, ceramics, botanical samples (both flotation samples and opportunistically collected wood charcoal), and fire-cracked rock (FCR). Lithic tools and debitage, baked clay masses, and FCR were analyzed in the Geo-Marine laboratory; ceramics, faunal materials, mussel shells, and a subset of botanical remains (selected wood charcoal samples) were sent to external analysts. The following discussion describes analytical strategies and summarizes the attributes recorded during the analysis of each class of material. 31

## Page 52

Faunal Remains Measures of differential survivorship (i.e., taphonomy) were carried out on the faunal assemblage as a whole as well as its temporal subdivisions in order to assess human verses natural modifications to bone surfaces. Every attempt was made to identify bone fragments to the highest taxonomic level possible. Bone specimens not bearing diagnostic features but similar in size and other formal characteristics were placed within specific size classes: small terrestrial mammal (STM), medium terrestrial mammal (MTM), large terrestrial mammal (LTM), and very large terrestrial mammal (VLTM). Assessments were also made of the following characteristics: bone element, size/weight of fragment, fusion state, rodent gnawing, burning/butchery evidence, number of identifiable specimens (NISP), and standard metric analyses (see Chapter 9). Benjamin Fullerton of Geo-Marine and Dr. Steve Wolverton conducted the faunal analyses. Mollusk Shells Professional examination of the mussel shell umbos collected from the site was conducted by Charles Randklev, and the identifications and their implications are discussed in Chapter 9. Analysis of the molluscan collection was conducted with the following goals: 1. Identification of individuals assigned to class, order, suborder, family, genus, and species according to their identifiability. 2. Identification of evidence of human alteration or tool use. 3. Interpretation of environmental information (i.e., stream environment, seasonality) indicated by molluscan species through time. 4. Interpretation of importance of mollusks to diet and whether consumption amount was affecting local molluscan population. Botanical Remains All features encountered in the manual excavations were bisected, and half of the feature was bulk collected and floated to recover charred and uncharred plant remains. A standard oil-drum flotation apparatus with upward water flow—sometimes called a Siraf system—was employed to separate material of interest from extraneous matrix. The light fraction—in other words, charcoal fragments and other buoyant objects scooped from the water surface—was dried and then passed through 6.35 millimeter (mm) and 0.5 mm screens. The heavy fraction—in other words, material that sank to the bottom of the apparatus—was dried and passed through 6.35 mm and 1.6 mm screens. Heavy-fraction objects larger than 6.35 mm were sorted into material classes (FCR, lithics, bone, etc.) and integrated into the corresponding collections from the excavations. Heavy materials smaller than 6.35 mm were set aside for later discard, with the exception of bone fragments and lithics, which were integrated into the appropriate assemblages with the larger pieces. The fine and coarse components of the light fraction material from each context were examined by Geo-Marine personnel using hand lenses and microscopes as necessary. Professional examination of the wood charcoal was undertaken by Dr. J. Phil Dering, and the identifications and their implications are discussed in Chapter 7. 32

## Page 53

Chipped Stone Tools and Debitage Geo-Marine personnel conducted an analysis of 100 percent of the lithic cores, tools, and unmodified lithic debitage recovered from general proveniences (see Chapter 7). The analysis was to address the following themes: 1. Definition of lithic tools into functional categories and description of each functional category with illustrations of representative samples. 2. Analysis of projectile points, definition of types, discussion of type groups, and illustration of representative specimens. 3. Classification of lithic debitage into raw material categories and the analysis of basic attributes (including dorsal cortex presence/absence, heating, size category). Broader questions to be addressed were to include the following: (1) implications of tool and debitage attributes for the lithic reduction process at 41COL172 (e.g., is tool/point production or maintenance/reworking or a combination represented at the site? Are different processes represented within different contexts?); and (2) implications of local versus nonlocal origin of tools and debitage (e.g., raw material availability and procurement, and the potential range of mobility and/or exchange). Baked Clay Irregular, gravel-sized masses of hardened clay, many with evidence of oxidation, reduction, or smudging due to fire, were common in cultural levels in trenches and test units. A basic analysis of these masses was performed in the Geo-Marine laboratory, where they were separated by the presence or absence of plant impressions and insect burrows (see Chapter 7). These categories were then subdivided into size classes: smaller than 0.5 in (12.7 mm), 0.5–1 in (12.7–25.4 mm), 1–1.5 in (25.4–38.1 mm), 1.5–2 in (38.1–50.8 mm), and larger than 2 in (50.8 mm). No materials in the collection were larger than 1.5 in, so the only the three smallest size classes were included in the report of the analysis. The cumulative weight and total number of baked clay masses within each class and within each context were then recorded in the project ACCESS database. Fire-Cracked Rock FCR was subjected to a similar basic analysis in the Geo-Marine laboratory. Fragments were first sorted based by rock material type (e.g., sandstone, limestone, quartzite), and any direct evidence of heating (e.g., fracture pattern, discoloration) noted (see Chapter 8). Within material types, the FCR was then sorted into size classes: smaller than 0.5 in (12.7 mm), 0.5–1 in (12.7–25.4 mm), 1–1.5 in (25.4–38.1 mm), 1.5–2 in (38.1–50.8 mm), 2–4 in (50.8–101.6 mm), 4–6 in (101.6– 152.4 mm), and larger than 6 in (152.4 mm). No FCR fragments larger than 4 in were found, and thus the largest size classes were not included in the analysis. The cumulative weight and total number of FCR fragments within each class and within each archaeological context were then recorded in the project ACCESS database. 33

Ceramics Detailed analysis of the ceramic sherds from 41COL172 was performed by Dr. Timothy K. Perttula. The analysis separated sherds based on differences in temper, type of sherd (i.e., rim, body, or base), rim and lip form, decoration (if present), surface treatment (smoothing, burnishing, or polishing), and firing conditions (see Chapter 10). The specific goal of the analysis was to identify the number of vessels represented in the collection and project the likely cultural group or region in which the ceramics were produced. To aid in this latter goal, five samples, representing individual vessels, were submitted to the Archaeometry Laboratory at the Missouri Research Reactor for neutron activation analysis (NAA). The NAA results were compared to a large database of ceramics from northern and eastern Texas to identify clay source regions. CURATION Upon completion of the analyses and reporting, collected materials will be assessed for the appropriateness for long-term curation. Some classes of recovered remains, such as burned rocks, residual and bulk unprocessed soil samples, unidentifiable shell fragments, nonartifacts from the heavy and light fractions of sediment columns (e.g., coarse sand, gravel, rootlets, etc.), unburned (e.g., likely modern) macrobotanical remains, mass-produced Historic period artifacts less than 50 years of age, etc., will be earmarked for discard. A list of such materials will be prepared and submitted to the THC for approval before disposal. Artifact inventories will be annotated to reflect the disposal of approved materials. The remaining collections from the project will be prepared for curation according to the packaging guidelines established by TARL at the University of Texas, Austin. Field and laboratory forms will be on acid-free paper; negatives and photographs will be labeled and placed in acid-free holders; cleaned and labeled artifacts will be placed in appropriate bags and boxes suitable for long-term storage. An inventory of materials submitted to curation will be prepared and a copy will be sent with the collection to TARL for long-term storage. 34

CHAPTER 5 RESULTS OF THE TEST EXCAVATIONS by Arlo McKee with contributions by Darryl Pleasant and Aaron Naumann MECHANICAL TRENCHING AND CORING RESULTS Geo-Marine conducted test excavations at site 41COL172 during two seasons between November 2006 and September 2007. As part of these investigations, 16 test trenches were mechanically excavated within the project area (Figure 4). Cultural materials and culturally significant ecofacts were identified and recovered in the backfill and within profile walls from the majority of the trenches (n=12). One trench (Trench F) was placed south of a subtle channel scar visible on the surface at the southern end of the project area. No archaeological materials were identified in Trench F and it was determined that the paleochannel, visible both on the surface and within a buried context, marked the southern boundary of the site (see Figure 2). Stratigraphy The stratigraphic context of the site was largely interpreted from the 16 test trenches excavated at site 41COL172. Each of the trenches was inspected and described in detail by geoarchaeological specialists. A generalized soil-stratigraphic description is presented in Table 2. All formal descriptions are presented in Appendix B at the end of the report. The test trench results indicated that there were two distinct packages of alluvial sediment at the site: (1) Late Holocene Alluvium; and (2) Recent Alluvium. Subsequent coring at the site during the 2007 field season revealed a third package of alluvium located beneath the Late Holocene Alluvium. This basal alluvium is assumed to be Holocene in age; however, no absolute dates were obtained. An interpretive cross section of the southern floodplain of Muddy Creek is presented in Figure 5. Earlier Alluvium Core Hole 13 was the only core that penetrated through the alluvial deposits within the Muddy Creek floodplain. The deposit is bounded on top by a dark-colored buried soil that exhibits an A- C profile that is approximately 60 cm thick. ## Page 58

deposits, the unit most likely corresponds to the middle Holocene Sanger Alluvium (Ferring 1990b). Typically, the Sanger Alluvium is bounded on top by the well-developed Arlington Paleosol, which has an eroded A horizon and prominent argillic Btk horizon. The general lack of development of the buried soil within the Earlier Alluvium suggests that either this represents an immature profile of the Sanger Alluvium or a basal section of the Pilot Point Alluvium. Late Holocene Alluvium Cultural materials identified during the testing seasons were all found to be associated within the upper 1.5 m of a thick, clay-rich alluvial deposit buried beneath roughly 1–2 m of recent sediments. At the top of the late Holocene deposit is a thick, cumulic paleosol that shows well- developed A and B soil horizons. This paleosol caps the Late Holocene Alluvium that was found to be over 3 m thick in one core hole (Core Hole 13) that penetrated it completely. The contact between the overlying sediments and the upper boundary of the paleosol is abrupt and wavy, as evident from a number of small swales that were observed in trench and test unit walls (Figure 6). These features suggest that the break represents an erosional boundary and not just a slowing of deposition. The erosional nature of the upper boundary is further supported by the absence of the paleosol in some of the core holes (e.g., Core Hole 6). Given the narrowness of the Muddy Creek valley, it is to be expected that many, if not all, of the preexisting deposits would be removed or deeply eroded by the succeeding units. However, the well-developed A-Bk profile indicates that the landform was relatively stable for a considerable length of time before being buried by the Recent Alluvium. The vast majority of the sediment observed in the site area was very fine-grained and calcareous (see Appendix B). These limey, clay-rich deposits did contain minor amounts of silt, sand, and gravel. Normally, coarse materials are found as coatings on ped faces or soil partings or as thin beds or lenses. The calcareous, fine-grained nature of the deposits is the result of Muddy Creek flowing exclusively over the shaley limestones and limey shales of the Austin Chalk and Ozan Formation. These bedrock formations contain very little in the way of coarse clastics. Although the availability of clastic materials is lacking, Muddy Creek has had enough energy to transport coarser materials at times in the past when they were available (note the presence of gravel in many of the core hole and trench wall profiles). The initial survey, which led to the discovery of site 41COL172, discussed the commonly known and accepted sequence of the five floodplain stratigraphic units of Late Pleistocene to modern age in the upper Trinity River valley (Cliff et al. 1998; Ferring 1986, 1990a, 1990b, 1995; Ferring and Yates 1997; Sills et al. 2005). The discussion of the sequence of soils was presented as a backdrop for the ultimate interpretation that the buried paleosol composing the matrix for site 41COL172 matches well with the West Fork Paleosol (Sills et al. 2005). The paleosol at the site has many of the normal pedologic characteristics of the late Holocene-age West Fork Paleosol (e.g., moderately high level of soil development, strong blocky structure, gastropod shells, and clay and carbonate illuviation). The presence of these features indicates a long period of relative landform stability with low sedimentation rates and accumulation of organic material in the site area. 38

Recent Alluvium The uppermost 1.1–1.6 m of deposits in the site area are alluvial sediments that resemble the Trinity soil series. The top 65–85 cm of sediment are composed of gray (10YR 4/1) silty clay that shows organic enrichment and evidence of a thin, discontinuous plowzone. The upper portion of the A horizon is massive, with blocky structure increasing with depth. Small roots are present are present in the upper portion s of the horizon. Faunal materials were observed within the matrix of this horizon, but no cultural material was recovered. Thus, these faunal materials within the modern alluvium are interpreted as the result of natural processes. Underlying the A horizon is a light grayish brown (10YR 6/2) silty clay C horizon that extends to a depth of approximately 135–150 cm. The lightness in color of the relatively unaltered C horizon of the Recent Alluvium contrasts with the parent material of the underlying stratigraphic units. This suggests that the two alluvial units are derived from separable distinct sources. Whether the sources represent different beds eroded from bedrock or a difference in clastic organic materials derived from redeposited alluvium remains unknown. TRENCH RESULTS: CULTURAL MATERIALS An ultimate result of the two seasons of test excavations at site 41COL172 was the determination that the site covers an area of approximately 567 m2. The northern portion of the site is bordered by the southern bank of Muddy Creek. The southern and eastern boundaries appear to be outlined by a paleochannel of Muddy Creek, which formerly flowed south of the current channel (see Figure 5). The filled channel scar was faintly visible on the surface in aerial photographs and 40

During the 2006 field season, six 50-x-50-cm units were excavated to an average depth of 70 cm. This provided a total of approximately 1.05 m3 of fill excavated from culturally relevant deposits at the site. 41

## Page 62

In 2007, a strategy of excavating 2-x-2-m excavation blocks with 1-x-1-m subunits in association with culturally positive trenches was employed. In total, five of these blocks were excavated and one was expanded around an exposed feature. This provided for an additional 19.7 m3 of fill excavated from the site. The excavation results from each testing season are summarized in the following sections, and the specific material analyses are presented in Chapters 7–10. The results of the radiocarbon analysis, which were performed later, are integrated into the field observations. 0.5-x-0.5-m Test Units (2006 Season) Test Unit 1 (Trench A) Test Unit 1 was placed off the northwest corner of Trench A. This trench was the westernmost trench excavated during the 2006 testing season. The excavations yielded one flake fragment, seven pieces of FCR, five shell fragments, one piece of charcoal, and 18 bone fragments (Table 4). Within the backfill of Trench A, additional cultural materials were recovered (see Table 3). The high number of faunal materials recovered from Trench A was attributed to the materials being broken during the excavation of the trench. Although the material collected within Test Unit 1 appears to be markedly less dense than that collected in Trench A, the test unit yielded the second highest number of artifacts at the site behind Trench B and Test Unit 2. Test Unit 2 (Trench B) Test Unit 2 was placed off the northeast corner of Trench B. These units were placed just west of the proposed centerline for the realignment of FM 1378 and consequently between the initial identification survey trenches (see Figure 2). Test Unit 2 was excavated to a depth of 70 cm below the top of the buried paleosol, and then the unit was profiled and photographed. The stratigraphy observed in this test unit mirrored the observations in Trench A. The backdirt from the trench excavation yielded 36 bone fragments and three shell fragments (see Table 3). One of the shell fragments was suspected to be worked or modified through use. Test Unit 2 produced the highest frequency and greatest array of cultural materials recovered during the 2006 testing of the site (see Table 4). The single ceramic sherd recovered in the test unit was of great interest at the time of its discovery because the high level of craftsmanship that it displayed was indicative of nonlocal wares attributed to the Caddo region of East Texas (Figure 7). A detailed analysis of this sherd and the others recovered during subsequent seasons is presented in Chapter 10. Test Unit 3 (Trench C) Test Unit 3 was placed off the northeast corner of Trench C. The trench was placed to the southeast of Trench A in order to define the southern extend of the cultural deposits. Test Unit 3 was excavated to a depth of 60 cm below the top of the buried paleosol, and then the unit was profiled and photographed. The profile observed in this test unit mirrored that observed in the previous test units with the exception that the buried A horizon appeared to be thinner in this test unit. The lower density and diversity of artifacts recovered from Test Unit 3 and the decreased thickness of the buried A horizon were interpreted as evidence of the site margins. However, 13 bone fragments and 40 shell fragments were recovered from this test unit (Table 5). 42

paleosol and one end of the unit was 10–15 cm higher than the other. As a result, the excavation began in the elevated section and the other portion of the unit was incorporated when the unit surface was level. The extent of the impact on data is unknown, but given the fact that cultural materials (16 bone fragments) were recovered from this unit, it is assumed that there was some data loss. The excavation of Test Unit 5 produced one lithic fragment, five bone fragments, and one piece of shell (see Table 5). Compared to the previous test units, the low density of cultural materials was interpreted as evidence of the site margin. Given the fact that Trench E was placed on the margin of the paleochannel, it was determined that it was unlikely that the site extended farther to the east of this location. Test Unit 6 (Trench F) Test Unit 6 was placed on the northeast corner of Trench F, the final trench excavated during the 2006 season. Trench F was placed south of the paleochannel of Muddy Creek and was the southernmost trench at 41COL172. There were two reasons for placing the trench south of the paleochannel. First, prior to the excavation of this trench, the southern boundary of the site was only hypothesized to be marked by the paleochannel. This trench confirmed this hypothesis. Second, the trench was placed on the southern bank of the paleochannel in order to confirm that this surficial feature was indeed an expression of a prominent filled former channel of Muddy Creek. Trench F yielded only four small bone fragments. Cultural materials identified in Test Unit 6 were limited to 10 very small fragmentary bones and two shell fragments (see Table 5). The sparse bone and shell fragments were interpreted as being the result of natural processes. For instance, the small shell fragments tend to be ubiquitous in the sediment and lack any sign of human manipulation. Furthermore, the bone recovered in this test unit was much more weathered than in the five northern units. This led to the interpretation that taphonomic processes, and not cultural processes, redeposited these fragments as secondary materials in the solum. Thus, the location of this trench and test unit is interpreted as being beyond the southern extent of the site. 2-x-2-m Test Blocks (2007 Season) At the end of the first testing season, the low density of cultural materials and the single ceramic sherd recovered from the site firmly placed 41COL172 in the Late Prehistoric period. Still, not enough information was gathered from the site to determine eligibility for NRHP inclusion. Thus, a second season of testing was warranted. A total of five excavation blocks with 1-x-1-m subunits was placed on the edges of 10 additional test trenches. The excavation blocks were numbered according to the associated trench, and subunits were numbered consecutively from the previous season. Not every trench excavated during the second season was selected for a hand excavation block. Only those trenches that were positive for significant cultural materials were selected. These were Trenches 5, 7–10. The specific results of these excavations are summarized below. 46

Trench 5 (Test Units 25–28) The first excavation block was placed on the western edge of Trench 5 at the eastern end of the site. The trench (yielding debitage, bone, and shell primarily; see Table 3) and test units provided valuable information pertaining to the buried landform within which the cultural materials were contained. Within these units, small remnants of erosional gullies were visible and there was a marked eastward slope to the paleosol (Figure 8). This suggested that the buried landform was both sloping to the southeast and draining toward the paleochannel or an associated lowland drainage (Figure 5.6). 8. View of the north profile of Test Unit 25 showing the two erosional features at the top of the buried soil. Note that although the photo board shows ―Unit 5,‖ this is actually Test Unit 25. No formal features were encountered in this excavation block. There were several areas of interest where artifact and faunal remains clustered, but none appeared to be intentional. One thin, dark linear stain was identified within the southern portion of Test Unit 28. The stain appeared in Level 1 within the upper portion of the buried soil. The area was 50 cm wide and 1 m long, crossing the entire level east-to-west; however, it was not noted in neighboring units. A denser concentration of artifacts, charcoal flecks, and small baked clay nodules was within the stain than in surrounding areas of the unit. The zone was exposed, bisected, and determined to be limited to only a few centimeters thick. The zone was interpreted as evidence of krotovina. 47

This was interpreted as evidence that at the time of occupation, the channel of Muddy Creek was located either north or south of the current location. The shell concentration also appeared to be associated with a peripheral scatter of bone, shell, FCR, and lithic debris. Given that the feature was concentrated in the southeast corner of the unit, it is likely that the excavation of Trench 7 destroyed much of the feature. Trench 9 (Test Units 13–16, 22–24) Trench 9 was a shallow trench excavated for the sole purpose of removing overburden to accommodate a 2-x-2-m excavation block in the center of the site. Due to the discovery of a large feature within the block, the unit placement was altered to accommodate exposing as much of the feature as possible with the allotted time. The trench was excavated to expose a surface at approximately 110 cmbs and was approximately 4 m square. In terms of cultural content and stratigraphic details, this excavation block was clearly the most productive. Two features were designated within the block. Additionally, a previously unknown horizon consisting of fragmented shell was discovered below the main occupation of the site. The top of the excavations began at 110 cmbs and continued to a depth of 220 cmbs in the deepest unit (Figure 14). Many of the northern units were excavated to a shallower depth than the southern units due to the strong southward slope of the paleosol. A total of 4,574 artifacts was recovered from the Trench 9 excavation block (Table 9). The majority of the artifacts were recovered within Levels 3–7, between 140 and 190 cmbs. Within this 50 cm-thick zone, two distinct cultural occupation zones were identified–although, directly associating materials by raw depths below the surface with each of the occupation zones is difficult due to the sloping stratigraphy. The first zone was associated the A horizon of the buried soil. In Test Units 15 and 16, a charcoal-filled basin feature was identified and designated as Feature 2 (Figure 15). Associated with Feature 2 was a scatter of deer and turtle bone, FCR, and mussel shell that followed the general stratigraphic slope of the buried paleosol. The densest concentration of materials associated with Feature 2 was found north and west ends of the basin feature. Additional 1-x-0.5-m and 0.5-x-0.5-m excavation units were established on the north and west sides of Test Units 15 and 16 in order to expose a greater area of this concentration. 53

10 excavations produced very little cultural information (Table 10). Two ceramic sherds were recovered from Test Unit 20 (these are further discussed in Chapter 10). The bulk of the remaining material collected was faunal. Several small clusters of FCR, bone, and mussel shell were identified during the excavations. SUMMARY The preliminary evaluation of site 41COL172 recovered 10,125 artifacts, consisting of 7 ceramic sherds, 385 lithics, 185 pieces of fire-cracked rock, 328 pieces of baked clay, 2 fragments of ochre, 528 pieces of charcoal, 5,244 mussel shell fragments, and 3,446 bone fragments. In addition to these artifacts, three features were identified, and one (Feature 2) is interpreted as a hearth. In addition to the exposed hearth an activity area surrounding Feature 2 was exposed. In conjunction with the Feature 2 excavations, at least two distinct cultural occupation zones were identified within the buried soil. The most prominent occupation represented in the profile was found to be associated with the buried A horizon of the paleosol. The lower component was found to be associated with a dense zone of highly fragmented mussel shell below the buried A horizon. From the test excavations, it was determined that discrete activity areas and separable components were not apparent within all areas of the site. Thus, the initial goal of the data recovery excavations was to identify areas which contained the best probability for locating additional activity areas. 60

## Page 83

CHAPTER 6 DATA RECOVERY RESULTS by Arlo McKee INTRODUCTION The data recovery excavations took place during two different field seasons. The first portion of fieldwork was conducted between June 30 and July 23, 2009. For various reasons discussed in Chapter 1, the project was then halted, before resuming again between November 30, 2009, and January 7, 2010. Between the two sessions, the open excavations were covered with plastic and earthen fill to minimize data loss between the seasons. Although the ownership of the project changed hands and multiple field personnel were not able to return for the second season, the project maintained a coherent whole with unchanged objectives. Encouragingly, no data appeared to be lost or compromised as a result of the logistical transition. The goal of the data recovery excavations was to target specific areas of site 41COL172 that were likely to yield in situ activity areas with separable components. Two results from the testing season guided the data recovery excavation strategy. First, the site was shown to contain variable densities of cultural materials within a limited area. Second, these materials were situated within the upper portion of a paleosol that exhibited a prominent south-to-southeastward slope. The data recovery strategy thus focused on exposing a wide, 20-x-20-m area centered on the units that produced the highest density of materials during the 2007 season. From within the 20-m block, approximately 1–1.7 m of overburden were removed to expose a surface immediately above the West Fork Paleosol. The exposed surface was generally shallower at the northern end of the block and deeper at the southern end. During the mechanical excavation, the project archaeologist periodically instructed the trackhoe operator to halt efforts in order to excavate a small shovel test-sized (approximately 20 cm) exploratory hole to determine the remaining depth to the surface of the paleosol. In most areas of the block, mechanical excavations were terminated approximately 5–10 cm above the paleosol surface. In the southwestern corner of the block, however, the paleosol sloped abruptly and mechanical excavations ceased at 1.7 m below the surface. This resulted in 35–50 cm of overburden remaining intact above the site. The second step in the data recovery field season was the data collection from a magnetic gradiometer survey. This was performed over the exposed surface to target anomalies that likely reflected hearths or concentrations of fire-cracked rock. A 1-x-1-m excavation unit was then placed over each anomaly. In each case, the test units were set up with the same orientation as adjacent test units from the 2007 testing season. In order to maintain the previous grid, the test 63


---

## Page 84

units were often placed slightly off-center from the central point of the anomaly. When an anomaly fell between multiple possible units, the northernmost unit was selected for excavation due to the northward direction of the ambient magnetic field at mid-latitudes (Hanson et al. 2005). A total station datum was established on the ground surface at the northern end of the site in order to maintain vertical and horizontal control of the excavation units. Arbitrary test unit datums were established with the total station on the exposed surface to allow the excavators to measure the vertical elevations of the 5-cm test unit levels. Based on the findings of the test unit, the measured depths below surface were converted to depths below the surface of the sloping paleosol. This was done in order to compare the findings of test units between multiple areas of the site. (The results presented in this chapter are listed as depths below the paleosol surface. The reader is referred to Appendix A for a listing of all artifacts according to absolute depths below the ground surface.) Once the test units positively yielded a significant cultural feature, additional adjacent test units were established. In total, 24 test units were excavated, producing an additional 16.31 m3 excavated from the site. The following chapter details the findings of the data recovery season and presents the results of the radiocarbon analysis, which was performed following the data recovery season. MAGNETIC SURVEY The magnetic gradiometer survey was performed on July 2, 2009, within the 20-m block. The specific methods of the survey are outlined in Chapter 4. Since the survey was performed within the 20-m block, which still had actively slumping margins, the resulting data set was slightly narrower than the 20-m grid (Figure 18). The survey was also negatively affected by numerous sources of metal across the site. An erosion control fence had been installed surrounding the two backdirt piles on the east and west sides of the 20-m block (Figure 19). Unfortunately, the fence had been installed with 2-ft steel t-posts, which seriously affected the data on the margins of the survey grid. Additionally, nails and other metal excavation equipment had been backfilled within the previous excavation units. This resulted in a serious amount of noise in the data, especially in the center of the survey grid near the Trench 9 excavations. Even with the considerable amount of metal scattered across the site, five monopole anomalies were selected for investigation. The anomalies were numbered sequentially and a 1-x-1-m excavation unit was established over each anomaly as described above. The anomalies selected ranged in strength from 3.1 to 11.5 nT above the background magnetic field. Three of the five anomalies selected (Anomalies 1–3) were all located in the northeast section of the 20-m block. Numerous other faint disturbances in the magnetic field strength were observed in the area, though it was unclear prior to excavation whether these represented significant cultural features. The southern half of the block was relatively quiet, compared to the northeast section. The absence of magnetic anomalies in the southern (especially southeastern) edge of the block generally supports the findings from the testing seasons of low cultural densities at that area of the site. Accordingly, no excavations were focused at the southeastern portion of the site. Anomaly Test Units Anomaly 1: Test Unit 31 Anomaly 1 was identified in the northwestern section of the 20-m block approximately 2.5 m west of Test Unit 28, which was excavated during the 2007 field season (see Chapter 5). ## Page 92

As the excavations continued below 50 cm bps in Test Unit 36, carbonate threads increased and the artifact frequencies dropped off considerably. This test unit was excavated during the height of summer, when temperatures were consistently over 100°F. Consequently, a vertical crack formed within the test unit that extended through the north and south walls as well as the floor of the test unit (Figure 23). The crack was more than 2.5 cm wide and persisted for more than 1 m. Although no artifacts were identified directly within the crack, this is one piece of evidence suggesting that portions of the site may have been subjected to intense argilliturbation and the vertical distribution of, at least some, of the artifacts may be caused by the vertic properties of the soil (Abbott 2001:84–86). Very few artifacts were identified below 60 cm bps in the test unit, and the majority of these were small fragments of shell and faunal materials. Thus, the materials identified deep within the test unit may have been more mobile within the profile and were translocated through shrink-swell processes. 23. View of the vertical crack in the north wall of Test Unit 36. Figure 23. View of the vertical crack in the north wall of Test Unit 36. Also visible within the profile in Figure 23 is a 10-cm-thick dark horizon beginning at approximately 55 cm bps. When the matrix was moist, the change in color compared to overlying materials was almost imperceptible. However, as the profile desiccated, the overlying and underlying horizons dried to gray or grayish brown (10YR 5/1–2), while this zone retained a very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) color. This suggests that a second buried soil is present at the site. Curiously, this break in sedimentation, indicated by the buried soil, appears to be associated with the rather ephemeral cultural materials, deep within the profile, rather than the relatively dense materials found within the overlying buried Bw horizon. 72

Anomaly 4: Test Unit 37 Anomaly 4 was an irregularly shaped anomaly located immediately south of the 2007 Trench 9 excavations. The anomaly appeared slightly elongated in the east–west direction; however, it was unclear if this was an interpolation effect from the metal disturbance within the former trench excavations. Because of the excessive nearby disturbance, the anomaly was not initially selected for investigation. However, the investigations in this area produced the best evidence for the lowest cultural component during the data recovery excavations. Test Unit 37 was established slightly to the north of the center of Anomaly 4. The stripped surface of the test unit began at 129 cmbs, and the surface of the paleosol was encountered at 136 cmbs. Within this test unit, faunal materials and a few very small shell fragments were the only artifacts recovered from the buried A and Bw horizons of the paleosol (Table 15). Instead, the greatest concentration of artifacts was recovered from below 50 cm bps. At 55 cm bps, a concentration of mussel shell was identified in the western half of the test unit (Figure 24). The concentration was not formally designated as a feature because, when it was informally bisected, it was found to be only a couple centimeters thick. Several pieces of lithic debitage and some small bone fragments were also identified on the periphery of the cluster of shell. Although other areas of the site had produced modified or burned mussel shell (see Chapter 9), none of the shell recovered from Test Unit 37 appeared to be modified. Anomaly 5: Test Unit 38 Not only was Anomaly 5 the weakest anomaly selected for testing (2.4 nT), but Test Unit 38 was the least productive of the anomaly test units. Anomaly 5 was located at the western end of the 20-m block, immediately to the east of Trench C from the 2007 testing season. The anomaly was faintly apparent, about a meter in diameter, adjacent to the disturbed area of Trench C and the effects of the silt fence posts. In this area, approximately 30 cm of overburden were left over the intact paleosol surface because much of the Recent Alluvium was found to be mottled from prior trench disturbance. It was decided to err on the side of caution and leave more overburden over the paleosol instead of accidentally removing a portion of the site with the trackhoe. Test Unit 38 was positioned directly over the faint anomaly. The stripped surface of the test unit began at 116 cmbs. A total of 28 cm of overburden was removed from the first level of the unit to expose the paleosol at 144 cmbs. A total of 60 artifacts was recovered from the test unit, the majority of which were recovered from the lighter-colored Bw horizon below the A horizon of the paleosol (Table 16). The majority of the remains recovered were small fragments of deer and deer-sized mammal bone. The test unit was terminated from a lack of recovery at 60 cm bps in order to focus on more productive areas of the site. Anomaly Test Unit Compilation Figures 25 and 26 display the frequency of artifacts recovered from the five anomaly test units. The results of the individual test units consistently showed that, although the paleosol surface was at different depths below the ground surface, the stratigraphy within the paleosol was consistent across the site. The colors on the data bars represent the interpretation of how the artifacts relate to the multiple cultural occupations, or phases, at the site. Based on the changes in observed artifact frequencies corresponding to stratigraphic position below the top of the paleosol, the artifactual materials were grouped into three phases, or cultural occupations (see Figures 25 and 26). In the Geo-Marine laboratory, the field proveniences from both testing seasons and the data recovery season were assigned to a specific phase based on the depth below the surface of the paleosol. Not shown in the figures above are materials recovered from within the Recent Alluvium, above the paleosol. These materials were assigned to Phase 0, to denote their stratigraphic position above the rest of the site. Since the A horizon of the paleosol was generally 25 cm thick, all materials within 25 cm of the paleosol surface were identified as Phase 1. Phase 2 was assigned to materials between 25 and 50 cm below the paleosol surface in order to reflect the thickness of the Bw horizon. Materials recovered below 76

## Page 98

BLOCK EXCAVATIONS Excavation Block 1 Based on the results of the anomaly excavation units, only one definitive hearth (Feature 09-01) was identified at the northeastern end of the 20-m block. Given that the test units in the area yielded separable components and other, yet untested, weakly expressed anomalies were in the area, a 4-x-3-m excavation block was established around Test Units 31 and 32. During the excavations, this area was termed Excavation Block 1. In order to further investigate the areas surrounding positively identified features, Excavation Block 1 was later expanded to include three additional units to the north and two units to the west of the original 4-x-3-m area. Work in Excavation Block 1 proceeded by first removing the overburden of each unit to expose the surface of the paleosol. When this was accomplished, it became apparent that the surface of the paleosol sloped dramatically to the south-southeast. From the northwest corner of the block to the southeast corner, there was an overall observed difference in the depth to the paleosol of 26 cm. Figures 27 and 28 display, in profile, the slope observed in the north–south direction. Further compounding the paleosol surface were numerous erosional gullies that were generally oriented east–west along the excavation grid. Two of these gullies are visible in the west wall profiles. It is assumed that these features reflect a gap in sedimentation, where the exposed surface was scoured during storm events, which resulted in small portions of the site being removed. In order to account for these features during the excavations, the paleosol general surface was first exposed. The fill within the gullies was then excavated separately from the rest of the unit within the paleosol. Levels were excavated following the macroslope of the paleosol instead of following the contours of the erosional gullies. The excavations in Block 1 consisted of resulted in 9.91 m3 of fill excavated from within the cultural-bearing deposits at the site. The initial intention was for each test unit to be excavated to 80 cm within the paleosol. However, this strategy was modified due to a lack of recovery below approximately 50 cm. Instead, two test units (35 and 41) were excavated below 80 cm, and the excavation block was terminated when these two excavation units failed to produce cultural materials at depth. In total, 6,041 (16,132 g) cultural materials were recovered from Excavation Block 1 (Table 17). No clearly identifiable living or activity surfaces were encountered during the excavations. Instead, variable densities of artifacts were present throughout the profile. When possible, large in situ materials, such as FCR, bone, and shell concentrations, were piece-plotted with the total station. No clear-cut occupation surface could be pinpointed across the excavation block, and these data were lumped back with the remaining test unit collections. From the profile in Figure 28, it is apparent that a clear shell horizon, as identified at other portions of the site, is not present in the area of Block 1. Instead, the concentration of artifacts appeared simply to be widely scattered in the soil. Below 50 cm bps, several large krotovina were identified as the generally dark sediments lightened in color from drying. Like the lower ABk horizon, identified in Test Unit 36, the krotovina were almost imperceptible when the test units were first excavated. Then, when the sediments were allowed to dry, the bioturbated zones remained darker in color, while the surrounding matrix lightened slightly. Numerous small artifacts and ecofacts including, hackberry endocarps, burned earth, FCR, bone, and shell, were identified within the krotovina. This suggested that at least some of the vertical distribution of artifacts throughout the profile was 78

The distal portion of a bison radius was identified shallowly within the profile in Test Unit 44 (Figure 29). The bone fragment was identified with numerous small fragments of lithic debitage and small mussel shell fragments within proximity. The area was not formally identified as a feature, but the bone was certainly humanly deposited as evidenced by the signs of butchery in the form of cut marks and spiral-fractures. A radiocarbon date was obtained from the bison bone, yielding a date of 450 ± 40 14C yr B.P. (2 Sigma Range: 1420–1480 Cal. A.D.: Beta 279342). ## Page 104

for flotation. When further explored, the feature was found to be approximately 7 cm thick in the center. In total, the feature produced a total of 182 small fragments (4,946 g) of FCR, 46 pieces of lithic debitage, 21 animal bone fragments, and 37 fragments of burned earth. It is important to note that the FCR was not found lining the shallow basin, but was instead scattered throughout the stain. From the general lack of burned earth and ash, it seems doubtful that this concentration represents the remains of a hearth, but is instead a clean-out pile from a nearby hearth. A plum/cherry wood charcoal fragment was recovered from a flotation sample from this feature and was dated to 770 ± 40 14C yr B.P. (2 Sigma Range: 1210–1290 Cal. A.D.: Beta 279343). A total of 11 ceramic sherds was recovered within Excavation Block 1. All of the recovered sherds were from the westernmost line of test units of the initial block (31, 35, 40, and 41). Of particular interest during the field season was that most of the decorated sherds appeared to belong to the same Pennington Punctated-Incised type as the initial sherd identified during the 2006 field season. Figure 31 displays the vertical distribution of the ceramics within Excavation Block 1 according to depth below the paleosol surface. The most productive test units for ceramics were Test Units 40 and 35. Within Unit 40, three decorated Pennington Punctated- Incised rim sherds were identified within the upper 10 cm of the paleosol surface. The sherds refit to form a continuous section of punctuate-filled incised triangles (Figure 32). The decoration on these sherds appeared to be identical to the initial Pennington sherd recovered during the 2006 testing season. Several additional undecorated ceramics and one small fragment of the Pennington vessel were recovered from Test Unit 35 throughout a vertical distribution of 28 cm. Discussed fully in Chapter 10, the ceramic analysis suggests that the ceramics recovered from the site were likely broken from four or five vessels, and Unit 31 contained sherds from two of these. The vertical distribution of the sherds is problematic for interpreting the integrity of the site. Figure 33 shows the distribution of the ceramics within the profile of Block 1. The radiocarbon dates obtained from a combination of charcoal from feature fill and animal bone are in logical order, with the oldest dates at the bottom of the profile and the youngest at top. However, multiple sherds from both Vessels 1 and 3 were recovered from multiple different elevations, suggesting that the sherds had been redeposited through the soil by pedoturbation. At the George C. Davis site and multiple Caddo sites in northwestern Louisiana, the Pennington Punctated-Incised ceramic sherds have been confidently dated to the period between A.D. 1000 to 1300 (e.g., Girard 2009; Perttula 1997; Stokes and Woodring 1981). Given the dates obtained from the bison radius (Beta 279342) and Feature 09-01 (Beta 279344), the presence of the Pennington vessel is anomalous. The earlier date between A.D. 1210 and 1290 obtained from Feature 09-03 (Beta 279343) appears to be a much closer approximation for when the Pennington ceramics were deposited at the site. This would pin the sherds to the latter period of the Pennington range. Evidently, however, for the dates to be in agreement with the ceramics, the interpretation is that the ceramics high within the profile (especially the Pennington sherd in Test Unit 40) must have been redistributed upward through the profile. Although it was not attempted as part of this project, this is an instance where a lithic refit analysis would be helpful in addressing further the degree of pedoturbation at the site. 86

Excavation Block 2 A second set of test units, referred to as Excavation Block 2, was placed adjacent to the Trench 9 excavations from the 2007 testing season. In this area, a hearth feature (Feature 2) was identified during the testing season (see Chapter 5). Surrounding the hearth was a dense scatter of well- preserved bone and shell remains that appeared to be concentrated in the northwestern section of the excavation units. Upon the conclusion of the testing season, it was felt that additional information could be gained by excavating units to the north and west of the initial units. Excavation Block 2 therefore consisted of four contiguous 1-x-1-m units, oriented in an L-shape, located on the periphery of the Feature 2 excavations. The new units were established by first excavating a trench within the former 2007 excavation units to identify the edge of the units. Compared to Excavation Block 1, the artifact density was roughly similar in these four excavation units. The main difference was that within the Lower Late Prehistoric (Phase 2) levels the dense accumulation of mussel shell was present in Excavation Block 2, but was not in Block 1 (Table 18). Curiously, only 12 lithic fragments (10 debitage, and 2 broken projectile points) were recovered from these test units. This yielded a lithic density of four fragments per m3, whereas the lithic density of Excavation Block 1 was approximately 37 fragments per m3. Given that bone and shell were found in abundance in this portion of the site, a working interpretation was that this portion of the site was consistently used as a processing area, but tool production and maintenance occurred in other areas, such as Block 1. 88

SUMMARY OF DATING RESULTS After the data recovery excavations were complete and all artifacts were washed and sorted, an evaluation of the datable materials within the collection was made. Small fragments of charcoal, which was fairly ubiquitous throughout most test units at the site, were collected from multiple contexts at the site: feature fill, profile walls, general screened matrix, and mapped locations within excavation unit floors. Because no clearly identifiable occupation surfaces were encountered during the excavations, the specific location of small materials, such as charcoal, within the profile was suspected to have been altered by various forms of pedoturbation. Charcoal materials collected during each of the three excavation seasons were thus filtered for those contexts that appeared to still have been in primary context and thus most clearly related to the human activities that deposited the materials. Hence, only large fragments of charcoal recovered from feature fill was selected for dating (Table 19). The only exception to this was that one fragment of charcoal collected from a profile wall within the lower ―shell layer‖ during the 2007 test excavations was dated. In addition to the charcoal dates, four bone fragments were also submitted for radiocarbon analysis. The bone fragments were chosen to provide upper and lower estimates for the archaeological deposits, as well as to provide a cross-check for the charcoal samples. Three of the four samples submitted were identified to white-tailed deer and deer-size mammal (see Chapter 9), but the final sample consisted of a portion of a distal bison radius. Since the association of Caddo-related materials and bison is poorly documented in Northcentral Texas, directly dating the bison remains was a key element in determining the timing of this possible connection. 92
