## Page 111

Figure 35 displays a plot of the 2-sigma dates of all samples from 41COL172 in order of increasing age from left to right. The suite of dates obtained from the site largely conforms to stratigraphic principles, with the oldest dates occurring at the bottom of the profile and the youngest at the top. These results were encouraging, since there were some soil features at the site that suggested that some amount of vertical mixing had occurred through bio- and argilliturbation. The total 2-sigma calibration range for the site was between A.D. 990 and 1480 (960–470 yr B.P.). One date was obtained from a deer bone recovered from within the Recent Alluvium, which has buried the site. This bone yielded a date between A.D. 1470 and 1660 (480– 290 yr B.P.), marking the onset of increased valley alluviation and the terminus ante quem for the Late Prehistoric occupation of site 41COL172. Most of the upper portion of the paleosol, which was assigned to the Upper Late Prehistoric analytical unit based on artifact densities, appears to have been occupied between roughly A.D. 1300 and 1400 (650–550 yr B.P.). The majority of the ceramic artifacts were recovered from within these depths, which is somewhat puzzling given the expected range for the Pennington Punctated-Incised sherds between A.D.1000 and 1300. As previously discussed, the occurrence of the Pennington sherds at both upper and lower portions of the A horizon is problematic for directly determining when the sherds were deposited. Direct dating of the sherds by thermoluminescence or optically stimulated luminescence are likely the only ways to determine when the Pennington sherds were made. Still, directly dating the sherds would give the date of construction for the pot, which may have been in circulation in a community or family for a considerable length of time before ultimately being left at the site. Whatever the case, the radiocarbon dates obtained from within the ceramic-bearing deposits at the site suggest that the sherds were deposited at the later range of the recognized period for the Pennington type. An even later date range was obtained from the bison radius found at the upper portion of the profile. This sample yielded a calibrated date between A.D. 1420 and 1480 (540–470 yr B.P.), which is confidently later than the recognized Pennington ceramic period. The dated bison remains were stratigraphically higher within the profile than the Pennington sherds recovered from adjacent units. One burnished and undecorated sherd, initially suspected to be part of the same vessel as the Pennington sherds, was recovered from approximately the same depth in Test Unit 31. If the sherd is indeed of Caddo origin, then its presence within the profile documents that the bison remains actually are associated with Caddo-related artifacts at the site (please see Chapter 10 for a full discussion of the results of the NAA, which partially indicate that this may not be the case). Although there is considerable statistical overlap between the samples through the profile, the features within the Lower Late Prehistoric analytical unit did not overlap quite as confidently as the features within the Upper unit. Feature 09-03 and the ―Shell Layer‖ were at approximately the same depths at different portions of the site and were initially suspected to be related features. However, the charcoal sample from the ―Shell Layer‖ yielded a slightly earlier date than the one from Feature 09-03. As a result, the interpretation is that these features may not have been contemporaneous and the Lower Late Prehistoric analytical unit (Phase 2–defined in this chapter) likely represents multiple discrete occupations. Finally, one small deer bone fragment was also dated from the lower portion of Excavation Block 1. Very few artifacts and bone fragments were recovered from below approximately 50 cm bps, and this bone was one of the larger fragments recovered. A calibrated date of A.D. 990–1160 (960–790 yr B.P.) was obtained from the fragment, which indicates a terminus post quem date for the site. This date also indicates that the maximum length of time that the site was repeatedly occupied was slightly less than a 500-year period. 94

CHAPTER 7 GEOARCHAEOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS by Arlo McKee and Charles Frederick, Ph.D. INTRODUCTION The geoarchaeological investigations at 41COL172 focused on three main topics. First, the studies were used to place the site within a stratigraphic context as a means of exploring the site formation processes. Second, the study focused on addressing the question of how many occupations are represented at the site. Finally, the study examined the paleoenvironmental history of the site. Quaternary paleoenvironmental reconstructions in Northcentral Texas are limited and the data should help to shed light on some of the environmental pressures relevant to the recent human past. REVIEW OF THE GEOLOGIC AND GEOMORPHIC CONTEXT Site 41COL172 is situated upon and within the Late Holocene alluvial sediments of Muddy Creek. Above the site, Muddy Creek flows mostly south, and turns southeast about one mile west of the site. The upper reaches of the Muddy Creek catchment are headed in the Austin Chalk (or Austin Group, undivided; Bureau of Economic Geology 1991), and the lower reaches drain the Upper Cretaceous Ozan Formation. The Austin Group consists primarily of alternating beds of chalk and marl, whereas the Ozan Formation is composed of calcareous dark gray clay. Hence, it is no surprise that the creek name reflects its fine-grained sediment load. As noted in Chapter 2, the surficial soil of the Muddy Creek floodplain is attributed to the Trinity Clay, frequently flooded, map unit (Hanson and Wheeler 1969). The site is situated between the modern channel of Muddy Creek and an arcuate paleomeander, which forms the southern boundary of the site. Part of the paleomeander was buried by recent roadwork that constructed a large earthen embankment oriented roughly parallel with the modern Muddy Creek channel. A succession of aerial photographs displays the modern impact to the landscape over the past 57 years (Figure 36). The project geoarchaeologist during the first season of test excavations speculated that the present channel of Muddy Creek was channelized in association with the construction of the Muddy Creek Reservoir immediately upstream of the site in the 1950s (Naumann 2007). An examination of the 1968 and 1953 aerial photographs confirms this point, as it is clear that the main channel on the 1968 photo is artificially straight 97


---

## Page 115

and articulated directly perpendicular to the dam. Unfortunately, the 1953 aerial photo of the site, which predates the construction of the dam, is too pixilated to be of much use in identifying whether the paleomeander adjacent to the site was active prior to channelization. However, the tree line (galleria forest) and an arcuate linear feature north of the rectified channel on this image suggest that the main channel was located north of the site and the paleomeander was, at least, not the main channel of Muddy Creek. DETAILED METHODOLOGY Field Methods Geoarchaeological observations were conducted in the field utilizing a combination of backhoe trench profiles, excavation unit profiles, and coring methods. Exposures selected at the site were cleaned with a trowel and knife, and described in general accordance with the methods described by Schoeneberger et al. (2002) and Birkeland (1999). Soil-stratigraphic descriptions deviated from the above methods with the use of the term ―zone‖ to describe each physically distinct deposit. For each zone, the field texture, Munsell color, moist consistence, structure, boundary, pedofeatures, and reaction with dilute hydrochloric acid were recorded, and a soil horizon was assigned. Calcic horizon stage assignments follow Gile et al. (1981) and Birkeland (1999). During the data recovery season a suite of three cores was collected from the site using an Eijkelkamp percussion coring set. The cores were collected with 10-cm- and 8-cm-diameter gouges and were logged and subsequently discarded. Core descriptions generally recorded color, moist consistence, boundary, and pedofeatures. Generally, structure was not recorded due to the small size of the sample. Laboratory Methods The physical properties of the sedimentary matrix of the site were documented from a series of 33 samples collected from 15-x-15-cm sample column samples collected at 5-cm increments during the excavation from Block 1 of the data recovery phase. For each sample, the texture (or particle size distribution), calcium carbonate content, magnetic susceptibility, organic carbon content, and stable carbon isotopic composition were determined. The details of the analytical methods employed are described below, and the results of the lab work are presented in Table 20 and Figure 37. Particle Size Analysis (Texture) Texture analysis was performed using the hydrometer-sieve method (cf. American Society for Testing Materials 1985; Bouyoucos 1962; Gee and Bauder 1986). Samples were first weighed moist and then gently passed through a 2-mm sieve taking care not to crush fragile bits of burned earth that might be present. When more than 200 g of <2-mm sediment were obtained, the remainder of the sample was transferred to a 1,000-milliliter (ml) beaker, and a 5 percent sodium hexametaphosphate solution was added to break down the clays and to permit separation of the >2-mm artifacts and gravels. After soaking for two days, during which time the samples were 98

Coarse material caught on the 2-mm sieve, if detrital sediment (and not artifactual), was then sieved at a 1-phi interval and the mass on each sieve recorded. In this particular case, cultural materials were counted and weighed separately for each size class so their depth distribution could be examined, as well as to exclude them from the detrital totals used to determine the properties of the alluvial sediments. A split of the <2-mm-size material (roughly 50 g) was then soaked in 50 ml of a 5 percent sodium hexametaphosphate solution overnight, and then mixed in a mechanical mixer for 5 minutes before being diluted to 1 liter with distilled water. This mixture was placed in a 1-liter settling jar, mechanically agitated for 1 minute, and then set on a table, after which point hydrometer readings were made at different time intervals (specifically 1, 3.5, 15, 45, 300, and 1,440 minutes). A control hydrometer and temperature reading on an empty jar with nothing but distilled water and the sodium hexametaphosphate solution was made at intervals throughout the analysis to permit calibration of the hydrometer. A small split of the <2-mm soil was also oven-dried to determine the moisture content and correct the sample mass used in the hydrometer analysis (hygroscopic moisture correction). After 24 hours, the contents of the hydrometer jar were wet-sieved through a 37-micron sieve, and the sand retained on the sieve was transferred to a beaker and oven- dried at 105˚C. This sand was subsequently sieved at 0.5-phi intervals once dry. and the mass retained on each sieve recorded. From these data, the percentage of gravel, sand, silt, and clay, as well as various descriptive statistics was calculated for the grain size distribution using a spreadsheet written by Paul Lehman. Calcium Carbonate Equivalent Content A small split (either 1.7 g or 0.85 g) of the ground <2-mm fraction of each soil sample was used to determine the calcium carbonate equivalent (C.C.E.) by means of a Chittick apparatus (Dreimanis 1962; Machette 1986). This sample was finely ground (to pass a 0.075-mm sieve), and then weighed, and placed into a small (250-ml) Erlenmeyer flask. Once attached to the Chittick apparatus, the liquid level in the measuring burette was set to -10 ml, then the stopcock was closed so no gas could leave the system, and the leveling bulb was dropped in order to establish a vacuum inside the sample chamber. At this point, the barometric pressure and temperature in the room were recorded. Then 10 ml of 50 percent hydrochloric acid (approximately 6 N HCl) was delivered to the sample flask, which was agitated intermittently until the reaction had ceased (usually 1–2 minutes). At this point, the leveling bulb was raised to the point that the liquid level inside of it was equal in elevation to the liquid in the burette, and the volume of gas evolved was then measured and the calcium carbonate equivalent calculated. Magnetic Susceptibility The magnetic susceptibility was determined from two sample sets. One set consisted of cubes that were pushed into the site sediments in the field, whereas the other set consisted of dry sediment samples that had been sieved to remove the >2-mm-size material and were packed into 2.5-cm plastic cubes. All of the magnetic susceptibility samples were weighed, and then the low frequency (470 Hz) and high frequency (4700 Hz) magnetic susceptibility (kappa) was measured for the 0.1 setting on a Bartington MS2 meter and an MS2b sensor (Dearing 1999a). The mass corrected magnetic susceptibility (c ) and coefficient of frequency dependency (c ) were then lf fd calculated. The coefficient of frequency dependency (c ), is the percent difference in magnetic fd 105


---

## Page 120

susceptibility measured at low and high frequencies (calculated as: c = (c – c )/c )*100). fd lf hf lf Elevated values of c (approximately >10 percent; Gale and Hoare 1991:213) are indicative of fd increased concentrations of fine-grained ferrimagnetic minerals, most often maghemite, in top soils (Dearing 1999b; Dearing et al. 1996). The magnetic susceptibility values are reported in SI units (10-8m3kg-1) (see Table 20). Organic Carbon and Stable Carbon Isotopic Analysis Two columns of soil samples were submitted for total carbon and stable isotopic analysis. One column, comprising 33 samples that form a continuous column sample through the modern and Late Holocene alluvium exposed by the block excavations were collected from Test Units 36, 46, and 35. A second column of 17 samples was collected from the west wall of Test Unit 52. For the first column, approximately 2 g of dry soil was separated from the dry hygroscopic moisture sample. The samples were then placed in a 400-ml beaker and decalcified using 6N hydrochloric acid. The second column was collected as a 2.5-cm cube that was hammered into the test unit wall. These samples were dried, weighed, and the magnetic susceptibility measured. The soil in each cube was then removed, and an approximate 2-g split was decalcified using 6N hydrochloric acid. For both groups, the acid was added until no additional reaction was observed, and then the samples were rinsed with tap water and left to stand 5 hours, or until the water column was clear. The samples were rinsed in this manner three times, and then after the final decanting, they were placed in a drying oven at 50°C until dry. The samples were then ground to a fine power with a mortar and pestle. In order to determine the carbon content of each sample, the dry, calcium carbonate-free, ground sample was then submitted to the Stable Isotopic Research Unit at the Central Analytical Lab, Department of Crop and Soil Science, at Oregon State University. The carbon content was determined on a Europa Scientific Tracermass Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer. Microartifact Analysis A column of bulk samples collected from a 15-x-15-cm area in 5 cm levels were examined for microartifact content. These samples weighed between 3 and 4 kilograms and were first soaked in a 5-gallon bucket of water with sodium pyrophosphate for more than one month in order to facilitate disaggregation of the clays. The samples were repeatedly, but gently, stirred throughout the soaking period. This slurry was then passed through a 2-mm sieve and all of the >2 mm material caught on the screen was collected, dried, and subsequently identified and tallied by count and weight. Identification of the materials was conducted with a low power binocular microscope (Leica S8 APO). The materials identified in these samples included lithic debitage, burned earth, bone, charcoal, mussel shell, hackberry endocarps, and gravels. Very small snails were also noted within the fine earth matrix, but these were not collected or analyzed. The results of the microartifact analysis is presented on Figure 38. Only one core (Core 13—excavated during the 2007 testing season) penetrated through the alluvial deposits at the site reaching the weathered limestone and shale of the underlying Cretaceous Ozan Formation. Three distinct allostratigraphic units, bounded by two buried soils and the surface soil, were identified at the site (see Figure 4). The lowest of these units was only present in Core 13. The alluvial units were identified based on field observations of sediment color, texture, bedding, clastic and carbonate concentrations, and soil development. These deposits were identified by their apparent age, and youngest to oldest are Recent Alluvium, Late Holocene Alluvium, and Earlier Holocene Alluvium. Radiocarbon dates were obtained from the base of the Recent Alluvium and from the cultural occupation associated with the Late Holocene Alluvium (see Table 19). Unfortunately, samples were not collected from the Earlier Holocene Alluvium, thus an absolute date was not obtained. During the data recovery fieldwork, an attempt was made to obtain a sample from the lower alluvial unit. However, the extremely wet field conditions permitted the coring rig to penetrate to 4 m below the surface and the lowest alluvium was not encountered. The clayey cultural-bearing deposits composing the bulk of the alluvial sediments along the south bank of Muddy Creek can be correlated to the stratigraphy of the upper Trinity River described previously by Ferring (1990b, 1994). Ferring notes that the two most recent deposits within the upper Trinity River basin are the Pilot Point Alloformation and the Recent Alluvium. The interface between these two deposits is typically denoted by the presence of a prominent paleosol called the West Fork Paleosol. Radiocarbon ages reported by Ferring (1994:51) for the Pilot Point Alloformation range from 4,150 to 530 yr B.P. Ferring (1994) does not report radiocarbon ages for the Recent Alluvium, but it is clear that this deposit accounts for alluvial deposition in the period following the deposition of the Pilot Point Alloformation, which appears to represent the last 500 years. The site excavations targeted prehistoric occupations within the West Fork Paleosol near the upper boundary of the Pilot Point Alluvium. The upper boundary of the Pilot Point Alluvium is marked by a pause in sedimentation and the formation of a prominent, cumulic soil that developed between 2,000 and 500 yr B.P (Ferring 1990b:53). The West Fork soil serves as an important Late Holocene stratigraphic marker throughout much of the upper Trinity valley. At site 41COL172, sedimentation was punctuated near the end of the deposition of the Pilot Point Alluvium so that the West Fork soil has formed a pedocomplex of two partially welded buried soils at the site (see Figure 14). The occasional distinction of the West Fork soil as a sequence of multiple stacked soils, or pedocomplex, is a result of the cumulic nature of the profile, where local micro- and macrorelief causes slight changes in the depositional environment and differential sedimentation as sedimentation and soil development are concurrent (Birkeland 1999:166; Holliday 2004:79). A column of bulk sediment samples was collected from the Recent Alluvium and the Pilot Point Alloformation along the northern margin of the site in Test Units 36, 46, and 35. These samples were used to characterize the site deposits (see Table 20 and Figure 37). A second column of samples was collected from the upper part of the Pilot Point Alloformation from the west wall of Test Unit 52. The samples from the second profile were examined for magnetic susceptibility, calcium carbonate content, organic carbon, and stable carbon isotopic composition (Table 21 and Figure 39). 108

## Page 124

Alluvial Deposition Recent Alluvium The Recent Alluvium at the site ranges from about 1.0 to 1.7 m thick. Results from test excavations and observations made while the data recovery block was being excavated showed that the Recent Alluvium thickens toward the paleochannel south of the site. However, this southward thickening of the deposit is not uniform across the site. Coring performed during data recovery excavations at the east end of the site suggest the opposite trend, with Recent Alluvium being about 1.4 m thick in Core 1 immediately adjacent to the channel and 1.2 m thick in Core 2, located approximately 25 m south of the modern channel (Figure 40). This implies a subtle thinning of the Recent Alluvium to the south of the site. Although not concretely confirmed, the geoarchaeological work conducted during the testing seasons suspected that the paleochannel migrates northward to form the eastern boundary of the site (Pleasant and Naumann 2007). If this is the case, Cores 1 and 2, collected during the data recovery season, were indeed located to the east of the paleochannel. Regardless of the macrogeometry of the deposit, the analytical work from this deposit indicates that the Recent Alluvium exhibits a subtle fining upward trend; but it is silty clay to silty clay loam throughout. The soil formed in the Recent Alluvium exhibits an A- AC-C profile in most exposures. The calcium carbonate increases dramatically downward throughout this deposit, but it is unlikely that this is attributable to leaching/weathering, given that the exposure time for the surface soil is significantly less than for the underlying West Fork Paleosol, which shows a less marked increase in carbonate with depth (rather, a less pronounced decrease within the A horizon). The magnetic susceptibility (Xlf) shows a gradual increase upward through the unit, which is consistent with pedogenic alteration of the upper part of the deposit. Similarly, the coefficient of frequency dependence (Xfd), which is generally thought to increase with pedogenic alteration, supports this interpretation, as these values also increase upward through the unit. Pilot Point Alloformation The deposits of the Pilot Point Alloformation at the site have been found to be at least 3.5 m thick. The deposit is capped by the West Fork Paleosol over the entire southern floodplain of Muddy Creek. Furthermore, the deposits exhibit an increasing complexity to the south, toward the presumed paleochannel. In places, the West Fork soil is separated by punctuated sedimentation, and it generally thickens to the south (see Figure 14; also see Figure 39, which is sampled across one of these features). This general relationship suggests that during the period of Pilot Point deposition the active channel of Muddy Creek most likely lay to the south of the site. Like the Recent Alluvium, a subtle fining upward trend is present within the Pilot Point Alloformation, but this is only partially captured by the textural analysis results (see Figure 37). Core 3, which was placed upon the floor of the Test Unit 34, extended about 2 m below the floor of the test unit and revealed alternating muds and slightly gravelly muds. These alternating clayey deposits probably reflect the bed load deposits of Muddy Creek. These deposits also exhibited increasing evidence of periodic saturation with increasing depth (Figure 41) in the form of gleyed matrix colors, mottles, and iron manganese concentrations. Still, Core 3 did not appear to reach the bottom of the Pilot Point Alloformation. 110

In each of the two profiles of the West Fork Paleosol examined, the magnetic susceptibility curves exhibit one prominent peak upon a broader enhanced zone. Sedimentation Rates A suite of five radiocarbon samples was assayed from materials recovered from Block 1 excavations from the data recovery season. The samples consisted of a mix of wood charcoal from feature fill, bison, and deer bone. Table 23 displays the results of the materials analyzed, including the rationale for performing the analysis. The total 2σ range of dates from contexts within the West Fork paleosol are between 960 and 470 calibrated (cal) 14C yr B.P. It is clear from the results that the West Fork paleosol present at site 41COL172 is at the later range typical of the West Fork seen at other sites in the upper Trinity valley (see Ferring 1994). One slightly later date of 480–290 cal 14C yr B.P. was obtained from deer bone resting on top of the paleosol (Beta 279341). Since the faunal materials were resting immediately above the paleosol, this date serves as the basal range for the deposition of the Recent Alluvium. Although the 2σ range of partially overlaps with the latter dates from within the West Fork, it surficially appears that there was likely a 150–200-year gap in sedimentation before the burial of the West Fork Paleosol. The calibrated intercepts of the radiocarbon curve are plotted on Figure 42. In the case of Beta 279344, the date obtained intercepted the curve at three places. These data were used to calculate the sedimentation rate of the upper portion of the Pilot Point Alloformation. In general, the data shows a curve that is typical of floodplains formed by vertical accretion. In these systems, sedimentation rates tend to decrease gradually as the floodplain surface gradually rises above the height of typical flood levels. As time progresses, more and more energy is required for a stream to overtop its banks and deposit additional sediment on the floodplain. At the bottom of the data recovery excavations between 35 and 80 cm (below the top of the paleosol), the sedimentation rates are approximately 19.5 cm per century. The rates decrease slightly with time between 18 and 35 cm to 17.6 cm per century. Then, within the cumulic A horizon of the West Fork, sedimentation rates drop to 5.8 cm per century between 13 and 18 cm before slightly increasing to 6.5 cm per century at the uppermost portion of the paleosol. This final sedimentation rate is slightly skewed since the uppermost date was obtained from within the Recent Alluvium above the Pilot Point Alloformation. Still, the general trend indicates that the sedimentation rates slowed by roughly one-third in the upper portion of the profile compared to the deeper portion of the excavation profile. Both the relative and absolute rates of sedimentation are consistent with other studies in the region (e.g., Frederick 2009; Hall 1990) and seem to represent a regional climatic shift favoring cumulic soil formation. The deposition of the Recent Alluvium, by contrast, occurred at a greatly accelerated rate. Using the bone date from the bottom of the Recent Alluvium and extrapolating to the modern surface, it appears that sedimentation rates for this deposit occurred at a rate of 43 cm per century or faster. This sedimentation rate assumes that the modern surface was aggrading until 0 14C yr B.P.—or 1950—the approximate period at which the dam was placed. Some amount of time was required to develop the surface soil, though it is immature compared to the West Fork. Hence, the 43-cm-per-century estimation is likely a minimum rate and the Recent Alluvium was deposited much faster. Given the slowing of sedimentation in the upper portion of paleosol, it is not surprising that the bulk of cultural materials was encountered within the upper portion of the paleosol. Slower sedimentation rates would have allowed for a greater period of time for a surface to be occupied (Ferring 1986; Hoyer 1980:61; Mandel and Bettis 2001:182–183). Since multiple occupations have been identified within the profile at site 41COL172, it seems doubtful that the increase in cultural materials in the upper portion of the paleosol is indicative of an increased intensity of occupation. Instead, repeated short duration uses of the location would, through time, result in a 114

To date, there have been only three carbon isotopic studies from localities in Northcentral Texas (Brown 1998; Frederick 2009; Humphrey and Ferring 1994). However, numerous similar studies have been published from adjacent regions in Central Texas (Nordt et al. 1994), Southcentral Texas (Nordt et al. 2002), and West Texas (Quigg et al. 2008) covering the Late Holocene and period of 117

These data, along with other published studies throughout the Great Plains region, have led to a regional synthesis of C plant productivity for the entire Late 4 Quaternary period (Nordt et al. 2008). Although the recent study by Nordt et al. (2008) focuses on the short- and mixed-grasslands regions, the carbon isotopic stages and substages identified for the region correlate temporally with the climatic shifts identified in the studies in Northcentral Texas. The recorded shifts in floral communities caused by changes in climatic conditions have been cited as having a dramatic affect on bison populations in Central and Northcentral Texas (Dillehay 1974). These changes in turn would have affected human populations in the region (Lynott 1981). The carbon isotopic work at site 41COL172 was conducted to address two main themes. First and foremost, the study focuses on reconstructing the local environment relevant to the lives of the prehistoric inhabitants of the region. Second, changes in climate affect sedimentation and erosion rates and thus the burial and preservation of archaeological sites. In Ferring’s (1990b) review of the alluvial chronology of upper Trinity valley, he states that the Pilot Point alluviation and the formation of the West Fork soil could be the result of either climatic forces or lower sediment yields due to graded stream valleys (Hall 1988). At the Aubrey site, isotopes from pedogenic carbonate indicated that the period between 2,000 and 1,000 yr B.P. was warmer and drier than previous conditions (Humphrey and Ferring 1994). Other studies contrast the results at Aubrey in that the period between 2,000 and 1,000 yr B.P. is characterized by cooler and wetter conditions than in preceding periods. Oxygen and carbon isotopic studies from mussel shell in northwest Dallas County show this period as cool and wet (Brown 1998). In Hall’s (1988, 1990) interpretation, the cumulic soil development in Southcentral Oklahoma and Northcentral Texas is the result of higher effective precipitation during the period and near-present-day warm and dry conditions establishing at 1,000 yr B.P. However, specific correlation between the regional Southern Plains paleosols have been shown to be the result of nonsynchronous valley-specific events (Ferring 1992; Hall 1990; Mandel 1992), and climate change as the only driver in alluviation is thus inadequate. Additional study is needed to understand the mechanisms driving Late Holocene soil development. The results of the stable carbon isotopic ratio analysis from site 41COL172 shows an essentially modern signature throughout most of the profile (Figure 43). Throughout the profile, the contribution from C sources centers around 50 percent. However, there does appear to be a 4 general trend toward more C vegetation within the Pilot Point Alluvium (pre 300 yr B.P.). 3 Several significant oscillations can be seen within both profiles from the site that generally range between 1–2 δ13C per mil PDB. Interestingly, shifts of a similar magnitude can be seen when comparing the two profiles collected at the site. To some degree, the absolute values of the data appear to be dependent on the intensity of human occupation where the profile was collected. The magnitude of these oscillations is similar in range with oscillations seen within data from 41TR198; however, the timing of the events differs significantly between the two sites. The sedimentation rates within this portion of the profile at 41TR198 were much slower than at 41COL172. Since much more time is represented in each shift in the data from 41TR198, it is likely that seasonal variations of C /C inputs would be less averaged and appear at a higher 4 3 frequency in the data from 41COL172. Both of these datasets appear to contrast the C - 3 dominated signature from 41COL203. Frederick (2009) noted that the trend from 41DL203 within this period is anomalous from the area and attributed the trend to reflect a highly local signature. These differences are interesting because the stratigraphy and soil development between these three sites is so similar, even if the exact timing of human occupation differs between the sites. 118

CHAPTER 8 LITHIC AND BAKED CLAY ANALYSES by Arlo McKee INTRODUCTION Upon the completion of the data recovery excavations, the collection from site 41COL172 consisted of 21,500 artifacts consisting of lithic debitage and tools, FCR, ceramics, animal bone, and shell. A small portion of the total collection (n=542) was analyzed in 2006 after the completion of the first season of NRHP eligibility testing. The material analysis presented in this chapter was performed by Geo-Marine in the Plano, Texas, laboratory. The materials analyzed by Geo-Marine consisted of the lithics, FCR, and burned earth collections. Specialized analyses of faunal and ceramic materials are presented in Chapter 9 and Chapter 10, respectively. LITHICS The lithic assemblage from site 41COL172 is composed of a total of 856 specimens (Table 24). The entire collection from all field seasons was analyzed by Geo-Marine staff in conjunction with the data recovery project. The goal of the analysis was to address numerous broad questions based on field observations and broader site context. The field observations and preliminary counts of the assemblage noted an apparent lack of completed tools and a relatively limited range of material types. The questions were formulated and grouped into three broad themes: (1) stage of reduction, (2) resource availability and intensity of pretreatment, and (3) behavior and regional interaction. Some of the specific questions to be addressed were: 1) Stage of Reduction a. To what degree is point production or maintenance/reworking represented at the site? b. Do the reduction stages vary with given material types? c. Can different processes be identified at different contexts at the site? 2) Resource availability and pretreatment a. Are the materials disproportionately local or nonlocal compared to similarly aged sites in the area? b. What is the degree of heat-treatment or resource improvement at the site? 121

Methodology and Attributes Material Types Identification of raw material categories in the lithic assemblage is especially important for identifying the degree of interaction the inhabitants of site 41COL172 had with adjacent regions. The upper Trinity valley has been identified as a ―chert-poor‖ region when compared with Central Texas (e.g., Ferring and Yates 1997; Tomka 2009). In the region, the composition of the Uvalde Gravels characterizes the locally available materials; and consequently, a given lithic assemblage is often represented by upwards of 90 percent quartzite (Prikryl 1990). Even with limited chert resources, variations in the abundance of chert artifacts relative to the more commonly available quartzite materials have been noted in many of the large-scale studies in the region (e.g., Ferring and Yates 1997; McGregor and Bruseth 1987; Peter and McGregor 1988; Prikryl 1990). Given that chert resources are poor in the area, relative abundance of this material is linked to either the relative mobility of a group or to the degree of interaction with groups in adjacent regions. The raw materials from the assemblage were classified into two main types: quartzite and chert. Quartzite is formed from a metamorphosed sandstone and occurs in the collection from fine- to coarse-grained. Quartzite is most commonly a reddish color in the collection, though it also 122


---

## Page 136

ranges from yellow to gray. When the materials are unaltered from firing, the materials are often dull; however, cleavage planes of larger quartz minerals can often give the quartzite a speckled lustrous appearance. A recent study by Tomka (2009) attempted to reproduce the lustrous characteristics in local quartzites by heating several flake removed from an unaltered nodule in a Tehermolyne furnace at known temperatures and durations. The study failed to reproduce the lustrous appearance thought to be caused by prehistoric firing techniques; however, Tomka ultimately concluded that heat-treatment can still be identified in collections in the area with some care (Tomka 2009:168). Of the cryptocrystalline materials in the collection, chert and silicified wood are the most common. The colors of the chert ranged from tan to grays, while silicified wood was typically dark brown to red and banded. These materials were typically opaque to slightly translucent. No microfossils or oolites were noted in any of the chert materials. This was somewhat surprising since Pisgah Ridge chert contains microfossils and is the closest major chert source to the site. Although the local gravels contain minor amounts of chert, determination of whether or not the chert in the collection was from nonlocal sources would ultimately have benefited from ultraviolet light analysis. However, this was not done with the collection; all samples were only inspected under natural light, and sometimes with a 10x hand lens. Minor materials represented in the collection consisted of novaculite and chalcedony. Each of these was represented in the collection by only one or two specimens. Novaculite is a cryptocrystalline opaque material that is often white, yellow, blue, or other colors. Novaculite is a common material in the Ouachita Mountains, and its presence at the site can be interpreted as an interaction with groups outside of the region. Chalcedony is a glossy cryptocrystalline material that is typically translucent and ranges in color from milk white to yellowish white. Unmodified Lithic Debitage A mass analysis strategy was employed for the unmodified lithic debitage collection. For the analysis, materials from a single provenience were first divided into type categories (flake and shatter). Flakes were defined as any fragment in which a dorsal and ventral surface could be identified, and shatter was defined as angular fragments that were the byproduct of early stages of reduction and not evidence of heating. The artifacts were then separated by raw materials category (e.g., quartzite, chert, silicified wood). The artifacts within each category were then passed through a nested set of USDA sieves with mesh sizes of 1, 0.75, 0.5, and 0.25 inches. Within each size class, the debitage was further subdivided by the presence of cortex on the dorsal surface. The specific cortical categories were primary flakes (100 percent cortex), secondary flakes (1–99 percent cortex), and tertiary (0 percent cortex). The materials were then subdivided into heated and not-heated subgroups. Tools and Cores An analysis of all formal tools and cores was conducted concurrently with the debitage analysis. The material types and other descriptive categories recorded for the debitage analysis were also conducted on all formal tools and cores. All bifacially flaked artifacts that have shoulders and/or barbs and a stem were classified as projectile points. The projectile points were then classified according to type following Turner and Hester (1999) and Suhm and Jelks (1962). The remaining 123


---

## Page 137

bifacially flaked artifacts that were highly fragmentary and/or did not have shoulders, barbs, or stems were simply classified as bifaces and a description of the artifact was recorded. Unifacial tools were classified according to the degree of retouch identified on the artifact. If the retouch was irregular and significant changes in the morphology of the parent flake were not noted, the artifact was classified as an edge-modified flake and not a formal tool. For instance, if only one or two small flakes were removed from an edge of a larger piece of debitage, the artifact was classified as an edge-modified flake. These artifacts were interpreted as expedient tools versus the more formal technologies represented by the biface and projectile point artifacts. Finally, other flaked artifacts, in which multiple edges were worked, were classified as formal edge-modified tools such as a scraper or drill. Results of the Lithic Analysis Chipped Stone Unmodified Lithic Debitage The unmodified lithic debitage identified from the collections at site 41COL172 were of six material types: quartzite, undifferentiated chert, silicified wood, chalcedony, novaculite, and coarse limestone. The focus of the study was to identify whether significantly different tool production activities occurred at both different parts of the site and during different periods of time. Three broad occupational periods were identified, though these likely represent a blend of many numerous discrete occupations (see Chapter 6). These occupational periods—termed phases—were identified as Upper Late Prehistoric (Phase 1), Lower Late Prehistoric (Phase 2), and Lowest Late Prehistoric (Phase 3). As discussed previously, the Lowest Late Prehistoric Phase was tentatively identified based on a very low density of materials identified deep within test units. The presence of krotovina and slickensides within the Phase 3 levels suggests that these materials may have translocated from upper horizons. Of the 818 unmodified debitage fragments recovered, the majority (n=790; 96.5 percent) could be attributed to one of the three occupational periods. The remaining fragments (n=28) were recovered either from proveniences that crosscut occupational boundaries or were recovered from proveniences without associated depths. From the lowest occupation, only 24 fragments were recovered. Because the sample size from the lowest horizon was so small, the data were not used for the statistical analyses presented in this section. The total population of statistically analyzed unmodified debitage from the discrete cultural phases at 41COL172 therefore was represented by 766 specimens. Figure 44 shows the distribution of debitage found within test units according to the relevant occupation zone. Since the unit sizes varied, the data were normalized to the test unit area to identify the actual density of debitage recovered. The maximum density of debitage recovered from a single test unit was 84 fragments (n) per m2. The distributions show that, in general, the highest density of debitage was recovered from units in the southern portion of the mitigation excavation block and from Test Block 1 (see Figure 44a). Two outlier units (TU 9 and 36) also produced a high density of debitage at the northern end of the site. Not displayed in Figure 44 is the distribution of flakes recovered from the Lowest Late Prehistoric phase. Only 28 flakes were recovered from this phase; and these appear to remain an opportunistic sample because most test units were not excavated through the Phase 3 levels at the site. 124

Two features were identified within the Upper Late Prehistoric phase (Feature 2 and F 09-01). The density of debitage recovered in association with this phase appears to be most associated with F 09-01 (see Figure 44c). Although the feature itself contained a relatively low number of flakes (n=6), higher densities were observed in test units 1–2 m away from the feature. In contrast, the debitage recovered from units associated with Feature 2 was relatively low in density in all directions. The debitage recovered from the Lower Late Prehistoric phase similarly shows a low density of debitage adjacent to F 09-03 (see Figure 44d). Although a scatter of two–four flakes per meter is present in nearly all units surrounding the feature, the majority of debitage was recovered from within the feature itself (n=46). These differences in spatial patterns could indicate changes in immediate environmental factors—such as wind direction or temperature—in which the knappers were adapting or it could indicate differences in functions of the features themselves. The unmodified lithic debitage was cross-tabulated to compare material type with the identified occupational horizons or phases (Table 25). The material types represented were quartzite, undifferentiated chert, silicified wood, chalcedony, novaculite, and coarse limestone. In order to limit the number of unpopulated fields, chalcedony, novaculite, and coarse limestone were combined to one category. This category was treated an unusual or rare materials category. An Χ2 test was performed on the matrix, which indicated that this grouping did not confidently represent statistically independent populations at the p=0.05 level. When these samples were further subdivided by field season, an Χ2 test on the materials collected during the data recovery season (n=435) appeared to represent independent populations (p=0.03), while the test season data (n=331) was not confidently independent at the 95 percent confidence level (p=0.22). This suggested that the field methods of 10-cm arbitrary levels were insufficient to clearly differentiate occupational horizons. Thus, the initial field methods had the unfortunate effect of mixing the occupational horizons. Some broad conclusions can still be drawn from the lithic materials collected from the site as a whole. First, quartzite appears to be the most abundant material found in each of the separable cultural occupations. Uvalde gravels are commonly found in the area, and it is not surprising that the collection consists primarily of these materials. At nearby site 41DL203, a similar reliance on local materials was noted throughout both the Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric components (Tomka 2009). At 41DL203, Uvalde gravels were represented in the assemblage at a ratio of 7:1 compared with chert and silicified wood during the Late Prehistoric phase. This ratio peaked to 70:1 within the Transitional period between the Late Prehistoric and Late Archaic. At 41COL172, quartzite was represented at an average of 8:1 over other materials in both periods. The variation in this reliance was not as pronounced at 41COL172 as it was at 41DL203 and ranged from 7:1 in the Upper Late Prehistoric to 15:1 in the Lower Late Prehistoric. Table 26 compares the frequency of materials found at site 41COL172 with the frequency of materials found within the Late Prehistoric phase at 41DL203 (from Tomka 2009:186:Table 27). The adjusted residuals indicated that silicified wood is statistically overrepresented at 41COL172 and underrepresented in the Late Prehistoric component at 41DL203. The opposite is true for chert resources. At 41COL172, chert is significantly underrepresented and is overrepresented at 41DL203. Since the chert identified in both collections is attributed to nonlocal materials, the greater abundance of chert in the collection at 41DL203 could indicate a greater total investment by Late Prehistoric craftspeople in raw materials. Likewise, the overrepresentation of silicified wood in the 41COL172 collection likely represents simply a greater availability of silicified wood within the Muddy Creek drainage. The residual analysis indicated that that the smallest size class is underrepresented in the Upper Late Prehistoric phase (-1.39) and overrepresented in the Lower Late Prehistoric phase, but these data are not significant at the p=0.05 level. Still, there is weak evidence of a greater degree of reduction or increased tool maintenance during the lower component compared with the upper component. To further explore this inference, the fractal distributions were analyzed for quartzite and chert materials following Brown (2001). This method attempts to quantify the degree of lithic reduction by observing that most reduction strategies proceed from producing coarse to small flakes. It is assumed that ―earlier stages of reduction produce proportionately more large flakes while later stages generate an increasing proportion of smaller flakes‖ (Brown 2001:624). The quantification of the stage of reduction is the fractal dimension (D), which is the absolute value of the slope of a best-fit line on a log-log plot of cumulative size versus frequency. In general, D is assumed to increase with later stages of lithic reduction. Figures 45 and 46 display the results of the fractal plots for the quartzite and chert materials, respectively. Since the analysis depends on accurately predicting the best-fit line in the data, null data values seriously hinder the results. Consequently, categories with only a limited number of fragments represented were omitted in the comparison. Phase 2 chert is not shown on Figure 46 because such a low number of artifacts were recovered (n=6). From the plots, it is apparent that chert materials have slightly greater D values than quartzite. This is to be expected since tested quartzite cobbles were identified in the collection, whereas relatively raw chert nodules were not identified. Although there is considerable overlap in Brown’s (2001:623) comparison data, the D values for both the quartzite populations (1.22–1.43) are all firmly within the mean range for an early reduction stage (Figure 47). The quartzite recovered from the Upper Late Prehistoric component (Phase 1) had a D value of 1.22, whereas the Lower Late Prehistoric component (Phase 2) was 1.44. This is the opposite of the weak trend in the adjusted residuals, and there are two possible reasons for this occurrence. First, this could indicate that less intensive lithic reduction was occurring in Phase 2 than in Phase 1 and that the weak evidence from the residual analysis should be negated. Second, this result could simply reflect an inadequate sample size for comparison. Brown (2001:624) does note that ―three or four size intervals seriously weakens‖ the fractal results of many other similar studies. Whichever the case, it appears that quartzite was, overall, slightly less intensively worked than chert materials. Formal Tools and Cores The stone tool collection consisted of a total of 27 tools and 10 cores. Overall, the formal tools were not very well represented in the collection, representing only 2.7 percent of the total within the stone artifact class. Given that approximately 37 m3 of sediment was excavated at the site, this yielded just over one stone tool per cubic meter. Of the chipped stone tools, projectile points, were the most common, followed by miscellaneous bifacial tools and expedient edge-modified flakes. Unifacial tools also represented a small portion of the chipped stone assemblage. Ten cores or tested cobbles were also identified. Table 30 shows that the vast majority of the chipped stone tools were recovered from the Upper Late Prehistoric phase (Phase 1) at the site. All of the diagnostic projectile points were recovered from within Phase 1, which limits the usefulness of the dataset for marking changes in point morphology through time. Similar to the debitage results, the most abundant material for tools in each phase was quartzite (Table 31). Chert tools and cores do appear to be overrepresented within Phase 1 (n=9), which appears to also mirror the increased abundance of chert debitage within the upper occupational zone. This trend of increasing use of presumed nonlocal materials for projectile points throughout the Late Prehistoric period has been commonly cited throughout Northcentral Texas (Ferring and Yates 1997, 1998; Prikryl 1990). 131

49. Rock material types represented in the FCR collection from site 41COL172 Figure 49. Rock material types represented in the FCR collection from site 41COL172. Fire-cracked rock is a common class of archaeological materials throughout North America (Thoms 2009) and is of particular interest in Central Texas, where FCR concentrations— variously dubbed burned rock middens, thermal features, and rock ovens, among other terms— ―have long received a large share of archaeologists’ attention‖ due to their ubiquity (Collins 2004:109). Despite this attention, little progress linking FCR patterns to particular activities or behavior patterns was made until the 1990s, when a flurry of studies, ably reviewed in Collins’s recent synthesis of Central Texas archaeology, resulted in ―the single most fundamental conceptual advance in burned rock midden research . . . [the] recognition that burned rock middens likely formed in several different ways‖ (Collins 2004:109). Although FCR is present on a far smaller scale in Northcentral Texas (for a rare exception, see Lintz et al. 2008), it is nonetheless an important material class with the potential to illuminate changes in behavior patterns, particularly at a stratified site where a particular locality may be used for different purposes or in a different way during different periods. Since Collins’s synthesis, recent studies have produced data and models with implications beyond Central Texas, some focusing on FCR fragment morphology (e.g., Backhouse and Johnson 2007) and others on FCR size distributions as an indicator of repeated reheating (e.g., Pagoulatos 2005; Thompson and Mauldin 2008). Thompson and Mauldin’s (2008) work is particularly useful, with experimentally derived models of size distributions tested against archaeological assemblages from 41KM69, a Central Texas site with several dozen FCR features dating from the middle of the Late Archaic period (ca. 2,500 yr B.P.) to the end of the Late Prehistoric period (after 500 yr B.P.). In sum, Thompson and Mauldin find generally consistent patterns of moderate to low FCR reuse, indicated by FCR collections with fewer small fragments and more mid-sized larger fragments, throughout the Late Archaic and the initial portion of the Late Prehistoric period (Figure 50a). Then, they document FCR collections at the end of the Late Prehistoric period dominated by smaller fragments, a trend interpreted as indicating greater fragmentation and therefore a higher degree of FCR reuse (see Figure 50b). 137

Simulated size curves indicating (a) low reuse activity, and (b) high reuse activity (after Thompson and Mauldin 2008). The X axis letters refer to ascending size classes discussed above. Thompson and Mauldin (2008) associate this change with the adoption of a subsistence regime focusing on intense processing of low-return plant foods, probably chosen due to increasing populations and decreasing game availability. These points are expanded to a continental scale by Thoms (2009), who proposes a similar trend in an ambitious FCR use model based on ethnographic, archaeological, and experimental data from across North America and representing the entire Holocene. It must be stated, however, that at the same time Thoms’s model predicts more FCR due to greater plant-food processing, it does allow for a decrease corresponding to the use of ceramics, which would obviate the need for stone boiling, a key FCR-producing activity in some regions (Thoms 2009). At site 41COL172, no in situ FCR features were encountered during the data testing and recovery seasons (see Chapters 5 and 6). However, FCR was recovered in significant quantities within and surrounding Feature 09-03, but none was in a recognizable arrangement at the level of abundance corresponding to an in situ thermal event. Generally, it appears that the variable densities of FCR at the site were likely the product of alluvial and pedogenic processes that most likely disassembled the primary activity areas. During the three seasons of excavations, 569 pieces of FCR were recovered, for a total of 21 kilograms (kg). The data recovery excavation strategy of 5-cm natural levels permitted a clear recognition of multiple (at least two) occupation zones that can be clearly recognized by the quantity of FCR present in the collection (Figure 51). During the Upper Late Prehistoric zone (Phase 1: 0–25 cm) there is a subtle peak in FCR between 10 and 15 cm below the top of the paleosol. The abundance of FCR in the Upper Late Prehistoric zone is much lower than within the Lower Late Prehistoric zone (Phase 2: 25–50 cm). The greatest concentration of FCR within the Lower Late Prehistoric zone occurs between 30 and 35 cm below the top of the paleosol. Approximately half of the FCR responsible for the dramatic peak in this zone was recovered in association with Feature 09-03. To test the site’s FCR assemblage against the simulated curves produced by Thompson and Mauldin (2008), the collected FCR was first plotted as a series of relative frequency diagrams with columns representing the percentage contribution of each size class for the entire collection (Figure 52). The distributions are skewed toward the larger size classes, suggesting a closer match to Thompson and Mauldin’s (2008) low-reuse curve than to the high-reuse one (see Figure 50a-b). 138

Both of the upper two components appear to be heavily skewed toward the low-reuse size classes, whereas the few materials recovered in Phase 3 are slightly skewed more toward the smaller size classes. It is unclear whether this size distribution in the lowest component at the site indicates behavioral or natural processes. It seems equally likely that these materials could indicate an intensification of FCR reuse or they could simply represent materials that were translocated downward from upper levels through pedoturbation. 139

BAKED CLAY Masses of baked clay, also described as burned clay, burned earth, or (with a layer of interpretation) daub, are common at prehistoric sites in Northcentral Texas and surrounding regions. When large concentrations of baked clay are found at a site, the materials are often interpreted as indications of fallen structures, especially in cases where many fragments are fiber- impressed, suggesting a measure of temper has been added to the matrix (e.g., Boyd 2004b; Drass 2008). In these cases, analyses of fiber-impressions can be a useful proxy for reconstructing the local paleoenvironment (Peacock and Reese 2003). However, not all burned clay remains found in archaeological contexts are products of building materials. Many fragments of burned clay are also indicative of the byproducts of cooking techniques, such as boiling stones (Ford and Webb 1956), or are found as fused deposits enclosing hearths (Osburn and Ward 2007). Additionally, burned clay materials may be spread across a living surface, either deliberately or unintentionally trampled onto a surface, as clumps collected on plant roots (Goldberg 2008). Finally, burned clay can be found as a product of natural forest fires, with no direct relation to human activity at all. A basic analysis of these masses was performed in the Geo-Marine laboratory, where they were separated into three types: masses without vegetation impressions, masses with vegetation impressions, and insect burrows. These categories were then subdivided into the following size classes: smaller than 0.5 in (<12.7 mm); 0.5–1 in (12.7–25.4 mm); and 1–1.5 in (25.4–38.1 mm). No fragments were recovered greater than 1.5 in (38.1 mm), so larger size classes were not included in the analysis. Masses of baked clay, both fiber-impressed and not, and baked insect nests compose a relatively minor amount of the assemblage at 41COL172. The entire collection consists of 1,726 fragments of baked clay, of which 11 are insect nests. Table 32 shows that although the total number, at first, appears impressive, the entire collection consists of 710 g, and most of these fragments (approximately 89 percent) are smaller than 0.5 in (<12.7 mm). Most of the masses were irregularly shaped, rounded, gravel-sized, and contained faint evidence of oxidation, reduction, or smudging due to fire. Munsell colors ranged from yellow (10YR 7/6) to yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) to strong brown (7.5YR 4/6). The masses were widely distributed throughout the profile, though the majority of masses (72 percent) were contained within the upper 25 cm of the top of the paleosol (Figure 54). Unlike the distribution of FCR, relatively minimal amounts of burned clay were recovered in the Lower Late Prehistoric levels (25–50 cm below the paleosol surface). Constituting 10.5 percent by weight (3.2 percent by count) of the collection are the vegetation- impressed baked clay masses and insect nests. As previously noted, these materials are proxies for the presence of structures (Boyd 2004b). Similar to the overall trend of baked clay with depth, these two material classes were found to be concentrated in the upper portion of the buried soil (Figure 55). However, given that the proportions of these materials do not increase greatly, relative to unimpressed masses, it seems doubtful to use these data as an indication of permanent structures at the site. Instead, these materials likely represent trampled masses that are the byproduct of hearth materials being scattered across the site. 141

Two subtle peaks were observed in both the lithic debitage and FCR distributions, and one broad peak was observed in the baked clay distribution. These distributions largely supported the field observations that the data could, with some careful consideration, be grouped into two to three occupational zones (though it is quite likely that the site was occupied more than simply two to three discrete times). The upper occupation (Phase 1) is represented by an abundance in lithic debitage and baked clay. The majority of the diagnostic lithic tools were recovered from within Phase 1. The debitage analysis overall indicated that the manufacture of tool types at the site was likely restricted to early stage biface production. However, these interpretations are somewhat hampered by the low total number of specimens collected and the lack of statistically significant data. Concerning resource availability, the lithic collection was dominated by locally available quartzite materials. Approximately 10 percent of the collection was composed of chert and silicified wood materials, which have been cited as approximately correlating with the abundance of these materials within the local Uvalde gravels (Prikryl 1990). An attempt was also made to quantify the amount of pretreatment by firing of the lithic materials. This analysis led to the tentative interpretation that heat-treatment was more commonly employed during Phase 1 than during the preceding occupations. CHAPTER 9 FAUNAL AND FLORAL ANALYSES by Ben Fullerton, Charles Randklev, and Dr. J. Phil Dering INTRODUCTION The faunal and molluscan collection from site 41COL172 constitutes the greatest proportion of samples collected. A total of 6,144 fragments of animal bone weighing 5,780 g was collected and analyzed. In addition to the animal bone, thousands of very small fragments (<6.4 mm) of mussel shell were observed at the site. The mussel shell fragments greater than 6.4 mm (n=7,869) were analyzed and classified taxonomically when possible. The high degree of faunal and shell preservation at the site suggested that botanical remains may be preserved as well. A subset of flotation samples from the site were processed and analyzed for macrobotanical remains. Although the floral preservation was not as high as initially expected, the data presented in this chapter still provided useful information concerning the local environment. PART I: FAUNAL ANALYSIS by Ben Fullerton The faunal remains from 41COL172 are well preserved compared to the majority of archaeofaunas from North Texas. Typically, sites within this region are either deeply buried and difficult to locate or are shallowly expressed and highly exposed. Though the former tend to produce well-preserved faunal remains, the more common latter scenario in North Texas is not conducive to preservation of animal remains. The high level of preservation in the case of 41COL172 resulted from rapid alluvial deposition and burial of a well-developed paleosurface following human occupations at 41COL172. Importantly, numerous specimens exhibit evidence (primarily green fracturing and butchery marks with minimal evidence of nonhuman attrition) suggesting that humans accumulated and deposited the vast majority of the animal remains at the site. Overall, the remains are highly fragmented and remarkably uniform due to consistent extraction of within-bone nutrients (primarily marrow). Although intensive fragmentation has likely hindered the recognition of some aspects of subsistence practices at 41COL172, information concerning resource exploitation, butchery, and transport patterns could still be obtained from the current faunal collection. 145

## Page 159

Based on the natural stratigraphy encountered at 41COL172, the faunal assemblage was subdivided into four temporal phases: Phase 0 is represented by specimens recovered from Recent Alluvium situated stratigraphically above the paleosol. Phase 1 represents specimens recovered from the upper portions of the paleosol, Phase 2 represents specimens recovered from the lower portions of the paleosol, and Phase 3 encompasses materials recovered from sediments situated directly below the paleosol. Measures of differential survivorship (i.e., taphonomy) were carried out on the assemblage as a whole and its temporal subdivisions in order to assess human versus natural modification to bone specimens. However, due to the small sample sizes recovered from Phase 0 (n=84) and Phase 3 (n=165), investigations of subsistence change through time were focused primarily on Phases 1 and 2, which comprise the majority of the collection. The basic identification procedure for vertebrate remains is discussed below, followed by a summary of the taxonomic composition of the faunal assemblage. Special attention is given to deer remains, as deer were clearly the most economically important resource exploited by humans at 41COL172. In particular, the deer assemblage is used to better understand carcass transport and processing strategies as well as to briefly discuss evidence related to deer body size and the age range of deer hunted at 41COL172. A discussion of taphonomy of the fauna then follows. Identification Terminology Faunal remains from 41COL172 were identified through comparison to modern vertebrate specimens housed at the University of North Texas, Center for Environmental Archaeology. Specimens are assigned to class, order, suborder, family, genus, and species based on their level of identifiability following mammalian taxonomy in Schmidly (1994), avian taxonomy in Gilbert et al. (1985), and reptile taxonomy in Garret and Barker (1987). Size classes (e.g., ―deer size‖) are used to describe specimens that retain no diagnostic features but are similar in size and shape to a particular element from a species. Species that may be represented within the deer size category include white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus), pronghorn (Antilocapra americana), and mule deer (Odocoileus hemionus). Criteria in Lawrence (1951) are used to differentiate specimens among these species; however, since all specimens assigned to a species within the order Artiodactyla were identified to white-tailed deer, it is assumed that specimens classified as ―deer size‖ also belong to white-tailed deer. Other size classes used in this analysis include ―micro mammal,‖ which includes small rodents; ―small mammal,‖ which includes squirrels, cottontail rabbits (Sylvilagus sp.), and woodrats (Neotoma sp.);―medium mammal,‖ representing jackrabbits (Lepus sp.), raccoon (Procyon lotor), and beaver (Castor sp.); ―large mammal,‖ which includes coyote (Canis latrans) and bobcat (Lynx rufus), but not deer; and ―bison size,‖ which includes species that are too large to represent anything other than bison (Bison bison), elk (Cervus canadensis), or domestic cattle (Bos taurus). Because all specimens assigned to a species within the order Bovidae were identified to Bison bison, it is assumed that specimens classified as bison size also belong to bison. Bone specimens are quantified using two units: NSP (number of unidentified and identified specimens) and NISP (number of identified specimens). The ratio of NSP to NISP is used in this analysis as an index of fragmentation intensity (Lyman 1994; Nagaoka et al. 2008; Wolverton et al. 2002, 2008). In general, the higher the ratio of NSP to NISP, the greater the frequency of small fragments that are unidentifiable and thus the greater the intensity of fragmentation that is assumed to have occurred during an animal’s taphonomic history. The minimum number of 146

individuals (MNI) is not used in this analysis because it is a derived measure of NISP making its use redundant, and it has been demonstrated to vary as a function of sample aggregation method (Grayson 1984; Lyman 2008). NISP is used as a conservative approach. The Vertebrate Fauna A total of 6,175 fragments of bone was recovered from 41COL172, 3,857 of which were identified to taxon or size class (Table 33). Taxonomic and size-class abundances are tallied for the site assemblage as a whole in Table 34 and also by cultural phase in Table 35. The taxa represented at 41COL172 are typical for riparian/edge environments and include ungulates such as bison and white-tailed deer; large mammals such as canids; medium size mammals such as jackrabbits; small mammals such as cottontail rabbits and squirrels; micro mammals such as pocket gophers, voles, and cotton rats; as well as turtles, snakes, several avian species, and several unidentifiable fish specimens. Resource exploitation within the vertebrate fauna appears to have been broadly similar through time at 41COL172 (see Table 35); however, sample sizes were inadequate in Phases 0 and 3 to confidently interpret resource exploitation in these initial and final phases. Unfortunately, no positive identifications were made beyond the level of Osteichthyes for fish specimens (n=34), which consist primarily of nondiagnostic vertebrae centrums. Of the 15 micro mammal specimens identified beyond the level of size class, voles (Microtus sp.; n=3), pocket gophers (cf. Geomys bursarius; n =1), and cotton rats (cf. Sigmodon hispidus; n=11) represent burrowers and are considered to be intrusive to the cultural deposits at 41COL172. Other apparent intrusive remains include a large segment of vertebrae of the Texas rat snake (Elaphe obsoleta), which is also a burrower. The turtle specimens from 41COL172 were typically too small to allow for identification beyond the level of order Testudinata despite consultation of comparative materials and published keys (Olsen 1968). In many cases, nuchal carapace fragments compare closely to box turtle (Terrepene sp.), and it is very likely that box turtles are in fact represented within the current faunal collection; however, positive identifications could not be confidently made. Instead, the majority of the specimens were assigned to Testudinata, while several were conservatively assigned to cf. Terrepene sp. allowing for the possibility that the fragments could belong to other species. 147

At 41DL203, deer carcasses were apparently butchered onsite and transported to another location for further processing and consumption. Overall, it appears that similar strategies of deer carcass transport occurred through time at 41COL172. Plus or minus a few percent, the relative abundance of the majority of skeletal elements in Phase 1 is very similar to Phase 2. There are, however, some observable differences worth noting, particularly with tibiae and skull specimens. The reason for the greater percentage of tibiae in the deer assemblage from Phase 2 (20.5 percent) compared to Phase 1 (7.02 percent) is difficult to determine. It is possible that during Phase 1 humans were removing the lower hind limbs containing the tibia at kill sites more often than in Phase 2 in order to transport more high value elements back to camp. However, the metatarsal, astragalus, and calcaneus, which would have likely also been left behind at kill sites along with the tibia, are equally or more abundant in Phase 1 compared to Phase 2 (see Figure 56). Additionally, if humans were removing low-utility elements at kill sites in Phase 1, other low-utility elements (e.g., skull, distal limbs) would be expected to be left behind also. This pattern, however, does not appear to be the case because low-utility skull fragments are more than twice as abundant in Phase 1 than in Phase 2, and low- utility distal limb abundances are relatively similar in both phases. Another possible explanation for the higher percentage of tibiae in Phase 2 compared to Phase 1 relates to the higher intensity of fragmentation in Phase 2 (see taphonomy section below) relative to the identifiability of tibiae fragments when bone specimens are small. As Marshall and Pilgram (1993) have noted, fragmentation first has the effect of increasing the NISP of any given element, but at some point as fragmentation continues, NISP will level off and decrease as fragments become too small to identify. Tibia fragments tend to be very recognizable even when fragments are small because of unique curvature and surficial grooves, which tend to not overlap with other deer elements. To determine the approximate body size range of deer that were exploited at 41COL172, astragali (n=9) were measured. The astragalus was selected because it is a weight-bearing element that matures by six months in white-tailed deer (Purdue 1987; Wolverton 2008), and because it is dense (preserves well) and thus easy to measure (Figure 61). The results show that the body size of white-tailed deer at 41COL172 falls in the smaller range when compared to other white-tailed deer dating to the Holocene (Figure 62). The range matches most closely to the Eagle’s Ridge site white-tailed deer assemblage in southeast Texas where deer are very small. Interestingly, the initial faunal analysis at Eagle’s Ridge suggested that deer appear to have been small enough to have been transported whole (Reitz and Keck 1998), a similar pattern to what seems to have occurred at 41COL172. There is, however, a single outlying point that falls within the larger body size range of Missouri Holocene white-tailed deer, which are notoriously large deer. It is possible that the outlier represents a buck, given that numerous antler fragments were identified in the faunal assemblage. Overall, the evidence suggests that on the average, deer within hunting range were relatively small during occupations at 41COL172. That there seems to be a wide range in deer body size from very small to very large indicates that humans did not target specific age/sex classes and were hunting deer opportunistically. This interpretation is further strengthened by the presence of deciduous, neonatal white-tailed deer teeth in the fauna and a range of wear on permanent molars and premolars from young and older adults. In regard to seasonality of deer procurement, the presence of neonatal teeth would be consistent with late spring through summer hunting. 153

Taphonomy As is common with any zooarchaeological study, it is necessary to consider the effects of natural versus cultural modification of the animal remains recovered from a site (Lyman 1994). Taphonomy is the study of the processes that affect a bone from the time of the death of an animal to the point of excavation and recovery of the remains. Some of the major taphonomic processes that can act on bones during this time span include carnivore damage, rodent gnawing, and burning, to name a few. If evidence for these processes is present on the faunal specimens of a particular assemblage, interpretations regarding human behavior may be altered as a result. Table 37 presents the frequency in occurrence of carnivore damage, rodent gnawing, and burning in the 41COL172 assemblage. Overall, the frequency of these characteristics is low. However, it is necessary to consider the effect of each characteristic on the faunal assemblage, especially in regard to the relationship between carnivore damage and green fracturing and between burning and fragmentation (see below). Table 37 Taphonomic Characteristics Characteristic NSP %NSP Carnivore damage 69 1.1 Rodent damage 37 0.6 Burning 562 9.1 A total of 96.5 percent of the faunal assemblage is composed of fragments that are less than 5 cm in length, and less than 1 percent is larger than 10 cm (Table 38). According to Lyman (1994) and Shaffer (1992), such a bias toward the recovery of fragments less than 5 cm in size is typical of collections screened with 6.4-mm mesh. It is therefore very likely that recovery bias is partially responsible for the bone fragment-size trend at 41COL172; however, the smaller fragment size is also a function of intentional bone fragmentation for within-bone nutrient extraction followed by excellent postdepositional preservation. Evidence that small fragment size is being driven primarily by within-bone nutrient extraction and not postdepositional breakage is exhibited by the presence and degree of green fracturing. Although only 7 percent of the total NSP at 41COL172 exhibits green fracturing, approximately 25 percent of deer specimens display green fracturing. Considering that deer specimens account for approximately 26 percent of the total NSP and 42 percent of the total NISP at 41COL172, it is clear that intentional bone fragmentation occurred at a high degree and is likely the primary agent driving the small- fragment-size trend at 41COL172. Several lines of evidence suggest that fragmentation intensity increased through time at 41COL172. The ratio of NSP:NISP (index of fragmentation intensity) increases from 1.60 in Phase 1 to 1.78 in Phase 2 (Table 39). Similarly, green fracturing within the total NSP increases from 5.7 percent in Phase 1 to 9.3 percent in Phase 2. Further, green fracturing in the deer assemblage also increases from 22.9 percent in Phase 1 to 28.3 percent in Phase 2. However, it is also possible that green fracturing was caused by nonhuman agents. For example, both carnivores and humans are known to fracture fresh bone marrow cavities (Lyman 1994).
