The more spherical the shell of a species, regardless of its shell density (structure), the more likely it is to preserve (Figure 63). In addition the more dense that the shell of a particular species is, the more likely it is to preserve given its shape. The shellfish fauna assemblage from 41COL172 is well preserved. The high abundance of species with shells that are nonspherical and low in density, such as members of the genus Toxolasma and Uniomerus, indicate good preservation of shellfish remains at the site. It is important to note, both genera possess distinguishing morphological characteristics that preserve well under high fragmentation. Because of this, a given assemblage could have lower preservation despite the occurrence of these nonspherical taxa. To determine whether this was the case for 41COL172, intensity of fragmentation as measured by a ratio of NRE to NSP (the higher the value of this ratio, the larger the number of identifiable umbos) was enumerated. For this assemblage, intensity of fragmentation is 92.5 percent, which indicates a well-preserved assemblage. The presence of four intact valves of fingernail clams (Family: Sphaeriidae) underscores this point; shells of this family are extremely fragile and should only be present in assemblages with low fragmentation. Environmental Reconstruction Prehistoric environmental conditions are reconstructed using Warren’s (1991) computer program UNIO (Version 3) for analyzing archaeological mussel assemblages. Four variables are examined: water depth, current velocity, substrate composition, and type of freshwater habitat (e.g., lentic or lotic). Water depth is quantified between 0.0 m to 2.1 m. Current velocity is categorized as fast, moderate, slow, and standing. Substrate composition is defined as cobble- gravel, gravel, gravel-sand, sand, and sand-mud. Phylum Mollusca (molluscs) Class Bivalvia (bivalves) Order Unionoida (freshwater mussels) Family Unionidae (pearly mussels) Genus Lampsilis Lampsilis hydiana (Louisiana Fatmucket) NRE: 177 Shells of Lampsilis hydiana are often large, swollen, and rhomboidal or oblong in shape. The umbo is raised above the hinge line with a moderately deep beak cavity. The pseudocardinal teeth for both the right and left valves tend to be more massive compared to other species within this genus. The depth of beak cavity and the size of the pseudocardinal teeth were used as diagnostic features to identify this species. Individuals for this species were compressed, which is indicative of streams and rivers with moderate flow. Lampsilis hydiana is tolerant of both lentic and lotic systems and can adapt well to no- or low-flow conditions (Howells et al. 1996). The pseudocardinal teeth are compressed and less massive than other species within this genus. Shell ornamentation for both L. hydiana and L. teres consists of only a few indistinct ridges, which is useful for differentiating both species from Ligumia subrostrata. Yellow Sandshell is intolerant of environmental perturbations and frequent dewatering, and is found only in lotic habitats (Howells et al. 1996). Lampsilis spp. NRE: 34 Individuals that shared diagnostic morphological features between L. hydiana and L.teres were classified as Lampsilis spp. Also, shells that were badly fragmented but had pseudocardinal teeth that were clearly representative of the genus Lampsilis were also categorized as Lampsilis spp. Genus Plectomerus Plectomerus dombeyanus (Bankclimber) NRE: 11 Specimens identified as P. dombeyanus are heavy shelled, rhomboidal in shape with a pronounced posterior ridge that extends from the ventral margin and terminates near the umbo. Shell ornamentation in the form of pustules and tubercles is restricted to the beak area and is 159

useful for differentiating this species from Quadrula verrucosa. The pseudocardinal teeth for these specimens are diagnostic as well: the left valve contains two large, divergent, grooved pseudocardinal teeth separated by a shallow notch. The right valve has one elevated, grooved, pseudocardinal tooth with an anterior and posterior denticle. Bankclimber is often found near the banks or shallow areas of large, slow flowing rivers (Howells et al. 1996). The presence of P. dombeyanus is significant because it is found only in prehistoric assemblages for Northcentral Texas. Pyganodon grandis (Giant Floater) NRE: 2 Shells of P. grandis lack pseudocardinal and lateral hinge teeth. Shell ornamentation consists of a few strong, irregular, broken ridges that are sharply double looped. The bases of these loops are nodulous, which is diagnostic. This species is typically found in lakes, ponds, and backwater streams (Howells et al. 1996). Unlike T. parvus, shells for this species have a posterior ridge that is well defined, and an overall shell that is less inflated. Beaks are low but full with ornamentation that consists of seven to nine curved ridges, which is unique for this species. Toxolasma texasiensis is found in both lakes and streams, preferring habitat with little or no flow (Parmalee and Bogan 1998). Genus Uniomerus Uniomerus tetralasmus (Pondhorn) NRE: 381 Shells of Pondhorn are elongated, thin, and trapezoidal in shape. Beaks are diagnostic, with six to seven prominent concentric ridges that appear to radiate from a central point. The surface of the shell is usually covered with elevated rest period ridges. The pseudocardinal teeth are useful for differentiating this species from others with umbo ornamentation; the left valve has two elevated, thin, widely divergent pseudocardinal teeth, whereas the right valve contains one pseudocardinal tooth that is triangular in shape. This species can become locally abundant in its preferred habitat, and is adapted for desiccation, dewatering and stagnant water (Howells et al. 1996). Additionally, fingernail clams differ from unionids by the presence of both anterior and posterior lateral teeth (Howells et al. 1996). Typically, two cardinal teeth are present in each valve along with smooth anterior and posterior lateral teeth. Shell shape is round to suboval. Discussion Paleoenvironmental reconstruction in UNIO using the four defined variables produces important results. First, water body preferences for the majority of mussels examined from this site are large creeks to lentic habitats (Figure 64a). Second, the species in this assemblage seemed to represent depths between 0.3 and 0.6 m (see Figure 64b). Thus, during the late Holocene, mussels were most likely collected from shallow areas within the stream. In fact, unionid abundance is often greatest in shallows areas and then decreases as water depth increases (Dillon 2000). Third, a preference for standing waters is observed in the analysis of current-velocity habitat preference (see Figure 64c). Fourth, substrate composition appears to have consisted primarily of mud with some sand (see Figure 64d). For many East Texas rivers, mussels are most often found inhabiting substrata composed of compact sand and mud (Randklev unpublished data). Cumulatively, the UNIO habitat reconstruction indicates that 41COL172 was near a small shallow stream with mud substratum and stagnant flows. The high abundance of both T. texasiensis and U. tetralasmus underscores this point. Both species tend to be locally abundant in shallow, slow-moving, backwater areas (Howells et al. 1996; Neck 1986; Parmalee and Bogan 1998). 64. PART III: MACROBOTANICAL ANALYSIS by Dr. J. Phil Dering The purpose of this analysis is to provide an assessment of the botanical assemblages from 41COL172. A total of seven flotation samples and four macrobotanical samples was submitted for analysis. The data will be utilized to assess the nature and condition of the plant remains from these sites and provide some evidence for plant utilization and local environmental conditions. Methods Two types of samples are in the current study—flotation samples and macrobotanical samples. Flotation is a method of recovering organic remains from archaeological sediments by using water to separate heavy or soluble inorganic particles from plant parts and small animal bone. The material floating to the surface is called the light fraction, and this is caught on a fine mesh screen or strainer. The material that sinks to the bottom is the heavy fraction and it is also caught on a fine mesh screen. Most of the soil, including clay and silt, is suspended in water and passes through the screens and is either recycled or discarded. In this study, both the light and heavy fractions were submitted for analysis. Macrobotanical samples are carbonized plant remains that are separated from the rest of the archaeological material by hand. They are collected either from an excavator’s screen or are point-collected and plotted individually in the field. They are often labeled 14C or radiocarbon samples. The analysis followed standard archaeobotanical laboratory procedures. The volume of the light fraction is first measured. In most cases, as much as 100 ml of light fraction from each sample is set aside for analysis. Then, the portion to be analyzed is passed through a nested set of screens of 4-mm-, 2-mm-, 1-mm-, and 0.450-mm-mesh and examined for charred material, which is separated for identification. The heavy fraction is also scanned for charcoal, which is set aside for identification. The results are combined with identifications from each corresponding light fraction. In the current study, charred plant material was so scarce that sorting was carried out through the entire volume of each light fraction that was submitted for analysis. Plant material is sorted into two categories—woody fragments, and seed/fruit fragments including maize or agave parts when present. Identification of carbonized wood was accomplished by using the snap technique, examining the fragments at 8 to 45 magnifications with a hand lens or a binocular dissecting microscope, and comparing the material to samples in the archaeobotanical herbarium. All seed identifications were made using seed manuals and reference collections at Shumla Archeobotanical Services. Only charred plant material is included in the analysis, because uncarbonized material is consumed by insects, fungi, and bacteria and does not survive more than a few years in the deposits of open sites. Typically, as many as 25 wood charcoal fragments large enough to be manipulated are examined and identified from each flotation sample. Fragments smaller than 2 or 3 mm cannot be manipulated. They are usually placed in the indeterminate category. When a sample contains more than 25 fragments, the rest of the material is scanned to make sure that no other taxa are present. Then the volume of the charcoal is measured and included along with its weight in the report. 162

## Page 176

The results for each sample are presented in tabular format. The data from the taxa counts are also presented as presence values. Presence value or ubiquity is defined as the percentage of all analyzed samples, both productive (with charred seeds or wood) and unproductive (no identifiable carbonized plant remains), in which a particular taxon is present. This method is used primarily to provide a rough measure of the occurrence of the major plant resources identified in the samples. Presence value provides a means of determining how widespread a taxon is throughout the samples recovered from a site, but it does not evaluate the abundance of that taxon. Disturbance Indicators Sample content may be affected by various biological disturbance factors, including insect or small mammal activity, and plant root growth. In an effort to assess the impacts, the amounts of insect parts, termite pellets, gastropods, mammal remains (including fecal pellets), and modern uncharred seeds are estimated for each flotation sample. These amounts are reported on a scale of 1–5 (+), 6–25 (++), 26–50 (+++), and over 50 (++++). Termite pellets occur in higher numbers when samples are taken from an area containing wood that has been exposed to the elements for a long time before burning. In the desert, this can occur in dead trees or roots, in which case the termite pellets can appear in any locus in which this wood was burned, such as in a hearth or roasting pit. However, evidence of termite infestations seems to be more frequent and intense in samples drawn from the remains of burned prehistoric habitations with vertical elements constructed of wood. Results and Discussion Results of the analysis are presented in Tables 41 and 42. Table 41 lists the sample proveniences along with plant taxa counts from each sample. Identifications and counts of plant material recovered from each sample, including the macrobotanical sample, appear in Table 42. Disturbance indicators were abundant, and clay, usually absent from light fractions, was present in many samples. Roots and gastropods constituted the majority of the disturbance indicators. None of the samples contained uncharred seeds. Considering the size of the flotation samples, recovery of charred plant material in most of the flotation samples was poor. The total charcoal in each light fraction varied from <.1 g to 5.4 g. Only wood charcoal was identified in the samples: four woody taxa oak (Quercus sp.), plum- cherry type (Prunus-type), cottonwood-willow (Salicaceae), and woody legume (Fabaceae). Fabaceae is the legume family that contains several taxa that are difficult to separate. With the exception of Quercus sp., the types included in Table 42 present wood types that include two or more genera of woody plants. The family Salicacae includes both willow and cottonwood, two wood types that are virtually impossible to distinguish. The legume family, Fabaceae, includes redbud and honey locust that have similar gross wood anatomy, making the charred material difficult to separate. Prunus is a large genus that includes crabapples, pears, cherries, and chokecherries, all of which are in the Rosaceae or rose family. As with the previous wood types, gross anatomy of the wood is similar, difficult to separate, and therefore the charcoal from this site has been placed in the Prunus-type. 163

These trees and shrubs, typical woody plants of the Blackland Prairie region, grow along the margins of waterways or erosional breaks in the grasslands. These strips of woody vegetation usually include hackberry, hawthorn, yaupon, cedar elm, and several different oaks. Therefore, the wood types identified in the current study mirror the vegetation of the region today. The Prunus-type also includes hawthorn, a member of the rose family, and a common component of the Blackland Prairie woody vegetation. Both black willow and eastern cottonwood grow along streams in the northeastern region of Texas. Oak, although not abundant in the samples, is nevertheless present. Assuming the wood charcoal from 41COL172 reflects the available woody vegetation during occupation, then the taxa have not changed drastically since that time. This is not to say that the distribution and abundance of taxa have not changed: the herbaceous prairie vegetation has been all but destroyed during the same time period, and even the abundance of woody taxa has been altered drastically (McMahan et al. 1984). SUMMARY OF FAUNA AND FLORAL ANALYSES Vertebrate Fauna The vertebrate fauna from 41COL172 was found to be a well-preserved, uniform assemblage of fragmented, yet relatively identifiable, animal remains. Resource exploitation appears to have been broadly similar throughout time at 41COL172; however, the small sample sizes of Phases 0 and 3 precluded detailed analysis of subsistence or environmental change through time. The suite of vertebrate taxa represented in the 41COL172 fauna is consistent with a riparian/edge environment with deer and turtle representing the vast majority of specimens identified in the assemblage. Deer carcasses were likely transported relatively complete and were processed intensively as marrow was commonly extracted from both high- and low-marrow-bearing elements. Taphonomic evidence indicates that the primary fragmentation agent was humans and that nonhuman attritional bias was minimal at 41COL172. Importantly, the presence of bison in Phase 1 may supply corroborating evidence to regional research that often implies a bison population increase during the Late Prehistoric in Northcentral Texas and the Southern Plains (e.g., Dillehay 1974; Lynott 1981). Molluscan Fauna The mussel fauna from 41COL172 is important for several reasons. First, such good shell preservation is rare, and as a result, several species that are not commonly encountered in zooarchaeological assemblages in North Texas occur at the site (Randklev et al. 2009). The fauna thus represents a bit of a taphonomic anomaly in that several species with fragile shells such as Pyganodon grandis, Toxolasma texasiensis, and Uniomerus tetralasmus are represented. For the former, this is the only know account from the zooarchaeological record in Northcentral Texas (Randklev et al. 2010). The second important characteristic of the fauna relates to taphonomy; good preservation has resulted in an assemblage that is important in terms of late Holocene zoogeography of mussel species in North Texas. For example, the presence of Plectomerus dombeyanus is significant because it is found only in late Holocene assemblages for Northcentral Texas and is absent today (Randklev et al. 2010). Modern collections for this species are restricted primarily to river drainages east of the Trinity River. The identification of this species from multiple sites, including 41COL172, within Northcentral Texas suggests that 165


---

## Page 179

this species was ubiquitous in the past. Its absence during modernity is related to both inadequate modern sampling and environmental impacts that have occurred in the upper Trinity River drainage. Macrobotanical Remains The subset of flotation samples analyzed for macrobotanical preservation provides a limited dataset that is nevertheless important for reconstructing the local environment surrounding site 41COL172. Although the collection contained many disturbance indicators such as roots and gastropods, a variety of woody materials was present in the collection. The seven flotation samples and four macrobotanical samples contained cherry-plum type, woody legume type, oak, and cottonwood-willow wood types. Because the remains did not contain any seeds or fragments or other types of edible plant material, the data do not address the food foraging practices of the site occupants. However, the wood types are typical trees and shrubs of the Blackland Prairie and post oak regions of Northcentral Texas. They reflect a taxonomic continuity that has been maintained despite the radical changes in vegetation distribution that occurred over the last 200 years. Final Comments Collectively, the vertebrate and nonvertebrate fauna from 41COL172 represent a well-preserved sample that has allowed for reconstruction of past resource procurement/processing and environment. Although the sample did not permit many interphase comparisons in procurement, a noticeable increase in the intensity of marrow extraction was revealed in the Lower Late Prehistoric period (Phase 2) compared with the Upper Late Prehistoric period (Phase 1). However, throughout all phases of the site occupation, white-tailed deer appear to be represented by fragments of nearly every element, suggesting that the carcasses were transported repeatedly to the location of site 41COL172. Both the vertebrate and molluscan fauna, and to some degree the macrobotanical remains, provide separate complementary proxy measures of the past local Holocene environment. Collectively, these samples reveal an active riparian environment associated with a slow-moving, small-order stream within the Blackland Prairie of Northcentral Texas. Botanical evidence, suggests that this riparian setting was fairly constant throughout the prehistoric occupation of the site. The isotopic evidence appears to support this view that, barring normal seasonal changes, relatively modern conditions were already established prior to the occupation of the site. 166

CHAPTER 10 CERAMIC ANALYSIS by Timothy K. Perttula, Jeffrey R. Ferguson and Michael D. Glascock INTRODUCTION Of particular importance to the overall interpretation of site 41COL172 is the small ceramic collection. During the first season of NRHP testing, a single ceramic sherd displaying stylistic characteristics of prehistoric eastern Caddo groups was identified on the site. Initial interpretations of the site suggested that the ceramic assemblage reflected an influx of Caddo ideology or, perhaps, Caddo people in the area. Specifically, the question was whether the ceramics were locally manufactured or whether they were brought in or traded from adjacent regions outside of Northcentral Texas. Although Caddo ceramics have been noted to be more common within the East Fork Trinity valley than other areas of Northcentral Texas, it is unclear what connection the inhabitants of site 41COL172 may have had with the Caddo. Shafer (2006) has proposed that during the Late Prehistoric period some Caddo groups may have been living an essentially hunter-gatherer lifestyle on the prairies of Central Texas when bison and other game were abundant. Excavations at the Cobb-Pool site led to similar questions about the meaning of the Caddo-influenced ceramics in Northcentral Texas (Peter and McGregor 1988). Ultimately, Peter and McGregor (1988) concluded that the stylistic elements in the Cobb-Pool assemblage were the result of local groups imitating the Caddo styles from outside the region. Other lines of evidence on the origin of ceramics focus on petrographic and chemical techniques, such as neutron activation analysis. Good results have been obtained with these methods indicating that the ceramic traditions associated with the Prairie Caddo have been shown to have chemical signatures differing from those within the eastern Caddo region (Perttula et al. 2003). In light of these discussions, the ceramic analysis for the 41COL172 collection was conducted in two steps. First, the collection was analyzed for its functional-stylistic characteristics in order to determine the number and types of vessels represented in the collection, as well as pinpointing probable cultural affiliations represented in the collection. The results of these analyses are presented in Part I below. PART I: CERAMIC ANALYSIS by Timothy K. Perttula The analysis of the recovered ceramic sherds from 41COL172 in northern Texas emphasizes the acquisition of information on the technological and stylistic character of the aboriginal ceramic sherds from the site. Of particular interest is the manufacture and production of the sherds from the several ceramic vessels discarded at the site, as adduced from the study of temper use, firing, and surface treatment as well as the stylistic character of the few decorated sherds, with the goal of assessing the place of the pottery made and used at this site within the context of Late Prehistoric northern and eastern Texas Caddo prehistoric ceramic traditions and practices. METHODS OF ANALYSIS OF THE CERAMIC VESSEL SHERDS Detailed analysis of 16 ceramic sherds from 41COL172 is based on differences in temper, type of sherd (i.e., rim, body, or base), rim and lip form (cf. Brown 1996:Figure 2-12), decoration (if present), surface treatment (smoothing, burnishing, or polishing; see Rice 1987), and firing conditions (cf. Teltser 1993). Sherd cross sections were inspected macroscopically and with a 10X hand lens to determine the character of the paste and its inclusions. Determining the firing conditions is based on the identification of the firing core in the sherd cross sections and the identification of oxidation patterns as defined in Teltser (1993:535–536, Figure 2a-h; see also Perttula 2005). More specifically, the following attributes were employed in the analysis of the ceramics from 41COL172: (a) temper, the deliberate and indeterminate materials found in the paste (Rice 1987:411), including a variety of tempers (grog or crushed sherds, burned bone, and hematite) and ―particulate matters of some size‖; (b) although most of the sherds are small and thus from indeterminate vessel forms, where sherds were large enough, vessel form categories that could be identified include carinated bowls. Other form attributes include rim profile (i.e., outflaring or everted, direct or vertical, and inverted) and lip profile (i.e., rounded, flat, or folded to the exterior, among others). Observations on ceramic sherd cross sections permit consideration of oxidation patterns (Teltser 1993:Figure 2), namely the conditions under which a vessel was fired and then cooled after firing. Finally, wall thickness was recorded in millimeters, using a vernier caliper, along the midsection of the sherd. With respect to interior and exterior surface treatment on the sherds, the primary method of finishing the sherds is smoothing, although one sherd is burnished. Smoothing creates ―a finer and more regular surface . . . [and] has a matte rather than a lustrous surface‖ (Rice 1987:138). Burnishing creates an irregular lustrous finish marked by parallel facets left by the burnishing tool (perhaps a smoothed pebble or bone). Decorative techniques present in the 41COL172 ceramic sherd collection include incising, punctation (with a tool), and on certain sherds, combinations of decorative techniques (i.e., incised-punctated sherds) that created the decorative elements and motifs. These decorative techniques were executed with tools (wood or bone sticks or dowels). Within these general decorative methods, a few specific ceramic decorative elements are defined that represent distinct kinds of decorations or decorative combinations. 168

This vessel is a Pennington Punctated-Incised vessel (see Creel 1979:Figure 19e; Newell and Krieger 1949:Figure 39a; Stokes and Woodring 1981:Plate 21f-l; Suhm and Jelks 1962:Plate 61i), a distinctive East Texas Caddo type first defined at the ca. SUMMARY OF THE CERAMIC VESSEL SHERD ANALYSIS The analysis of the ceramic sherds from 41COL172 indicate that the 16 rim or body sherds in the assemblage are from four different vessels (Vessels 1–4). That these vessels include between only one to six sherds per vessel indicates that the vessels were broken and then widely dispersed in the archaeological deposits; the vessels were not broken and discarded in place. Vessels 1 and 3 are grog-tempered carinated bowls—and are possibly parts of the rim and body of the same vessel—that have technological, functional, and stylistic attributes consistent with their manufacture by Caddo peoples living in East Texas. Vessel 1 is a Pennington Punctated-Incised vessel, and Vessel 3 consists of plain body sherds from a carinated bowl. Both ceramic petrographic analysis and instrumental neutron activation analysis (see Ferguson et al. 2008 for the most current definition of Caddo ceramic compositional groups) of these sherds would need to be conducted to determine the manufacturing locale within the East Texas Caddo area of these vessels. The most notable characteristic of the 41COL172 ceramic sherd assemblage is the occurrence of sherds from a Pennington Punctated-Incised vessel (Vessel 1), a vessel of East Texas Caddo origin. An analysis of the ceramic assemblages from well-dated unit excavations at George C. Davis (see Perttula 1997:Table 1, amended using IntCal09 [Reimer et al. 2009]; Stokes and Woodring 1981:Table 26; Story and Valestro 1977), suggests that Pennington Punctated-Incised sherds are present in unit excavations that date from cal A.D. 897–1276, virtually the entire span of the prehistoric Caddo occupation (see Story 2000). This type is most common in archaeological deposits at the George C. Davis site that date between cal A.D. 988–1276 (14–17 percent), but excavation units at the site with decorated sherd assemblages having more than 10 percent Pennington Punctated-Incised sherds may date as early as cal A.D. 897–1039. In northwest Louisiana Caddo sites, however, there are not significant amounts of Pennington Punctated-Incised in ceramic assemblages until after ca. A.D. 1050 (Girard 2009:27–28). The presence of a Pennington Punctated-Incised vessel (or sherds from that vessel) at 41COL172 thus has specific temporal implications with respect to the age of the site, indicating it likely was occupied sometime between the late tenth century A.D. and the late thirteenth century A.D. Vessels 2 and 4 from 41COL172 are suspected to be of local manufacture, primarily because of the different kinds of tempers that were used, as well as the firing conditions exhibited by Vessel 2, the exterior roughening of Vessel 4, and the poorly executed incised decoration on Vessel 2. Both ceramic petrographic analysis and instrumental neutron activation analysis of sherds from these vessels would need to be conducted to determine their manufacturing locale. Vessel 2 has been tempered with small amounts of shell, bone, and hematite, which is not a temper composition seen in East Texas Caddo pottery, and it was fired in a distinctive manner, leaving a 174

## Page 188

thin black band along the interior sherd cores (see Table 44). It also has a simple and not well- executed geometric design of short parallel and opposed incised lines. Vessel 4 has an exterior roughened surface and is tempered with small amounts of bone. Shell-tempered Caddo pottery dates to after ca. A.D. 1300–1400 along the Red River in East Texas, but in this Late Caddo ceramic tradition, burned mussel shell is generally liberally added to the paste of both fine ware (engraved and red-slipped), utility ware (wet paste-decorated jars and bowls), and plain ware vessels; other tempers (such as bone or hematite) were not added to the paste. Therefore, Late Caddo shell-tempered ceramics from East Texas do not resemble the Vessel 2 sherds from 41COL172. Shell-tempered pottery is abundant in both Washita River and Henrietta phase sites on the Southern Plains in northern Texas and southern Oklahoma. Drass (1997:87) notes that by A.D. 1300, between 71 and 96 percent of the ceramics at Washita phase sites are shell-tempered, increasing ―dramatically through time‖ from earlier Paoli phase (ca. A.D. 900–1300) contexts. These earlier sites tend to have less than 12 percent shell-tempered pottery, and ―[i]n general, there is an increase in shell temper from very small amounts at the early Paoli sites to predominantly shell tempered ceramics at Washita River phase sites dating between A.D. 1300 and 1450‖ (Drass 1997:88). Given the estimated age of the site based on the Pennington Punctated-Incised vessel, perhaps the 41COL172 shell-tempered ceramics are contemporaneous with the shell-tempered pottery found on pre-A.D. 1300 Paoli phase sites. There is a possibility, however, that the shell-tempered vessel from 41COL172 is related to the shell-tempered pottery found as the principal ceramic ware in post-A.D. 1300 Henrietta phase sites in the upper Trinity, Brazos, and Red river basins in northern Texas, although considered unlikely because of the temper composition and firing conditions of Vessel 2. At the Harrell site on the upper Brazos River, coarse shell-tempered pottery comprises 97 percent of the sherd assemblage (n=597) (Krieger 1946). That percentage is 98.6 in post-A.D. 1430 sites (n=292 sherds) on the Elm Fork of the Trinity (Ferring and Yates 1997), and 79 percent at the 14th century A.D. Dillard site (n=754) on the Red River (Martin 1994). About 20 percent of the sherds from this site are tempered with limestone instead of shell, and another 30 percent have both shell and limestone tempers; the only nonshell- or limestone-tempered sherds are grit-and-bone- tempered cordmarked Washita River phase pottery (Drass 1997:Tables 18 and 19). PART II: NEUTRON ACTIVATON ANALYSIS by Jeffrey R. Ferguson and Michael D. Glascock This section describes the preparation, analysis, and interpretation of five pottery samples from 41COL172. One sherd was selected from each of the four vessels defined in Part I of this chapter with the exception that two sherds were analyzed from Vessel 2. A summary is given in Table 45 for the rationale for each sherd submitted to MURR. The limited number of samples from this site prohibits a detailed internal comparison, so the samples are compared to the existing Caddo reference groups from East Texas. The samples are generally similar to other East Texas samples, but not close enough to match any particular established reference group. The two samples presumed to derive from the same vessel are the two most chemically different samples, and thus it is unlikely that they are from the same vessel. 175

Fragments of about 1 cm2 were removed from each sample and abraded using a silicon carbide burr in order to remove glaze, slip, paint, and adhering soil, thereby reducing the risk of measuring contamination. The samples were washed in deionized water and allowed to dry in the laboratory. Once dry, the individual sherds were ground to powder in an agate mortar to homogenize the samples. Archival samples were retained from each sherd (when possible) for future research. Two analytical samples were prepared from each source specimen. Portions of approximately 50 mg of powder were weighed into clean high-density polyethylene vials used for short irradiations at MURR. At the same time, 200 mg of each sample was weighed into clean high-purity quartz vials used for long irradiations. Individual sample weights were recorded to the nearest 0.01 mg using an analytical balance. Both vials were sealed prior to irradiation. Along with the unknown samples, standards made from National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) certified standard reference materials of SRM-1633a (coal fly ash) and SRM-688 (basalt rock) were similarly prepared, as were quality control samples (e.g., standards treated as unknowns) of SRM-278 (obsidian rock) and Ohio Red Clay (a standard developed for in-house applications). IRRADIATION AND GAMMA-RAY SPECTROSCOPY Neutron activation analysis of ceramics at MURR, which consists of two irradiations and a total of three gamma counts, constitutes a superset of the procedures used at most other NAA laboratories (Glascock 1992; Neff 1992, 2000). As discussed in detail by Glascock (1992), a short irradiation is carried out through the pneumatic tube irradiation system. Samples in the polyvials are sequentially irradiated, two at a time, for five seconds by a neutron flux of 8 x 1013 n cm-2 s-1. The 720-second count yields gamma spectra containing peaks for nine short-lived elements: aluminum (Al), barium (Ba), calcium (Ca), dysprosium (Dy), potassium (K), manganese (Mn), sodium (Na), titanium (Ti), and vanadium (V). The samples are encapsulated 176

in quartz vials and are subjected to a 24–hour irradiation at a neutron flux of 5 x 1013 n cm-2 s-1. This long irradiation is analogous to the single irradiation utilized at most other laboratories. After the long irradiation, samples decay for seven days, and then are counted for 1,800 seconds (the ―middle count‖) on a high-resolution germanium detector coupled to an automatic sample changer. The middle count yields determinations of seven medium half-life elements, namely arsenic (As), lanthanum (La), lutetium (Lu), neodymium (Nd), samarium (Sm), uranium (U), and ytterbium (Yb). After an additional three- or four-week decay, a final count of 8,500 seconds is carried out on each sample. The latter measurement yields the following 17 long half-life elements: cerium (Ce), cobalt (Co), chromium (Cr), cesium (Cs), europium (Eu), iron (Fe), hafnium (Hf), nickel (Ni), rubidium (Rb), antimony (Sb), scandium (Sc), strontium (Sr), tantalum (Ta), terbium (Tb), thorium (Th), zinc (Zn), and zirconium (Zr). INTERPRETING CHEMICAL DATA The analyses at MURR, described above, produced elemental concentration values for 33 elements in most of the analyzed samples. Data for Ni in many samples were below detection limits (as is the norm for most New World ceramics) and was removed from consideration during the statistical analysis. Two of the five samples in this study had calcium concentrations exceeding 1 percent, and justified a calcium adjustment. The analysis here uses calcium-adjusted reference groups. The following mathematical correction was used as it has been proven to be effective in other calcium-rich datasets (Cogswell et al. 1998:64): 106e e' 106 2.5c where e′ is the corrected concentration of a given element in ppm, e is the measured concentration of that element in ppm, and c is the concentration of elemental calcium in ppm. After the calcium correction, calcium and strontium were removed from the statistical analyses. Statistical analysis was subsequently carried out on base-10 logarithms of concentrations on the remaining 30 elements. Use of log concentrations rather than raw data compensates for differences in magnitude between the major elements, such as calcium, on one hand and trace elements, such as the rare earth or lanthanide elements (REEs). Transformation to base-10 logarithms also yields a more normal distribution for many trace elements. The interpretation of compositional data obtained from the analysis of archaeological materials is discussed in detail elsewhere (e.g., Baxter and Buck 2000; Bieber et al. 1976; Bishop and Neff 1989; Glascock 1992; Harbottle 1976; Neff 2000) and will only be summarized here. The main goal of data analysis is to identify distinct homogeneous groups within the analytical database. Based on the provenance postulate of Weigand et al. (1977), different chemical groups may be assumed to represent geographically restricted sources. For lithic materials such as obsidian, basalt, and cryptocrystalline silicates (e.g., chert, flint, or jasper), raw material samples are frequently collected from known outcrops or secondary deposits and the compositional data obtained on the samples are used to define the source localities or boundaries. The locations of sources can also be inferred by comparing unknown specimens (i.e., ceramic artifacts) to knowns 177


---

## Page 191

(i.e., clay samples) or by indirect methods such as the ―criterion of abundance‖ (Bishop et al. 1992) or by arguments based on geological and sedimentological characteristics (e.g., Steponaitis et al. 1996). The ubiquity of ceramic raw materials usually makes it impossible to sample all potential ―sources‖ intensively enough to create groups of knowns to which unknowns can be compared. Lithic sources tend to be more localized and compositionally homogeneous in the case of obsidian or compositionally heterogeneous as is the case for most cherts. Compositional groups can be viewed as ―centers of mass‖ in the compositional hyperspace described by the measured elemental data. Groups are characterized by the locations of their centroids and the unique relationships (i.e., correlations) between the elements. Decisions about whether to assign a specimen to a particular compositional group are based on the overall probability that the measured concentrations for the specimen could have been obtained from that group. Initial hypotheses about source-related subgroups in the compositional data can be derived from noncompositional information (e.g., archaeological context, decorative attributes, etc.) or from application of various pattern-recognition techniques to the multivariate chemical data. Some of the pattern recognition techniques that have been used to investigate archaeological data sets are cluster analysis (CA), principal components analysis (PCA), and discriminant analysis (DA). Each of the techniques has its own advantages and disadvantages, which may depend upon the types and quantity of data available for interpretation. The variables (measured elements) in archaeological and geological data sets are often correlated and frequently large in number. This makes handling and interpreting patterns within the data difficult. Therefore, it is often useful to transform the original variables into a smaller set of uncorrelated variables in order to make data interpretation easier. Of the above-mentioned pattern recognition techniques, PCA is a technique that transforms from the data from the original correlated variables into uncorrelated variables most easily. PCA creates a new set of reference axes arranged in decreasing order of variance subsumed. The individual PCs are linear combinations of the original variables. The data can be displayed on combinations of the new axes, just as they can be displayed on the original elemental concentration axes. PCA can be used in a pure pattern-recognition mode, i.e., to search for subgroups in an undifferentiated data set, or in a more evaluative mode, i.e., to assess the coherence of hypothetical groups suggested by other criteria. Generally, compositional differences between specimens can be expected to be larger for specimens in different groups than for specimens in the same group, and this implies that groups should be detectable as distinct areas of high point density on plots of the first few components. It is well known that PCA of chemical data is scale dependent (Mardia et al. 1979), and analyses tend to be dominated by those elements or isotopes for which the concentrations are relatively large. This is yet another reason for the log transformation of the data. One frequently exploited strength of PCA, discussed by Baxter (1992), Baxter and Buck (2000), and Neff (1994, 2002), is that it can be applied as a simultaneous R- and Q-mode technique, with both variables (elements) and objects (individual analyzed samples) displayed on the same set of principal component reference axes. A plot using the first two principal components as axes is usually the best possible two-dimensional representation of the correlation or variance-covariance structure within the data set. Small angles between the vectors from the origin to variable coordinates indicate strong positive correlation; angles at 90 degrees indicate no correlation; and 178


---

## Page 192

angles close to 180 degrees indicate strong negative correlation. Likewise, a plot of sample coordinates on these same axes will be the best two-dimensional representation of Euclidean relations among the samples in log-concentration space (if the PCA was based on the variance- covariance matrix) or standardized log-concentration space (if the PCA was based on the correlation matrix). Displaying both objects and variables on the same plot makes it possible to observe the contributions of specific elements to group separation and to the distinctive shapes of the various groups. Such a plot is commonly referred to as a ―biplot‖ in reference to the simultaneous plotting of objects and variables. The variable inter-relationships inferred from a biplot can be verified directly by inspecting bivariate elemental concentration plots. (Note that a bivariate plot of elemental concentrations is not a biplot.) Whether a group can be discriminated easily from other groups can be evaluated visually in two dimensions or statistically in multiple dimensions. A metric known as the Mahalanobis distance (or generalized distance) makes it possible to describe the separation between groups or between individual samples and groups on multiple dimensions. The Mahalanobis distance of a specimen from a group centroid (Bieber et al. 1976; Bishop and Neff 1989) is defined by: D2 [y X]tI [y X] y,X x where y is the 1 x m array of logged elemental concentrations for the specimen of interest, X is the n x m data matrix of logged concentrations for the group to which the point is being compared with X being its 1 x m centroid, and I is the inverse of the m x m variance-covariance matrix x of group X. Because Mahalanobis distance takes into account variances and covariances in the multivariate group, it is analogous to expressing distance from a univariate mean in standard deviation units. Like standard deviation units, Mahalanobis distances can be converted into probabilities of group membership for individual specimens. For relatively small sample sizes, it is appropriate to base probabilities on Hotelling’s T2, which is the multivariate extension of the univariate Student’s t. When group sizes are small, Mahalanobis distance-based probabilities can fluctuate dramatically depending upon whether or not each specimen is assumed to be a member of the group to which it is being compared. Harbottle (1976) calls this phenomenon ―stretchability‖ in reference to the tendency of an included specimen to stretch the group in the direction of its own location in elemental concentration space. This problem can be circumvented by cross-validation, that is, by removing each specimen from its presumed group before calculating its own probability of membership (Baxter 1994; Leese and Main 1994). This is a conservative approach to group evaluation that may sometimes exclude true group members. Small sample and group sizes place further constraints on the use of Mahalanobis distance: with more elements than samples, the group variance-covariance matrix is singular thus rendering calculation of I (and D2 itself) impossible. Therefore, the dimensionality of the groups must x somehow be reduced. One approach would be to eliminate elements considered irrelevant or redundant. The problem with this approach is that the investigator’s preconceptions about which elements should be discriminate may not be valid. It also squanders the main advantage of multielement analysis, namely, the capability to measure a large number of elements. An alternative approach is to calculate Mahalanobis distances with the scores on principal components extracted from the variance-covariance or correlation matrix for the complete data 179


---

## Page 193

set. This approach entails only the assumption, entirely reasonable in light of the above discussion of PCA, that most group-separating differences should be visible on the first several PCs. Unless a data set is extremely complex, containing numerous distinct groups, using enough components to subsume at least 90 percent of the total variance in the data can be generally assumed to yield Mahalanobis distances that approximate Mahalanobis distances in full elemental concentration space. Lastly, Mahalanobis distance calculations are also quite useful for handling missing data (Sayre 1975). When many specimens are analyzed for a large number of elements, it is almost certain that a few element concentrations will be missed for some of the specimens. This occurs most frequently when the concentration for an element is near the detection limit. Rather than eliminate the specimen or the element from consideration, it is possible to substitute a missing value by replacing it with a value that minimizes the Mahalanobis distance for the specimen from the group centroid. Thus, those few specimens that are missing a single concentration value can still be used in group calculations. RESULTS Comparison with Texas Caddo Compositional Groups The MURR Caddo database (consisting of approximately 1,000 ceramic samples, mostly submitted by Tim Perttula) is one of the largest samples from any region in the world. It is also one of the most complex. Over the past decade, the compositional group structure has undergone numerous modifications and has recently undergone a minimally successful complete reanalysis (Ferguson et al. 2008). The most recent interpretation of the East Texas Caddo database divided the region into 11 subregions (Figure 68). Each of these subregions was then treated as an individual dataset, and for most subregions, a core group has been isolated. Unfortunately, many of these core groups consistently overlap, making the determination of the location of production very problematic. Based on the location of the site, the most likely regional match would be with the two groups (subregions 1 and 2) along the Red River of northeastern Texas. Fortunately, these two groups are some of the only regional core groups to separate from the mass of samples found throughout most of the rest of the Caddo region to the south. The samples were plotted against each of the compositional groups identified from each of the subregions and none of the samples consistently plotted within any of the groups. Figure 69 is a plot of the five new samples compared to the Region 1 and 2 Core Groups. Statistical overlap between the regional core groups makes it difficult to use Mahalanobis distance projections to examine the probabilities of membership for the new samples. However, there are a few compositional groups with enough samples to allow the use of almost all elements in the projection. Sample GMI023 (Vessel 1) is the only sample with a significant probability of membership in any of the larger regional compositional groups. GMI023 has at least a 10 percent probability of membership in groups from Regions 4, 5, 6, and 7, with the highest probability of membership in Group 4 (Figure 70). 180

SUMMARY Sherds from four different vessels at 41COL172 have been identified in the small ceramic sherd assemblage from this buried archaeological site. Two vessels (Vessels 1 and 3) were apparently made by Caddo peoples living in East Texas, and the other two vessels (Vessels 2 and 4) may be of local manufacture. The occurrence of a discarded and broken Pennington Punctated-Incised Caddo vessel (Vessel 1) at the site would seem to constitute evidence of contact/interaction between East Texas Caddo peoples and the local occupants of the site. That contact/interaction took place between the late tenth and late thirteenth centuries A.D. Of the five samples submitted for NAA from 41COL172, only the Pennington Punctated-Incised sherd (GMI023) seems to fit the typical compositional patterns observed for the central region of the East Texas Caddo. None of the other vessels is completely different from the range of Caddo material, but they do not fit the established compositional groups. The compositional analysis of two sherds from Vessel 2 suggested that a significant degree of compositional variation exists between the two samples. This variation could suggest that the samples were from two distinct vessels, or that a there is very high degree of compositional variation within the vessel. 184

CHAPTER 11 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS by Arlo McKee INTRODUCTION The successive field investigations at site 41COL172 have provided a data set of materials dating to a fairly narrow time period during the Late Prehistoric period. The seven radiocarbon dates obtained from both charcoal and animal bone have bracketed the site to a roughly 530-year period between 980 and 450 yr B.P. (A.D. 970–1500). Within this period, the majority of the diagnostic cultural materials were associated with dates between 770 and 560 yr B.P. (A.D. 1180–1390). These radiocarbon ages place the site at a transitional period between the Late Prehistoric I and Late Prehistoric II periods, as defined by the major investigations in the region (e.g., Peter and McGregor 1988; Prikryl 1987, 1990; Yates and Ferring 1986). The Late Prehistoric period in Northcentral Texas is signaled by a number of changes in prehistoric lifeways. Principally, the period has been defined by the adoption of both ceramics and bow-and-arrow technologies, as well as the occurrence of corn horticultural practices. The two subdivisions within the Late Prehistoric period have also been marked by changes in projectile point morphology that may have corresponded with changes in the abundance of bison populations. The data recovery investigations at site 41COL172 were carried out in hopes of adding new data concerning the specific timing of these events within the region. Initially, the discovery of the Caddoan Pennington Punctated-Incised ceramics was of particular interest, for the site appeared to be an ephemeral hunting camp with well-preserved stratigraphic integrity. Although Caddoan-influenced pottery is not unique on sites within the East Fork of the Trinity River valley, the specific Pennington type is relatively undocumented in well-preserved settings. However, within the Caddo home range in East Texas, Pennington wares have been well documented and attributed to the late tenth through the late thirteenth centuries A.D. Given that site 41COL172 was an essentially minimally occupied site, the theory was that the data recovery investigations could help pinpoint the timing of the introduction of Caddoan ceramics to the area. 185

SITE DEPOSITION AND INTEGRITY Based on the results of the field excavations at 41COL172, it became apparent that the cultural materials at the site had been deposited as the result of multiple discrete occupations. The distinction of exactly how many points in time, and for what duration, the site was occupied has proven to be difficult, at best. One of the more significant results concerning this issue concerned the sedimentation rates calculated as part of the geoarchaeological work at the site (Chapter 7). The sedimentation rates have had a dramatic effect on how the site function or occupation intensity is interpreted. According to these data, the profile aggraded at different rates, with sediment input, overall, slowing through time during the prehistoric occupation of the site. For instance, at the bottom of the section, the rates were approximately 17.5 cm per century, while at the top these rates slowed to an average of 6 cm per century. The slowing of the sedimentation allowed for the formation of the thick, well-expressed cumulic profile at the top of the Pilot Point alluvium. The cumulic portion of the profile, represented by the 25-cm-thick, A horizon, represents an approximately 400 year period in which the site would have been a quasi-stable surface. Conversely, the underlying ~25-cm B horizon represents only 150 years within the profile. If one would assume that random chance were the only factor determining intensity of site occupation (i.e., Ferring 1986; Hoyer 1980; Mandel and Bettis 2001), based on these data, the materials from the upper occupation should account for roughly two thirds of the collection. However, this does not appear to be the case. The artifact frequencies observed at the site showed that within roughly the same thickness of sediment, approximately 54 percent of the materials were recovered from the upper occupational zone (n=5,710), while 46 percent (n=4,791) were recovered from the lower occupation zone. By weight, the frequencies are even more skewed toward an intensity of occupation in the lower component, with 44 percent of materials coming from the upper occupation and 56 percent from the lower. Both of these measurements suggests that, overall, site 41COL172 was most intensively occupied within the Lower Late Prehistoric component, and less intensively occupied during the Upper Late Prehistoric component. Aside from sediment input affecting the level of the ground surface at the time of occupation, at least two forms of pedoturbation have also acted on the archaeological deposits at the site. First, the clay-rich sediments exhibited both abundant slickensides and wide vertical cracks as the sediments dried during excavation. Collectively, these two forms of argilliturbation are defining characteristics for the Vertisol soil order, to which the West Fork Paleosol belongs. Vertisols are common to the Blackland Prairie due to the wide availability of expanding clay minerals that have weathered ultimately from the fine-grained bedrock of the area. The seasonal shrink-swell process is commonly attributed as a destructive force in archaeological sites since the swelling causes lateral movement of peds and the shrinking of the sediments furthers the chances that artifacts will move vertically through the profile (e.g., Abbott 2001; Holliday 2004). The second form of pedoturbation that affected the site’s integrity was really only apparent after the excavation units and profile walls were allowed to dry. The dark sediments at the site were typically very dark gray (10YR 3/1) to very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) when moist. The persistence of dark materials through the paleosol prohibited the clear distinction of krotovina until after the sediments had been excavated. Based on the field observations and profiles of artifacts clearly within krotovina, as well as the lack of large size-classes within the deeper levels of the excavations, it is apparent that materials have been translocated from the upper levels of the paleosol. 186

## Page 200

The natural site formation processes of sedimentation, erosion, and pedoturbation have certainly limited the interpretability of many aspects of the site’s context. It is evident, from the multiple in situ cultural features at the site at different depths that the site was occupied at multiple times. However, our inability to accurately identify the individual occupations has led to the fairly coarse interpretation that the assemblage can be grouped into only two analytical units or phases. Even with this separation, there is some evidence to suggest that some degree of mixing has occurred between the defined phases. This was most clearly evident with the occurrence of multiple sherds from the same vessel at different depths within the profile (see Figure 32). The recognition of the effects of these formation processes must be kept in mind when interpreting the meaning of the site. REGIONAL CULTURAL CHRONOLOGY Several different cultural chronologies have been developed for the Late Prehistoric period in Northcentral Texas. The development of the regional chronologies have primarily been formulated as part of a several theses and dissertations (Lynott 1977, 1981; Prikryl 1987, 1990), as well as the major reservoir investigations that took place since the late 1970s (Lewisville Lake [Ferring and Yates 1998]; Lake Ray Roberts [Ferring and Yates 1997]; Lake Lavon [Lynott 1975]; Richland Creek [McGregor and Bruseth 1987]; Lake Joe Pool [Peter and McGregor 1988]). Many of the studies in the region have led to a general consensus of the timing of major technological innovations (e.g., the adoption of the bow and arrow) or subsistence practices (e.g., corn agriculture); however, linking the archaeological materials to specific prehistoric ethnographic groups has been a concern for the region as a whole. Concerning the Late Prehistoric period, the introduction of different ceramic types to the area has raised questions of whether certain areas in the region had more interaction with Caddoan populations to the east or Plains villagers to the west. The Late Prehistoric period has been subdivided in two primarily different ways. Prikryl (1990) and Lynott (1977) subdivided the period into an early and late period. Additional research at Lake Joe Pool (Peter and McGregor 1988) and Richland Creek (McGregor and Bruseth 1987) resulted in the formulation of a tripartite system for the Late Prehistoric; however, the specific timing of these periods differ slightly. Throughout this document, Prikryl’s (1990) division of the Late Prehistoric has generally been applied since it is the simpler of the two systems. Prikryl (1990) subdivided the period into Late Prehistoric I (1250–750 yr B.P.) and Late Prehistoric II (750–350 yr B.P.) subperiods. Prikryl distinguished the Late Prehistoric I assemblages based on the first occurrence of pottery as well as the adoption of bow-and-arrow technology. Toward the later portion of this period, corn horticulture was introduced to the area, as evidenced at the Cobb-Pool site in southwestern Dallas County (Peter and McGregor 1988). Diagnostic lithic artifacts of the Late Prehistoric I period include Scallorn, Alba, Steiner, and Catahoula arrow points, and pottery was typically grog-tempered plainwares. By Late Prehistoric II times, Plains Village-like assemblages are common throughout the area. The projectile point styles tend towards Washita, Fresno, Perdiz, and Harrell types. Additionally, a variety of thumbnail scrapers, bifacial knives, and flake drills are common. Prikryl also notes that shell- tempered pottery is also increasingly present during the Late Prehistoric II period. These technological styles have been linked to an increased reliance of bison during the period. 187


---

## Page 201

At Lake Joe Pool, Peter and McGregor (1988) defined three phases of the Late Prehistoric, which each encompass a 300-year period: Early (1250–950 yr B.P.), Middle (950–650 yr B.P.), and Late (650–350 yr B.P.). McGregor and Bruseth (1987) gave different names and slightly different dates to the three phases of the Late Prehistoric at Richland Creek. As defined by McGregor and Bruseth, the Late Prehistoric period can be subdivided by the Richland Creek phase (1250–1050 yr B.P.), Round Prairie (1050–650 yr B.P.), and St. Elmo (650–300 yr B.P.); however, they also admit that there was likely considerable overlap between the periods, indicating that this is essentially the same system as proposed for Lake Joe Pool. Whichever of these tripartite systems is employed, a similar progression of lithic and ceramic technologies is evident. Scallorn and Steiner points are generally regarded as early arrow point forms, which are gradually replaced by Alba types. Toward the end of the Late Prehistoric period, Perdiz, Fresno, and Cliffton points appear in assemblages in the area. Ceramics tend to be grog-tempered in the earlier phases of the Late Prehistoric, and shell-tempered ceramics appear in assemblages after A.D.1000. With these trends in mind, site 41COL172 was excavated in hopes of helping to provide new data to the cultural developments that took place during the Late Prehistoric period. Both grog- and shell-tempered ceramics were identified in the collection; however, these appeared to be mixed within the profile. Several of the diagnostic Pennington sherds, which are presumed to have been from the same vessel, were identified at multiple depths within the profile. The projectile point collection, too, appeared to contain a Perdiz assemblage with some earlier points, such as an Alba and Steiner point. However, the various projectile point types were also found within the same occupational horizons at the site. It is likely that these various tool forms were used contemporaneously; however, given that the site was likely occupied repeatedly over a roughly 500-year period, it is equally likely that different groups, carrying a different tool assemblage, resulted in a mixed assemblage. It is thus not possible to accurately determine the timing of different tool styles at the site. Hence, the site offers very little toward a refinement of the cultural chronology of the area except for documenting the activities at a small, repeatedly used, deer-processing site in Northcentral Texas. PALEOENVIRONMENTAL RECONSTRUCTION Research of past environmental conditions within the plains region of the United States has been uneven, with the Southern Plains within Northcentral Texas being the least documented (Prikryl 1993). To date, there have been only a few interdisciplinary investigations of paleoenvironmental reconstructions within the region (Brown 1998; Frederick 2009; Humphrey and Ferring 1994). These investigations do not all agree with the general cycles of temperature and precipitation that have been cited as potential influences on prehistoric game availability (Ferring and Yates 1998:151–152). Hence, additional work focusing on reconstructing past climate conditions is needed. The investigations at 41COL172 provide only a narrow window in which to examine climate change. However, two proxies (δ13C, faunal diversity, molluscan diversity) were examined to help elucidate the local environment during the Late Prehistoric period. Initially pollen samples were also to be included, given that the presence of a well-preserved faunal assemblage might also indicate a well-preserved pollen record. However, the examination of several flotation samples for macrobotanical remains indicated that pollen was likely not preserved at the site. Thus, pollen and phytolith analysis was not conducted. 188

## Page 202

The isotopic data from the site generally display that modern climatic conditions were established at the site prior to the occupation of 41COL172. In general, there does appear to be a general trend toward increasing contributions from cool season grasses progressively through the period. However, this contribution ranges from approximately 40 to 50 percent C , corresponding to a 2 4 per mil PDB change. Hence, much of the data from the Late Prehistoric period at the site are a study of continuity throughout all phases of occupation. The faunal assemblage from 41COL172 only provides a general proxy measure of the environment through the entire duration of the site. The vertebrate fauna was fairly uniform in its diversity throughout the site, and small changes in the number and variety of species throughout different depths in the profile could simply have been a factor of sample size and were not used in a phase-by-phase interpretation of past environment. Similarly, the small sample size of the molluscan fauna also provided only a general reconstruction of the local environment at the site as a whole. However, collectively, the faunal assemblage from 41COL172 reveals riparian taxa consistent with a slow-moving, small-order stream (see Chapter 9). SUBSISTENCE PRACTICES Subsistence data have been systematically gathered from archaeological sites in Northcentral Texas for more than 20 years. Although some diachronic trends have been postulated for the region (e.g., bison population increase in the Late Prehistoric II period), little systematic work has been carried out in the region addressing subsistence practices. Over the past few decades, select data sets from discrete and varied locations across the region have been used to discuss possible subsistence strategies through time. Not surprisingly, these disparate data sets are from numerous environmental settings within the region and have revealed a range of data suggesting subsistence variation through time and space. Many of the Late Prehistoric sites in the region show great continuity of occupation and subsistence patterns from the Late Archaic. McGregor and Bruseth (1987) note that the flora and fauna for the early Late Prehistoric was generally similar to the preceding period, with an increase in the Psoralea sp. bulb remains. Maize appears by A.D. 1000 in the Mountain Creek drainage at the Cobb-Pool (41DL148) site and represents over 71 percent of the recovered botanical remains, with Psoralea sp., nutshell, maygrass, and vetch also being present (Peter and McGregor 1988). To date, maize has not been confirmed on any other site in northcentral Texas with an early Late Prehistoric component. Maize does appear at a number of sites in Northcentral Texas, but the context has not been well documented for most sites. By the later portion of the Late Prehistoric (A.D. 1300–1600), several changes are noted in regional subsistence patterns. Maize appears in Richland Creek contexts at the same time fish and turtle species decrease in abundance (McGregor and Bruseth 1987). McGregor and Bruseth (1987) report that bison remains do not significantly increase during this period, but Ferring and Yates (1998) and Peter and McGregor (1988) argue for their increased presence during the later part of the Late Prehistoric. Although attributed to a shift in bison procurement and Plains influences, the presence of shell-tempered pottery is noted for both areas where bison evidence increases as well as for areas where it appears to remain the same. 189

## Page 203

The Late Prehistoric subsistence patterns for 41COL172 remain largely the same throughout the duration of the Late Prehistoric occupation of the site. Large-animal hunting with a heavy reliance upon deer (and a very small percentage of bison), as well as the exploitation of small riverine fauna, such as turtle, constitute the majority of the assemblage throughout the Late Prehistoric period. Botanical data directly reflecting subsistence were not recovered from the bulk flotation samples collected at the site and, as such, makes regional comparisons difficult. However, it is likely, given the site’s function as a short-term processing area that domesticated plant foods may not have contributed to a large portion of the subsistence at the site, even if agriculture was practiced by the Late Prehistoric group that occupied 41COL172. Other post- A.D. 1300 Late Prehistoric shifts seen in other regional sites, such as the increase in bison hunting or a reduction in fish and turtle, were only evident in the few bison remains that were identified in the upper portion of the profile. Though given the small sample size, it is unclear if the presence of bison during this time reflects sampling strategy rather than an increased reliance on bison during this period. Regarding subsistence practices, 41COL172 appears to be a study in continuity. In spite of evidence for climatic variations that occurred throughout the Late Prehistoric period, subsistence patterns were very similar through time. TECHNOLOGICAL PATTERNS Prikryl (1990:80) states that the Late Prehistoric II period (750–250 yr B.P.) is commonly composed of diagnostic chipped stone tools of the Washita, Harrell, Perdiz, and Fresno types. Accompanying this technology is a variety of scrapers, edge-beveled knives, and flake drills. The Late Prehistoric II stone tool assemblage has been commonly attributed to an increased focus on bison hunting by hunter-gatherer groups throughout much of Texas (Prikryl 1990). By contrast, the preceding Late Prehistoric I period (1250–750 yr B.P.) is associated with Scallorn, Alba, Steiner, and Catahoula points (Prikryl 1990:77). There is also some debate as to whether Late Archaic Gary dart points continued to be produced and used during the Late Prehistoric period (c.f. Bruseth and Martin 1987; Prikryl 1990). Bison hunting was still an important part of subsistence practices during the Late Prehistoric I period, but there is evidence to suggest that climatic conditions would have been increasingly favorable to bison populations during the Late Prehistoric II period (Humphrey and Ferring 1994). Given that the vast majority of the diagnostic projectile points at 41COL172 were identified within the Upper Late Prehistoric component of the site (dated between 610–450 yr B.P.), it is not surprising that the collection is dominated by Perdiz points and flake tools. Two diagnostic points (one Alba and one Steiner) commonly attributed to the Late Prehistoric I period were also recovered, though these appear to have been contemporaneous with the Late Prehistoric II technology. Given that the Late Prehistoric II technologies are commonly attributed to the increased economic reliance on bison hunting and the assemblage at 41COL172 consists primarily of deer, it is likely that the earlier Alba and Steiner points were still utilized during the later periods. Given the problems of bioturbation of many of the materials within the profile, it is difficult to determine whether the earlier projectile types were contemporaneously used along with the Perdiz technology. Whatever the case concerning the projectile point styles, the overall degree of tool production at the site appeared to be skewed toward early reduction stages of chipped stone tool manufacture (Brown 2001), and minimal reuse of lithic resources for hot-rock cooking (Thompson and Mauldin 2008). Additionally, the material types in the collection represent a general reliance on 190


---

## Page 204

locally available materials, with quartzite representing approximately 90 percent of both the fire- cracked rock and lithic debitage categories. Even with the abundantly local signature of the lithic materials, the ceramics appear to represent, by-and-large, a mixed signature. The neutron activation analysis (see Chapter 10) yielded results to indicate that only the decorated Pennington Punctated-Incised ceramics were produced outside of the region. The remaining sherds failed to display characteristics definitive of the Caddo source areas; and thus, specific provenance could not be determined for the undecorated sherds from 41COL172. REGIONAL EXCHANGE AND INTERACTION As previously stated, none of the items in the assemblage from site 41COL172 would be immediately labeled as exotic materials. The absence of exotic materials limits insights into long-distance exchange. However, the presence of ceramics that appear to have been produced within the Caddo home region of East Texas does represent at least a regional interaction with other groups. Shafer (2006) has suggested that many assemblages within the Late Prehistoric period in Central Texas contain sufficient Caddoan influence (evidenced in ceramic types, decorative motifs, chipped-stone bifacial and projectile technologies, and bone tools such as beamers and needles), to warrant the distinction of a plains group of Caddo within Central Texas. Shafer postulated that this group of Caddo likely shared ideological, and perhaps linguistic, ties with the East Texas Caddo; however, their reliance on agriculture would have been less than that within the Caddo home region. The geographic distribution of artifacts that Shafer identifies for defining the Southern Prairie Caddo model has no easily perceived corollary with the northern prairie of the upper Trinity River. However, Shafer suggested that ceramic styles relating to early Caddo pottery of the Sanders focus, as well as Bonham-Alba, Steiner, and Friley arrow points, may be indicative of a Prairie Caddo presence within the northern prairie area. Given this definition, several of the artifacts in the collection from 41COL172 surficially appear to fit with the Prairie Caddo complex. These artifacts include two projectile points (one Alba point and one Steiner point), a bone needle, and grog-tempered undecorated and decorated Pennington Punctated-Incised ceramics reflective of early Caddo pottery. However, all of these artifact types are common to Late Prehistoric sites in the region, and interpretation as material correlates of population movement or the transfer of ideas is difficult. Other materials, such as an abundance of Perdiz type technologies and shell-tempered plainwares, also appear to be at least equally as abundant in the collection. Shafer (2006) notes that generally, Perdiz technologies tend to replace the earlier projectile point types associated with the Prairie Caddo. However, given the general similarity in point morphology, it is difficult to tell whether this is attributed to a stylistic variation, or if it reflects different people with ideologies differing from the Caddo. It is also important to note that the complex of traits (both plain shell-tempered plainware and decorated pottery) observed at 41COL172 is not altogether uncommon for sites on the East Fork. In fact, this complex of artifacts, combined with the occurrence of large circular pits in the region, led Stephenson (1952) to define the Wylie focus. Subsequent investigations of Wylie focus sites along Lake Lavon (Lynott 1975), and Richland Creek (McGregor and Bruseth 1987) concentrated on the use and function of the Wylie pits themselves. These studies have ultimately led to the determination that the Wylie pits were likely built and used during the Late Archaic period, rather than the Late Prehistoric; and given the mixed assemblages, the Wylie focus has 191


---

## Page 205

been abandoned and is regarded as an archaeological construct, rather than indicative of an actual prehistoric culture. Neither a Wylie pit nor a Late Archaic occupation was discovered at 41COL172. Unfortunately, none of the other lines of evidence (such as burials, house structures, Gahagan or Friday bifaces, or metapodial beamers) that Shafer (2006) used to distinguish the Prairie Caddo were identified at the site. Additionally, both the diagnostic lithics and ceramics from the site appear to have been from mixed contexts, such that determining whether the diagnostic materials were from temporally distinct occupations is impossible. Ultimately, the few definitively Caddo artifacts that were identified at the site were interpreted as trade items (see Chapter 10) and not as evidence for Caddo people moving into the region. FINAL DISCUSSION The testing and data recovery investigations at site 41COL172 adjacent to Muddy Creek in Collin County have provided a site-specific data set pertaining to a Late Prehistoric animal processing site. Data were recovered spanning through a transitional period between the earlier and later portions of the Late Prehistoric period. It is during this time when bison populations may have been greater than during preceding periods and when the practice of agriculture has been documented in the area. Data from the site are placed within a regional context and many similarities were noted with other creek-side procurement sites investigated within Northcentral Texas (e.g., 41DL203). However, certain differences were also noted. For instance, bison hunting was not exceptionally evident within the assemblage even though the presence of a few bison bones was one of the first research attractions of the site. Instead during each occupational zone, the site appears to reflect a continuity of intensive animal processing activities centered on the exploitation of deer and riparian small animals. The artifactual data from the site also show a combination of plains and Caddo technologies. However, evidence for how these materials came to be represented at this small animal processing site is scant. Multiple sherds from one vessel were identified at the site; however, these appeared to be vertically mixed through the upper portion of the profile. Hence, the exact timing of the use of this vessel is impossible to pin down. The Pennington type has been confidently attributed to a terminal range of A.D. 1300, and the radiocarbon dates from 41COL172 certainly place this vessel at the latter portion of this range. How long the vessel was in use, and whether or not it was directly traded with groups in the Caddo homeland is still up to speculation. However long the vessel was in use, the investigations at 41COL172 suggest that the Pennington vessel was a trade item and the site does not likely reflect an immigration of Caddo people to the area. 192

APPENDIX B BACKHOE TRENCH AND CORE DESCRIPTIONS

## Page 731

BACKHOE TRENCHES FROM SITE 41COL172 Profile of the West Wall Trench A: This was the first trench placed on site 41COL172. The trench was placed south of a bois d’arc tree and west/southwest of initial test trench #1 excavated by PBS&J (Sills et al. 2005a). The trench was orientated in align with magnetic north. The trench measured 4.6 m long, 1.8 m wide at the top half and 0.8 m wide in the bottom half to a depth of 3 m. Once excavated and profiled the overburden was removed from the northwest corner of the trench to allow for the placement of a 50-x-50- cm test unit. The space cleared by the backhoe measured roughly 3.1 m by 2.6 m. The stratigraphic sequence observed in Test Unit 1 was identical to that observed in the Trench Profile.
