Profile of the South Wall of Test Unit 2, Trench B: Trench B was the second trench placed on the site. This trench was located to the south of the mid-point between the initial survey Trenches #1 and #2 (Sills et al. 2005a). Trench B was orientated in align with magnetic north and was 4.3 m long, 1.7 m wide at the top half and 0.8 wide at the bottom half and was 2.4 m deep. Once excavated and profiled the overburden was removed from the northeast corner of the trench to allow for the placement of a 50-x-50-cm test unit. The space cleared by the backhoe measured roughly 2.4 m by 2.75 m. The stratigraphic sequence observed in Test Unit 2 was identical to that observed in the profile of Trench A. The stratigraphy observed in this trench appeared to be identical to that observed in Trench A. The nature of the clayey soil made it extremely difficult to profile and excavate. These logistical concerns and the fact there appeared to be little or no observable horizontal variability present supported the decision to focus attention on the excavation of the test unit than spend time and energy profiling the wall of the trench. The table presented here shows the observed horizons in relation to the test excavations carried out in Test Unit 2. Profile of the East Wall of Trench F: The stratigraphic profile of Trench F appeared somewhat different from the stratigraphic sequences observed in Trenches A, B, C, D, and E. The sedimentary structures of the horizons are very similar, but the degree of the human signature is completely different between the location of Trench F and the others. Trench F lacks the association of the cultural material observed in the northern section of the site. The reason for this is because there is a filled in former channel of Muddy Creek running between Trenches F and E. The channel, in effect, marks the southern boundary of the site and Trench F is south of the site. These observable features on the landscape confirmed by aerial photographs necessitated the profile of the trench wall to fully document the geological setting of the area beyond the site. Trench F was located to the south of Trench E. Trench F was orientated 20o west of magnetic north and was 4.2 m long, 1.5 m wide at the top half and 0.8 wide at the bottom half and was 2.9 m deep. Once excavated and profiled the overburden was removed from the northeast corner of the trench to allow for the placement of a 50-x-50-cm test unit. The space cleared by the backhoe measured roughly 3.2 m by 2.2 m. The stratigraphic sequence observed in Test Unit 5 was identical to that observed in profile of Trench A. B-5

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY The Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), Environmental Affairs Division, subcontracted the investigations reported here with Geo-Marine, Inc., under work authorization 57512SA010 created by Scientific Services Contract No. 575XXSA010 (Contract) between the State of Texas, acting through the Texas Department of Transportation (State), and Geo Marine, Inc. (Technical Expert). GMI was responsible for performing the environmental services described as archeological testing of two sites in Collin County: site 41COL172, FM 1378 (Country Club Road) from FM 544 to FM 3412 (Brown Street), CSJ 0619-06-007; and site 41COL173, FM 981 at Desert Creek, CSJ 1012-03-013. This appendix details the results of investigations at site 41COL173, FM 981 at Desert Creek, CSJ 1012-03-013. The construction project will involve the realignment a bridge replacement on FM 981 near Blue Ridge. An initial reconnaissance was conducted by PBS&J during the summer of 2005, confirming the existence of the deeply buried prehistoric site 41COL173 within the proposed area of potential effects (APE). The APE includes the terrace edge immediately adjacent to Desert Creek at FM 981. The 2006 testing program conducted at both sites consisted of mechanical trenching, followed by hand excavation of test units in selected areas. Site 41COL173 yielded two diagnostic projectile points from intact deposits in addition to higher than expected frequencies of burned clay/earth fragments. Thus, the preliminary interpretation was that the site was thought to have the potential to provide important information that would ultimately further our understanding of the Late Prehistoric period in the region. Discussions with TxDOT personnel, however, resulted in the determination that insufficient information was available for a determination of National Register eligibility. Therefore, additional test excavation in the form of 2-x-2-meter blocks was conducted at the site in 2007. The continued testing of site 41COL173 within the proposed APE (367.9 m2 or 0.09 acre) yielded a very low-density artifact assemblage; and it was determined that the site would not contribute significantly to our understanding of the Late Prehistoric use of the region. There was no evidence of the possibility of cultural features within the portion of the site within the APE. Although the paleosol present on the site provided the potential for intact remains, the artifact recovery was inadequate to provide data sufficient for a significant contribution to our understanding of regional prehistory. Nevertheless, the possibility exists that the site continues beyond the right-of-way because most of the 2007 recovery was adjacent to the southern C-v

SECTION 2 ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING The general environmental setting of site 41COL173 is very similar to the setting of site 41COL172 (see Chapter 2). Both sites are located on the banks of small streams in the upper reaches of the East Fork Trinity basin. The main difference in the two sites pertains to the soil map unit within which the site is situated. Site 41COL173 is mapped as Trinity clay frequently flooded. The Trinity series consists of deep, nearly level, clayey soils on the flood plains of major streams and their tributaries. A representative soil profile contains a very dark gray to dark gray clay A horizon, which measures from 0 to 35 centimeters (cm; 0–14 inches [in]) in thickness. It is underlain by a C horizon of dark gray clay that measures from 35 to 142 cm (14– 56 in) below surface (Hanson and Wheeler 1969:25). The frequently flooded areas of Trinity clay are not suitable for crops, are subject to washing, and they continually receive deposits of new material (Hanson and Wheeler 1969:26). C-5

SECTION 3 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODOLOGY INTRODUCTION The cultural resources investigations recorded in this document pertain to the archeological assessment of the buried prehistoric site 41COL173, in Collin County, Texas. The need to test the site was triggered by its identification in an earlier survey (Sills, et al. 2005), which recommended further investigations be conducted as part of the TxDOT compliance process associated with proposed bridge improvement requirements along FM 981. Therefore, assessment of the sites was required to determine the extent, integrity, and eligibility for National Register inclusion per Section 106 of the NHPA or for designation as an SAL under the Antiquities Code of Texas before construction plans proceed. The testing of the site was performed in conjunction with testing at site 41COL172 during two field sessions. The initial testing at site 41COL173 was conducted in 2006, with continued testing occurring in 2007. The need for two field sessions was based on a determination by TxDOT that insufficient information was obtained at either site in the initial 2006 session to make a final determination of NRHP or SAL eligibility. Additional investigations in the form of backhoe trenches and associated 2-x-2- m units were conducted in 2007. 2006 FIELD PROCEDURES The 2006 field session began with excavation of exploratory trenches using a rubber-tired backhoe. Trench walls and backdirt were examined by staff to determine whether they contained cultural material or features. The trench profiles were cleaned with a shovel and trowel to obtain a flattened plane to observe the stratigraphic sequence. A stratigraphic profile was drawn of the walls with accompanying soil descriptions. A digital photograph was taken of the same wall profiled. Seven trenches were excavated at site 41COL173 during this field season. In addition to the written and photographic observations of stratigraphic setting, two continuous columns of soil samples from the entire exposed stratigraphic sequence were collected from the site. The two trenches containing the two test units with the highest concentrations of cultural materials on the site were selected as sampling locations, which entailed taking approximately 10- x-10-x-5-cm blocks of sediment from the bottom to the top of the trench profile and encasing C-7


---

## Page 763

them in labeled plastic bags. The collection of these continuous stratigraphic sequences was to ensure the collection of data relevant to assist in the process of determining the sequence of the localized depositional regimes. The samples are being temporarily curated at the GMI headquarters in Plano, Texas, until a final decision is made concerning their research potential. The results of these geoarcheological investigations and the full interpretations of the geological setting are presented in Section 4. The field procedures used to excavate the test units were standardized for both sites 41COL172 and 41COL173. The size of the hand-excavated units varied depending on the nature of the deposits when observed during excavation of the trenches. These units measured either 1-x-1 m or .5-x-.5 m in area and were excavated in 10-cm arbitrary levels to varying depths, depending on the presence of cultural material, using shovels, trowels and in some instances picks. No features were encountered during the 2006 excavations; therefore, none of the original units was expanded. The soil removed from each unit was passed through ¼-inch hardware cloth or, in the areas of particularly high clay content, soil was broken down to ¼-inch pieces using a trowel and then sorted. Once excavations were completed, the sites were mapped using a hand-held Trimble XM global positioning system (GPS) device. GPS points were taken at the corners of each trench, the location of the datum points, and from within the center of the test units. These data were later transferred to the ArcView 9 software program and used to configure the site maps presented in this appendix. 2007 FIELD PROCEDURES The 2007 field session began with excavation of two large shallow trenches that were excavated at the site to remove much of the overburden and to allow for placement of two 2-x-2-m blocks. An additional 1-x-2-m block was excavated within Trench 1 at site 41COL173. Once again, the 2-x-2-m blocks were assigned individual unit numbers for each 1-x-1-m unit within the block. No further deep exploratory trenches were excavated at site 41COL173 in the 2007 session. The trenches and excavation units at each site were recorded using a Trimble GPS System. As work progressed, a total station was used to map the trenches, excavation units, and contours at the sites. The data were entered into the ArcView 9 software program to plot the excavations at the sites. ARTIFACT TREATMENT AND ANALYTICAL METHODS All cultural materials collected during the assessment of sites 41COL172 and 41COL173 were brought to the GMI laboratory facilities in Plano, Texas, where all artifacts were washed, catalogued, and labeled in compliance with TARL standards. Following this, preliminary analyses were undertaken on the materials collected during the 2006 field season. The materials collected during the 2007 field season were analyzed in conjunction with the continued data recovery excavations at site 41COL172. The specific analytical methods employed for these analyses are presented in Chapter 4 of the main report. Only those methods that deviated from the analysis of the larger collection are reviewed here. C-8

Mussel shell umbos were analyzed by Charles Randklev at the University of North Texas in Denton. All other artifact classes, such as burned earth/clay, lithics, and FCR, were analyzed by Geo-Marine archeologists. ## Page 766

SECTION 4 RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS Site 41COL173 is located at the junction of FM 981 and Desert Creek, east of the town of Blue Ridge, in Collin County (see Figure C-1). TxDOT is planning to reconstruct the bridge at this location by widening the approaches, extending the roadway surfaces to include shoulders, redesigning the roadway base, and then reconstructing the pavement overlay and pavement markers. In order to accomplish the goal, TxDOT acquired 1.07 acres of new ROW to extend the existing ROW from 90 ft to 165 ft on both the north and south sides of FM 981 (Sills et al. 2005b). The site is reported as extending beyond the extent of the existing road on both the north and south sides of FM 981, west of Desert Creek. The landform is a uniform, level creek bank that is roughly 550 ft amsl. The northwest side of the site has been disturbed by apparent logging activities, and the southern side has a series of large bois d’arc trees that limits the locations for the placement of trenches (Figures C-2and C-3). PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS Previous investigations conducted on this site by PBS&J initially included a combination of pedestrian survey and shovel testing (Sills, et al. 2005). The pedestrian survey and nine shovel tests within the extended ROW for FM 981 failed to identify any cultural remains or reach subsoil. It was subsequently decided an adjusted strategy involving the excavating of exploratory archeological trenches would be undertaken to (1) evaluate the potential for in situ burial of archeological deposits and (2) search for buried archeological sites and evaluate the potential effects of the proposed project on them. The results of the adjusted strategy included the excavation of three backhoe trenches placed as close to the creek banks as possible. Trench 1 was placed on the east bank of Desert Creek north of FM 981, Trench 2 was placed on the west bank of Desert Creek south of FM 981, and Trench 3 was placed on the west bank of Desert Creek north of FM 981. The trenches on the west bank produced culturally related materials, but the trench on the east bank was culturally sterile (Sills, et al. 2005:4). C-11

The cultural material observed from PBS&J Trench 2 south of FM 981 included faunal evidence field-identified as the remains of white-tailed deer and a medial fragment of a biface from a depth between 45–90 cm bs. Faunal material was also collected from Trench 3 on the north side of FM 981 and field-identified as both white-tailed deer and turtle between 70–123 cm bs. The stratigraphic profiles of the two trenches on the west bank of Desert Creek were reported as similar, though a slight color difference was noted between the horizons underlying the cultural- bearing zone. The initial researchers from PBS&J recommended further investigation on the site in order to fully assess the research potential prior to the beginning of construction (Sills, et al. 2005). CURRENT INVESTIGATIONS Stratigraphy Introduction GMI investigated the site during two field seasons, from 13–18 November 2006 and again from August 30 to September 13, 2007, in an attempt to assess further the research potential and eligibility of the site for inclusion in the NRHP and for designation as an SAL. GMI excavated seven exploratory test trenches (A–G) in 2006 to document the geological setting of the site. Once these profiles were investigated, GMI archeologists placed two 1-x-1-m test units off the edge of the two most southeasterly trenches and four 50-x-50-cm units off the edge of four other trenches for the purpose of recovering a representative sample of the cultural material present in the cultural-bearing deposits onsite (see Figure C-3). During those excavations, the cultural- bearing zone was encountered below the modern alluvial deposits at an average depth of 81 cm bs. The distinction between the overlying modern alluvial deposits and the underlying cultural- bearing deposits was demarcated by an easily identifiable unconformity. The cultural-bearing zone was roughly 40 cm thick. In 2007, two additional, shallow trenches (1 and 2) were excavated for the sole purpose of overburden removal. No further exploratory trenches were needed because the stratigraphy of the small site was fairly well known after the 2006 investigations. Initially a single 2-x-2-m block was placed within each trench. Subsequently, a 1-x-2-m block was also excavated within Trench 1. Site Context Site 41COL173 is situated on the relatively level flood plain on the western bank of Desert Creek. The landform is similar on both the north and south sides of FM 981. The northern side of FM 981 has a series of partially filled channel scars, especially in the western portion of the ROW. The southern side of FM 981 is completely flat, except for a deeply incised intermitted streambed at the far western edge of the newly acquired ROW. The intermitted streambed runs west-to-east until reaching the western edge of the ROW, and then it turns sharply to the south passing to the west of the southwestern ROW corner. Numerous large bois d’arc trees are scattered throughout the site area between the intermittent drainage and Desert Creek. C-14

Generalized Sequences Trenches A, C, D, E, 1, and 2 all have the same generalized stratigraphic sequence (Table C-1). The uppermost portion of the sequence is composed of a culturally sterile, modern, alluvial deposit that can be subdivided into two horizons based on the observation of two different depositional layers. Regardless of the separation, each of these horizons has little bearing on the archeological interpretations of the site. The subdivision of the more modern alluvial deposits from previous noncultural alluvial deposits may help in the reconstruction of the former landscape or the land use patterns of the area; thus, this discussion of the alluvial deposits separates the two horizons (Figure C-4). The section focuses on presenting the generalized stratigraphic sequence associated with the site and relates the other trenches to the master sequence. The full descriptions of each trench are found at the end of this document. No additional exploratory trenches were excavated during the 2007 field session; however, the stratigraphy noted within the 2007 shallow trenches and blocks is identical to the stratigraphy in the trenches excavated in 2006. Figure C-4. Profile of south wall, Trench A, site 41COL173. The underlying horizon is composed of laminated clays and sand. The horizon averages 30 cm in thickness and is interpreted as a 2AC horizon of dark gray (10YR 3/1) clay. The zone is characterized by thin interbedded zones of pale brown (10YR 6/3) to very pale brown (10YR 7/3) sand. The horizon has a weakly platy structure with a number of small roots present. The contact between this and the overlying horizon is clear. The next strata are part of the buried paleosol, which is typically encountered from 60–80 cm bd. In Block 1, Trench 1, the paleosol begins with a 3A1b dark gray (10YR 4/1) silty clay followed by a 3A2b very dark gray (10 YR 3/1) silty clay and is slightly thicker than the first. These horizons have a strong blocky structure, and the peds have a calcium carbonate lining. Small roots are present in this horizon, along with many snail shells ranging in size from 0.25 mm to 3 cm in diameter. The 2A2b horizon is the cultural-bearing horizon and averages 40 cm in thickness. In Block 2, Trench 2, the paleosol begins around 80 cm bd and grades from a very dark gray (10YR 3/1) 3Ab to very dark grayish (10YR 3/2) 3ABb clay. This is the cultural- bearing horizon in Block 2. The underlying horizon is the transitional horizon between the buried paleosol and the underlying C horizons reported in the initial survey conducted by PBS&J (Sills, et al. 2005:10). The horizon is composed of a gray (10YR 5/1) clay with a weak to moderate subangular blocky structure and the peds have no lining. Snail shells are fewer in number and exclusively have diameters of 2–3 cm. No roots are present. At the bottom of this horizon, resting on top of a scrolling abrupt boundary with the buried paleosol, are two patches of oxidized and reduced sandy silt indicative of an in situ burning. This evidence of fire is unassociated with the buried paleosol; rather it represents modern activities conducted on the surface of the scrolled interface. There is evidence of a similar occurrence on the north side of FM 981 in Trench G, which will be discussed below. The underlying horizon is the buried A horizon or cultural-bearing layer. It is identical to that observed in Trenches A, C, D, and E but has a different contact with the overlying horizon. The contact represents an unconformity because the surface of this buried A horizon is composed of a wavy boundary mixed with sand. It is unknown how much of the buried A horizon has been disturbed, but the horizon is only 30 cm thick in this location compared to the 40 cm on average observed in the easterly trenches. The buried paleosol is composed of a very dark gray (10YR 3/1) silty clay loam. The horizon has a weak subangular structure, and the peds have a calcium carbonate lining. There are small roots present in this horizon, along with many small snails ranging in size from 0.25 mm to 3 cm in diameter. The underlying AC horizon mirrors the observations made in the eastern trenches. Trench G was excavated on the north side of FM 981 close to the western bank of Desert Creek. Despite being on the other side of the site, the depositional sequence in Trench G is similar to that observed in Trench B. The uppermost horizon composing the modern alluvial deposits is identical to those observed in the southeasterly trenches and correlates well with the Trinity clay series. This horizon is thicker in this location, likely due to the raised roadbed acting as a break, backing up flood waters and ultimately forcing those waters to lose energy and sediment load. The boundary with the underlying horizon is clear. The buried A horizon is partially truncated; it is thinnest on the upstream side (34 cm) and thickest on the downstream side (44 cm). The filled depression is composed of gray (10YR 3/1) clay loam. The fill has a weak, subangular, blocky structure and is roughly 30 cm thick. The underlying horizon dives to the west at a 45-degree angle to the surface. The horizon constitutes the majority of the channel fill and is composed of alternating gray (10YR 4/1) and light gray (10YR 7/1) clays with mottles of dark yellow brown (10YR 4/4) clay. The horizon is a mixture of plated and weak, subangular blocky structures. The bottom of the horizon rests on a relatively flat-lying, 10-cm-thick gravel lens, marking the bottom of the filled channel. ## Page 779

Test Unit 4 (Trench C) Test Unit 4 was positioned off Trench C, which was placed to the west of the halfway point in the newly acquired ROW on the south side of FM 981 (see Figure C-3). The test unit was a 50-x-50- cm unit placed south of the mid-point of Trench C. The stratigraphic profile of the trench was nearly identical to that observed in the eastern trenches; however, the percentage of snail shells was slightly lower and the color of the sediment was lighter. No materials were collected from the excavation of Trench C; rather, the decision to place a test unit off this trench was based on the similarities of the stratigraphic profile to the profiles of the easterly trenches. A total depth of 50 cm was excavated from Test Unit 4, which yielded three bone fragments (see Table C-4). These faunal materials have no distinct characteristics indicating they are culturally related. It is obvious from the lack of other cultural material that this area is peripheral to the site. Test Unit 5 (Trench B) Test Unit 5 was a 50-x-50-cm unit located off the mid-point of the northern side of Trench B, which is the westernmost trench on the south side of FM 981 (see Figure C-3). Trench B is bordered to the west by a deeply incised, intermittent stream, and it marks the western edge of the newly acquired ROW. Placement of a trench this far to the west was based on the similarity of the topography across the newly acquired ROW. The entire southern portion of the ROW appears to be the same landform, and thus the decision was made to obtain a rough profile of the landform. The total depth of the test unit was 50 cm because the uppermost portion of the buried paleosol had been truncated by either fluvial processes or road construction activities. The 32 fragments of collected bone constitute one badly fragmented antler (see Table C-4). Additionally, three pieces of FCR refit into one small cobble were recovered from the same level. These remains were not found within the fluvial-impacted sediments, and they are interpreted as unrelated to the materials farther east. The low density of artifacts likewise indicates that this unit is beyond the western margin of site 41COL173. Test Unit 6 (Trench G) Test Unit 6 was a 50-x-50-cm unit located off the northeast corner of Trench G, which is the trench located closest to the west bank of Desert Creek on the north side of FM 981 (see Figure C-3). During the excavation of Trench G, a medium-sized, burned bois d’arc tree was encountered on the southern side of the trench. The burned tree trunk is associated with the top of the unconformity at the base of the alluvial deposits, and it is interpreted as being related to initial FM 981 road construction. No cultural materials were found during the trench excavation. A total depth of 60 cm was excavated from this unit. Four fragments of bone were recovered in the uppermost portion of the first level. These fauna are identified as white-tailed deer and may be associated with the alluvial deposit rather than the paleosol in this location. This hypothesis stems from the fact that the uppermost portion of this test unit was a mixture of buried paleosol and alluvial deposits resulting from the long teeth on the backhoe bucket. Given the low density of the materials recovered from a largely questionable context, Test Unit 6 is presumed to be beyond the northern extent of site 41COL173 (see Table C-4). C-24

## Page 784

Artifact Analysis In total, 423 artifacts were recovered from this site in 2006 and 2007. Backhoe trench excavations yielded a piece of FCR, one piece of charcoal, and four bones. The lithics and the charcoal came from Trench A and the bone from Trench D. Excavation of the test units produced a similar pattern, indicating the eastern portion of the site was the area of primary use. Artifacts recovered in 2006 from the hand excavation of the test units consist of three stone tools (two arrow projectile points and a fragment of an end scraper), 20 pieces of FCR, 10 pieces of debitage, a piece of charcoal, 67 fragments of bone, 25 pieces of shell, and 47 pieces of burned clay/earth. Of these 173 artifacts, the majority (n=131) were recovered from the eastern portion of the south side of FM 981 near the west bank of Desert Creek. The collections from 2007 consist of 18 lithics, 84 pieces of FCR, 85 bones fragments, 53 baked clay nodules, and 10 mussel shells fragments. The vast majority of the artifacts came from Block 1, perhaps indicating that, based on Block 1 and Trench A, the greater portion of the site lies adjacent to and south of the ROW boundary and immediately adjacent to the creek bank. The miniscule recovery from every trench and block north and west of Block 1 seems to confirm this assertion. Lithics The lithic assemblage recovered in 2006 from site 41COL173 contains two projectile points, one fragment of an exhausted end scraper, eight flakes, two pieces of shatter, and 21 fragments of FCR. All of the lithic materials are identified as being of local raw materials, with the exception of one projectile point. The 2007 collection contains 18 lithics and 84 small fragments of FCR. The two projectile points represent two different diagnostic types recovered from Levels 2 and 3 in Test Unit 1. The projectile point recovered from Level 2 is identified as a Catahoula point (Bell 1960:16; Justice 1987:237; Turner, et al. 1999:206). The specimen from Level 3 is identified as a Cuney point (Suhm and Jelks 1962:271; Turner, et al. 1999:210). The identifications of these points are tentative, because stylistically they exhibit elements characteristic of other chronologically similar points such as Alba and the small end of the continuum of Scallorn. Regardless, the chronological position of these point types rests in the Late Prehistoric period A.D. 700/800–1200, with the Cuney type extending into the Contact period in specific locations. The Catahoula point is fairly small with an over length of 20 mm (Table C-8). The blade edge is serrated and appears to be the byproduct of resharpening while hafted. The point was manufactured from a heat-treated quartzite of local origin (Figure C-12). These types of points are identified as having a local geographic distribution extending through northeast and southeast Texas and Louisiana (Bell 1960:16; Justice 1987:237; Turner, et al. 1999:206). The reported date range for this type extends from A.D. 700 to the Contact period, depending on the reference. The type was identified in the region on the Upper Rockwell site, 41RW2 (Ross 1966:22–24). C-29

The Cuney point type is less well known because many standard texts on diagnostic chipped stone tools lack a discussion of the type (Bell 1960; Justice 1987). Turner et al. (1999) does discuss the point type, and they suggest a general date range beginning in the Late Prehistoric period and extending into the Contact period, but without the support of chronometric dates. The collected Cuney point from this site is relatively small, similar to the Catahoula point, with an overall length of 24 mm (see Table C-8). The edges are also serrated, but this specimen lacks the signs of resharpening. The raw material is silicified sandstone, which likely of foreign origin and may potentially be an imported item from the east (Figure C-13). The type was identified in the region on the Pecan Springs site, 41EL11 (Sorrow, et al. 1966:23). The end scraper fragment from the site is composed of heat-treated local undifferentiated Uvalde chert. Under 15x magnification, the piece shows signs of wear along one edge similar to wear patterns associated with the use of stone against both hard and soft materials. This artifact was recovered from Trench A, Test Unit 1, which is the same test unit from which the two projectile points were recovered. C-30

The Vertebrate Fauna A total of 132 fragments of bone were recovered from 41COL173, 91 of which were identified to taxon or size class (Table C-9). Approximately 80.2 percent (n=73) of the identifiable faunal assemblage consists of deer size fragments. Of this deer size total, deer size long-bone shaft fragments account for 34.2 percent, while antler fragments account for 41.1 percent. Only 4 specimens, all first phalange fragments from a single excavation unit, were identified to white- tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus). The presence of white-tailed deer in the fauna is not surprising given that they represented the largest-bodied, consistently available prey to humans in eastern North America during most of the Holocene. Unfortunately, due to the small sample size, it is not possible to interpret carcass exploitation strategies aside from noting the presence of green fracturing which is indicative of marrow extraction. All of the Bison bison specimens (n=4) were confidently distinguished from domestic cattle using modern comparative materials and published criteria (Lawrence 1951; Olsen 1960). The metatarsal fragment and three phalanges assigned to Bison bison in the assemblage may refit anatomically; however, the metatarsal has weathered and deteriorated through time, thus precluding refitting. A long-bone shaft fragment, a third phalanx fragment, a vertebrae fragment, and an unidentifiable fragment were assigned to the bison size class because diagnostic features for species designation were not present. From a biogeographic perspective, 41COL173 is important because it offers additional evidence as to the Holocene distribution of Bison bison in Texas. C-32

Taphonomy Most of the 41COL173 fauna is highly fragmented as a result of a combination both human and non-human derived taphonomic factors. Approximately 92.2 percent of the site assemblage consists of fragments between 1 and 5 cm in length, and no fragments are larger than 10 cm (Table C-10). According to Lyman (1994b) and Shaffer (1992), such a bias towards the recovery of fragments less than 5 cm in size is typical of collections screened with 0.25-inch mesh. Table C-11 presents the percentages of each taphonomic characteristic present in the 41COL173 faunal assemblage. Green fracturing is exhibited on 14.4 percent of the specimens, indicating that humans may have been fracturing long bones in order to extract marrow. However, 5.3 percent of the specimens (n=7) display carnivore damage. Since carnivores and humans are both known to fracture fresh bone marrow cavities (Lyman 1994b), it is possible that carnivore damage is responsible for some if not all of the green fracturing observed in the assemblage. Clear evidence that the 41COL173 is in fact archeological, however, is provided by the high proportion of remains that exhibit high-temperature burning (Table C-12). Partially calcined (whitened) bone occurs at temperatures between about 500 and 600°C, and calcined (whitened and chalky) bone occurs at temperatures greater than about 700°C. Conclusion Most of the specimens recovered from site 41COL173 are too fragmented to provide diagnostic criteria for identification. As a result, only brief discussion of taphonomy is possible. The fauna is small, yet it contains remains of a taxon that is important in terms of its biogeography—Bison bison. The rest of the fauna primarily reflects taxa that are commonly represented as remains of prehistoric diet throughout much of the Midwest and Texas during the Late Holocene, primarily white-tailed deer. A few taxa recovered from the site (e.g., snakes, turtles and cotton rats) might have been naturally deposited. Overall, the fauna is remarkably uniform in its taphonomy, which is a product of nearly all of the remains being highly fragmented and/or burned. C-34

## Page 790

Burned Clay/Earth Excavations on site 41COL173 yielded a total of 101 pieces of burned clay/earth. All but two pieces were recovered from the two easternmost units (Test Units 1 and 2) and Blocks 1 and 3; the remaining two pieces came from Test Unit 3. These units are in the eastern half of the ROW on the south side of FM 981. The fragments of burned clay/earth from this site are all under 25.4 mm (< 1 in) and 78% of the specimens are under 12.7 mm (0.5 in). Some (n=7; 6.9 percent) exhibit impressions of being wrapped around an object such as a stick or perhaps a root. It is possible, though not highly represented in the collection, that some of these fragments represent evidence of a wattle-and-daub structure. The high frequency of burned clay/earth correlates well with the location of the burned faunal material. These pieces of evidence in conjunction with the observed charcoal flecking in the matrix of the eastern test units indicates a high potential for in situ evidence of fire. Mussel Shell The 25 fragments of mussel shell recovered in 2006 from site 41COL173 during the GMI assessment came from the eastern Test Units 1, 2, and 3. All of the mussel shell fragments (n=10) recovered in 2007 came from Block 1. Of the fragments collected, only 4 umbo fragments could be assigned to a specific taxon. The rest were unidentifiable. A total of 4 specimens belonged to the Uniomerus teralasmus (Pondhorn) species and the other to Lampsilis hydiana (Louisiana Fatmucket). Both species appear to be locally abundant and are well adapted to low flow conditions (Howells, et al. 1996). Thus, the mussel shells recovered are considered ubiquitous inclusions in the site matrix because of the proximity of Desert Creek. Summary Site 41COL173 is situated in a very dynamic setting within the flood plain of Desert Creek. Fluvial erosion and the original construction of FM 981 have impacted the site. The site area within the APE is approximately 367.9 m2 or 0.09 acre. It is highly probable that portions of the site have been eroded away by Desert Creek. Portions of the site context remain preserved with a paleosol buried approximately 80 cm below the present-day flood plain surface. Although the 2006 Geo-Marine investigations indicated that the site might have the potential to contain a well- preserved Late Prehistoric component or components, the excavation of an additional 4.3 cubic meters of site matrix failed to yield significant data. Block 1, situated at the southern edge of the APE, exhibits the greatest abundance of artifactual material, while Blocks 2 and 3 yielded little more than fire-cracked rock. Fire-cracked rock and burned clay are most abundant in Units 11– 14; however, these materials are scattered, small, and do not represent an intact feature. The burned clay items are very small in size (<15 mm) and do not represent daub. Rather, it appears that the remains of a short-term occupation with a small hearth were scattered by flood action shortly following the occupation. It is entirely possible that cultural deposits that are more extensive exist outside the boundary of the APE. C-35

SECTION 5 SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS SUMMARY Test excavations conducted on site 41COL173 in Collin County, Texas, were designed to determine the horizontal and vertical extent of the cultural deposits within the ROW and determine the contextual integrity of the deposits. This was performed in order to assess the site for its eligibility for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places, as per Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA) of 1966, as amended through 2004 [16 U.S.C. § 470 et seq.; P.L. 89–665; 80 Stat. 915] and for designation as a State Archeological Landmark under the Antiquities Code of Texas [Title 9, Chapter 191, the Natural Resources Code of Texas]. The results of the test excavations and the interpretations of those investigations are discussed in the previous section. This section presents a more detailed discussion of the NRHP and SAL criteria and provides a summary of the site assessment in relation to the potential for fulfilling these criteria. Site 41COL173 Like site 41COL172 (discussed in the main body of this report), site 41COL173 provides evidence of the use of the Blackland Prairie by people during the Late Prehistoric period. The site can be cross-dated to between A.D. 700/800 and the historic period on the basis of two diagnostic arrow points recovered from the site. The two projectile points are identified as Catahoula and Cuney types. Both types have been recovered from other sites within the region, but the Catahoula type has associated chronometric dates. The site context within the proposed APE is preserved in a small area adjacent to the west bank of Desert Creek. The site may extend southward outside of the expanded right-of-way. The 2006 investigations revealed diagnostic artifacts, well-preserved bone, and much burned earth/baked clay in a restricted area along the west bank of Desert Creek. The continued testing of the site in 2007 was carried out to acquire additional data to determine the site’s data potential. C-37

## Page 793

The baked clay from the 2006 investigations was also thought to represent daub from the walls of a structure; consequently, the site was initially thought to exhibit excellent contextual integrity. The 2007 investigations demonstrated that the original view of the site was flawed. The distribution of FCR and the nature of the baked clay clearly suggest that site 41COL173 is a very low-density site that appears to have been impacted by fluvial erosion. No intact features were found within the excavation blocks. ELIGIBILITY FOR INCLUSION IN THE NRHP The archeological property discussed in this report were evaluated according to criteria based on federal regulations for determining the significance of cultural resources for inclusion in the NRHP. Determinations of eligibility for inclusion in the NRHP are applied following the identification of relevant historical themes and related research questions: The quality of significance in American history, architecture, archeology, and culture is present in districts, sites, buildings, structures, and objects that possess integrity of location, design, setting, materials, workmanship, feeling, and association, and: (a) that are associated with events that have made a significant contribution to the broad patterns of our history; or (b) that are associated with the lives of persons significant in our past; or (c) that embody the distinctive characteristics of a type, period, or method of construction, or that represent a significant and distinguishable entity whose components may lack individual distinction; or (d) that have yielded, or may be likely to yield, information important in prehistory or history [36 CFR § 60.4]. Usually, Criterion ―d‖ is applied to most prehistoric and many historic sites. Important information is generally recognized to refer to scientific importance. However, scientific importance is partially driven by the research perspectives of the time and in part by the state of available information regarding a particular research topic in a specific research area. The purpose for conducting archeology should not be to fill museum drawers with relics, but rather to fill informational gaps relating to specific research domains. As research progresses within a region, well-excavated sites contribute information to some of those research domains. Through time, data needs for some research questions may be addressed to various degrees, even though complementary data are often needed from different periods, seasons, settings, and site types to fully understand the diversity of activities. As data required to address specific questions approach redundancy, such information may diminish the priority of that kind of repetitive information needed from nearby sites. This suggests that the identification criteria of important historic properties are tied to both a specific geographical area, reflecting a cultural adaptation or region, and a state of accumulated knowledge about a research domain. Archeological sites with integrity containing artifacts and features that can contribute information toward addressing research issues are regarded as significant and are eligible for inclusion in the NRHP. Archeological sites that exist on static landforms, such as bedrock surfaces or ancient upland hilltops that lack eolian sands, can contain concentrated densities of artifacts and feature remains. Such ―palimpsest‖ remains of occupations are generally regarded as having very little or no research potential for contributing useful information toward the understanding of prehistory, because the artifact assemblages are mixed and not interpretable. In such cases, the sites are not regarded as scientifically important, and in general, these kinds of sites are not eligible for inclusion in the NRHP. C-38

## Page 794

The most ideal kinds of archeological remains are those left in rapidly aggrading settings, where there is a chance for noncultural sediments to separate a series of materials and residues representing brief, short-term activities. Usually, aggrading alluvial, wind-blown or eolian sand sheets and dunes, and sometimes colluvial slopewash are the kinds of settings and events that are apt to quickly bury archeological remains and preserve the discreteness of activities. The evaluation of the depositional context of a site is one of the key characteristics for distinguishing the integrity of deposits. Comments on NRHP Eligibility Criteria The assessment of NRHP and SAL eligibility is often accomplished through the implementation of test excavations. Of particular importance is the requirement that an archeological property should be capable of yielding information important to the understanding of prehistory or history. To guide research in Northeast Texas, which affects both sites 41COL172 and 41COL173 because of their locations, Peter et al. (1990) proposed a series of research themes specific to the region. Also applicable are five broad, regional historic contexts, or ―study units,‖ defined by the Texas Historical Commission as having priority for prehistoric studies in Northeast Texas, along with various associated research questions (Kenmotsu and Perttula 1993). The research themes applicable to the Late Prehistoric site 41COL173 are summarized below (Table C-13). Table C-13 Research Themes for the Prehistoric Contexts for Northeast Texas General Research Themes (Peter, et al. 1990) (1) Paleoenvironmental Reconstruction (2) Culture History (3) Prehistoric Settlement-Subsistence Systems (4) Prehistoric Lithic Raw Material Use Patterns (5) Prehistoric Technology TxDOT Historic Context, ―People of the Prairie: A Possible Connection to the Davis Site Caddo (Shafer 2006) THC Historic Contexts/Study Units (3) ―Emergence of Sedentism in the Northeast Texas Archeological Region, ca. 500 B.C.–A.D. 1000‖ (Kenmotsu and Perttula 1993) (a) Paleoenvironments (b) Settlement Systems (c) Subsistence Systems (d) Social Systems (e) Demography and Health (f) Mortuary Practices (g) Intra- and Interregional Exchange and Interaction (h) Material Culture Characterizations (i) Technological Change C-39

## Page 795

Information is useless in a vacuum. Thus, the first criterion of significance for any archeological property is considered its capability to yield information relevant to one of the historic contexts or research themes listed in Table C-13. Of course, whether or not specific archeological properties exhibit such potential or contain data relevant to any particular historic context or research theme is dependent upon a precondition of contextual integrity of the archeological deposits. For example, a prehistoric site buried by sediment within an aggrading river levee has a far greater potential for containing undisturbed deposits than one located on an eroding upland surface. The nature of contextual integrity as it affects the research potential of a property must also be viewed as relative, since different research problems require different types of data. In their introduction to the East Texas plan, Kenmotsu and Perttula (1993:10) note the following: It is a truism that most archeological sites are disturbed due to a variety of natural and cultural processes, such as bioturbation and timbering. However, just because they have been disturbed does not mean that their integrity has been unduly diminished or lost. It has been demonstrated time and again that archeological deposits containing significant information are still intact and have integrity even after agricultural activities, timbering, etc., have occurred, because these land-disturbing actions only penetrate a certain subsurface depth and can be expected to leave features and archeological deposits below a plow zone or churned soil. The best way to determine the condition and integrity of an archeological site is to examine its subsurface context through soil probes and exploratory test units dispersed across the site, and assess the level of soil churning, the stratigraphy, and the potential for middens and cultural features to be preserved. The test excavations GMI conducted at site 41COL173 were designed to provide an assessment of the following: 1. The review and assessment of the geological and stratigraphic setting of the cultural deposits (i.e., is the site undisturbed, bioturbated, deflated, etc.). 2. The review and assessment of the cultural deposits (i.e., the range of artifactual and feature information available). 3. To collect a representative sample from the cultural-bearing deposits, conduct preliminary analysis, and provide a baseline interpretation of the site (i.e., diagnostic artifacts such as ceramics and projectile points, faunal material, etc.) 4. To place the site interpretations into the wider context of the relevant research environment and assess the site’s potential of assisting research in answering those questions (i.e., regional culture history, subsistence practices of the Late Prehistoric, settlement patterns of the Late Prehistoric, etc.) One goal of this project was to use the information derived from the investigations to evaluate each site and its potential for increasing our knowledge of past lifeways, contributing to the resolution of regionally pertinent research questions, or containing information relevant to any of the above research themes or problems. The archeological site is situated on lands owned or controlled by the State of Texas or one of its political subdivisions; or C-40

2. The archeological site is situated on private land that has been specifically designated as an SAL . . . and fits at least one of the following criteria: (A) Preservation of materials must be sufficient to allow application of standard archeological techniques to advantage; (B) The majority of artifacts are in place so that a significant portion of the site’s original characteristics can be defined through investigation; (C) The site has the potential to contribute to cumulative culture history by the addition of new information; (D) The site offers evidence of unique or rare attributes; and/or (E) The site offers a unique and rare opportunity to test techniques, theory, or methods or preservation, thereby contributing to scientific knowledge [Texas Natural Resources Code 1977; Title 9, Chapter 191, Texas Antiquities Committee, Section 191.094 and Chapter 41.7, Antiquities Code of Texas]. Comments on SAL Eligibility Criteria Site 41COL173 is slated by TxDOT as a location for road improvement. Thus, because TxDOT is an entity of the State of Texas, the first condition of the SAL designation is met. The five criteria of the second condition are very generalized, occasionally ambiguous, and might apply to virtually any archeological site. For example, the first criterion of sufficient preservation of materials to ―allow application of standard archeological techniques to advantage‖ is vague as to the meaning of the use of ―techniques to advantage.‖ Clearly, some kind of surface recording techniques could be applied to preserve chipped stone remains in a highly disturbed and shallow archeological site for the advantage of illustrating methods in a classroom teaching exercise. Nevertheless, we would argue that without some degree of context, such sites are neither worthy of nor warrant SAL designation simply because they contain archeological remains. We tend to place greater emphasis on the SAL criteria for sites with integrity (condition B), addition of new information (condition C), and/or unique or rare attributes (condition D), over the criteria for the preservation sufficient to apply archeological techniques (condition A), or the mere opportunity to test techniques, theories, and methods (condition E). In so doing, SAL criteria strongly resemble NRHP criteria involving the criteria of site integrity and potential to contain information significant to prehistory. ## Page 798

Paleoenvironmental Reconstruction Similar to the requirements of the Regional Cultural Chronology theme, any study intending to reconstruct the paleoenvironment is dependent upon good chronographic control. Additionally, for the reconstruction to be truly useful to furthering archeological understanding, the study needs to be problem driven and tailored to the specific archeological research questions. Simply reconstructing the local environmental record of an archaeological site with little other research value limits the usefulness of the paleoenvironmental study. Given that there is a paucity of datable materials at site 41COL173, and that the site is of very little other research value, it is doubtful that continued efforts focused on paleoenvironment will yield useful data. Site Function The determination of site function is critical to the placement of 41COL173 within the overall settlement pattern of the Late Prehistoric period. Significant quantities of both artifacts and features in primary, isolable contexts are essential for determining site function. The excavations at 41COL173 produced a very minimal collection of cultural material and a total absence of evidence for the presence of features within the ROW portion of the site. Thus, it is unlikely that additional excavations would produce substantial data pertaining to either the function of the site or to the specific behaviors represented. Settlement Patterns Presently, it is hypothesized that site 41COL173 represent a type of hunting and animal processing station that may have been used on a cyclical basis. The lack of formal features and a very limited artifact assemblage at site 41COL173 severely limits any interpretation of its role in the larger settlement pattern. An examination of the of the raw materials used at the site can be used to indicate whether the site was occupied by local groups or by intruders from the Caddo region (e.g., Peter and McGregor 1988; Shafer 2006). The Cuney projectile point found at the site appears to be from a nonlocal material. The remainder of the assemblage consists entirely of local materials. Given the lack of datable materials and the extremely low density of artifactual remains, it seems unlikely that the site would yield information pertaining to the origin of the Cuney point or the prehistoric group responsible for the site. Subsistence Practices A sizeable faunal collection is needed to address research questions relating to subsistence practices through prey mortality analysis, consideration of foraging efficiency by prey choice as compared to diet breadth models and prey mortality, and the analysis of carcass exploitation (butchering procedures). Although site 41COL173 exhibited a high level of preservation of faunal materials, the overall faunal densities appear to be too low to address significant research issues. However, given that the faunal collection includes bison, and there are only a few regional archaeological sites dating to the Late Prehistoric with associated bison remains, the site is important from a biogeographical perspective. Still, the lack of dateable features at site 41COL173 does not allow a clear definition of the time period involved. C-43

## Page 799

Another issue worthy of pursuit on site 41COL173 relates to the high percentage of calcined bone in the faunal assemblage. The calcination of bone requires sustained temperatures of 600–700° C, which is a temperature range obtainable in open campfires. Although the discovery of such a feature would aid greatly in the understanding of the site function and the subsistence practices of Late Prehistoric peoples, the potential for such a feature to be preserved within the right-of-way appears to be very limited. Technological Patterns Technology and the processes prehistoric people used to convert raw materials into consumable goods is the basis for understanding behaviors of Late Prehistoric populations in the upper East Fork of the Trinity River. In light of the kinds of materials associated with these sites, future analysis should focus on issues relating to lithic technologies. Site 41COL173 was presumed to have the potential to provide data relevant to furthering the collective knowledge of Late Prehistoric lithic technology. The presence of two diagnostic projectile points—one of which appears to have been resharpened on the haft—offered the chance to further understand chipped stone tool maintenance. The collection and processing of flotation samples would indicate the presence or absence of microdebitage. In addition, the Cuney projectile point appears to be made from a nonlocal lithic material. It is uncertain if the point was manufactured onsite or brought to the site in a finished form. The analysis of microdebitage would assist in the determination of chipped stone tool production and maintenance onsite. These projectile points could also be investigated for signs of wear. Unfortunately the 2007 excavations recovered only one lithic tool from the block excavations on site 41COL173. Whatever potential data the site might contain is likely beyond the ROW boundary. Regional Exchange and Interaction There are no specific items that would be immediately labeled as exotics in the assemblage from site 41COL173. The absence of these remains limits insight into long-distance exchange. However, there are items present in the assemblage that represent exchange: for example, the Cuney point on site 41COL173. It is presently unclear the type of exchange or interaction that this artifact represents. Site 41COL173 offers little or no data that would help address this research issue. Summary The portion of site 41COL173 within the proposed APE exhibits a very low-density artifact assemblage that will not contribute significantly to our understanding of the Late Prehistoric use of the region. There was no evidence of the possibility of cultural features within the portion of the site within the APE. Although the paleosol present on the site provided the potential for intact remains, the artifact recovery was inadequate to provide data sufficient for a significant contribution to our understanding of regional prehistory. Therefore, site 41COL173 is recommended as ineligible for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places; consequently, no further work is recommended at site 41COL173. Nevertheless, it is unknown if C-44

BACKHOE TRENCHES FROM SITE 41COL173 Profile of the South Wall Trench A: This was the first trench placed on site 41COL173. The trench was placed closest to the western edge of Desert Creek on the south side of FM 981. Trench A was located just within the southeastern corner of the newly acquired ROW and roughly 5 m south of initial survey Trench #2. The trench was aligned 600 east of magnetic north and was 4.25 m long, 1.2 m wide at the top and 0.8 meters wide at the bottom, and 1.7 m deep. Once excavated and profiled it was decided the test unit would be located off of the south east corner of the trench. The overburden was removed to make space for a 1.5 m by 2.2 m rectangle, which allowed for the placement of a 1-x-1-m unit. ## Page 837

Profile of the West Wall of Trench E: Trench E was placed to the west of Trench A. It was the fifth trench placed on the southern side of FM 981. The reason why it was the fifth was due to the fact the backhoe had to excavate the trenches moving from the west to east in order to be able to get out of the ROW space safely. Thus, after Trench A was excavated the backhoe went to the western boundary of the newly acquired ROW and proceeded to excavated four additional trenches across the ROW in an easterly direction. It was decided Test Unit #2 would be placed in this trench because it was expected the artifact densities would decrease moving westward, which meant this trench received a higher priority than test units to the west. Trench E was orientated 90o east of north and measured 5.3 m long, 1.4 m wide at the top and 0.8 m wide at the bottom, and extended to a depth of 1.7 m. The stratigraphic profile was identical to that observed in Trench A. Once excavated and profiled it was decided the test unit would be located off of the south east corner of the trench. The overburden was removed from the northeast corner to make space for a 2.3 m by 2 m rectangle, which allowed for the placement of a 1-x-1-m unit 50 cm west of the east wall. ## Page 841

Profile of the North Wall of Trench F: Trench F was the second trench located on the north side of FM 981. The trench was placed in this location to test a small topographic rise that was thought to potentially be associated with site 41COL173. Once the trench was excavated it was realized this was not the case, as the trench profile was reminiscent of a filled in channel. The lack of an intact paleosol and the presence of apparent channel fill forced GMI archeologists to abandon excavations in this trench. The trench was profiled and documented before the trench was refilled. Trench F was orientated roughly 90o east of magnetic north and measured 4 m long, 1.3 m wide at the top and 0.7 m wide at the bottom, and extended to a depth of 1.8 m. The profile presented below takes into account only the area on the western edge of the profile. Depth (cm bs) Soil Zone Description 0-32 Disturbance Dark gray (10YR 4/1) clay loam; subangular blocky structure; small roots; contact with underlying horizon is abrupt marking an unconformity. This may be a filled in tree fall. 32-140 AC Horizon Banded mottled gray (10YR 5/1) and light gray (10YR 7/1) with blocks of yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) and streaks of light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) clays; weak to moderate massive structure; moderately plastic; the contact between this and the underlying horizon is abrupt and marked by a 10 cm thick lens of gravels marking an unconformity. The horizon grades into dark colors as the moisture levels in the sediments increase. 140-172 C Horizon Light gray to very light brownish gray (10YR 7/1-6/2) clay; weak to moderate massive structure; moderately plastic. Profile of the South Wall of Trench G: Trench G was the first trench located on the north side of FM 981. The trench was placed as close to the edge of the Desert Creek bank as possible. The Trench was located only a couple of meters to the south of where the initial survey Trench 3 was excavated. Trench G was placed in this location to confirm the presence of cultural material in this location. Trench G was orientated roughly 90o east of magnetic north and measured 3.9 m long, 1.3 m wide at the top and 0.7 m wide at the bottom, and extended to a depth of 1.6 m. The profile indicated the presence of a paleosol, but the material recovered is likely natural. The buried paleosol is much lighter in color in this location than on the southern side of FM 981, most likely due to the lack of human signature.
